Iollann, after choosing to retreat and regroup, decides to seek a diplomatic resolution with Fionn and the Fianna, resulting in a newfound alliance with Ireland that honors both his fallen brothers and his kinship with the tales he shared.

name: The Death of Bran
story:
The Death of Bran
Bás Bhrain (The Death of Bran)
Further Information
A death of Bran unlike Bá/Imeacht Bhrain or Comhairle Oisein dha Mhàthair
Fionn kills his hound Bran in this story. In the County Limerick version, Fionn is forced to put Bran down when he becomes rabid after killing a large, mystical black bird. (This is very similar to an episode in many versions of the tale Cailín Aimsire Phádraig [St Patrick’s Housekeeper].)

In the County Sligo version, which incorporates an international tale (ATU 178A), Fionn arrives after Bran has saved his infant son from an attacking wolf. Fionn notices that the child is not in his crib and sees blood around Bran’s mouth from his fight with the wolf. He wrongly assumes the worst and hastily kills his faithful hound. When the child is later found safe and sound with the body of the slain wolf nearby, Fionn regrets killing the hound.

scenes.setting: A dense forest where Bran has just returned after encountering a mystical black bird.
scenes.action: Fionn notices Bran's strange behavior after killing the mystical bird. Bran begins to act erratically.
choices: Calm Bran and investigate the source of the behavior.
Observe Bran from a distance to ascertain more information.
Immediately restrain Bran, fearing a rabid outburst.
scenes.trigger: If Fionn calms Bran, he notices the bird's mystical aura and prepares for a cure. Observing leads to information about the bird's influence. Restraining Bran pushes Fionn to a rash decision to put Bran down.

scenes.setting: Fionn's homestead, where he finds his baby missing from the crib and Bran nearby.
scenes.action: Fionn sees blood around Bran's mouth and assumes Bran has harmed the infant.
choices: Examine the area for clues before confronting Bran.
Immediately act on suspicion and confront Bran.
Call for assistance to understand the situation.
scenes.trigger: Examining the area may reveal wolf tracks and lead to finding the infant safe. Confronting Bran leads to haste and potential tragedy. Calling for assistance unravels the situation through a community response.

scenes.setting: The clearing near Fionn's homestead, where the truth about Bran's actions is revealed.
scenes.action: The body of the slain wolf is discovered, proving Bran's innocence and bravery.
choices: Honor Bran's loyalty with a commemorative ritual.
Grieve the mistake and vow to learn from the hasty choice.
scenes.trigger: Honoring Bran leads to a celebratory acknowledgment of heroism. Grieving the mistake leads to Fionn's self-reflection and personal growth, altering how he interacts in future dilemmas.

choicelist: Fionn, equipped with insights from calming Bran earlier, desperately searches for signs of the mystical bird's influence before anger swells within him, leading him to falsely assume Bran has harmed the infant upon seeing blood around Bran's mouth.

Though Fionn had wisely chosen to observe Bran and had seen signs of the bird's mystical influence, he now faces a surge of fear and self-doubt upon discovering his child missing, as Bran sits nearby with blood around his mouth, leading Fionn to assume Bran has harmed the infant.

Fionn, gripped by anxiety over Bran's restrained state and fearful of a rabid attack, hastily returns home to find his baby missing from the crib and blood around Bran's mouth, jumping to the conclusion that Bran has harmed the infant.

Having discovered the wolf tracks leading out of the homestead, Fionn's heart swells with relief and fury as he realizes his distrust almost cost him Bran's life, igniting a conflict within him that cannot be easily quelled, as the body of the slain wolf is discovered, proving Bran's innocence and bravery.

Fionn, overwhelmed with guilt and the weight of his rash decision, grieves deeply as his warriors and kin, shocked and accusatory, demand answers for Bran’s unjust fate, leading to the climactic discovery of the slain wolf that redeems Bran's loyalty and bravery.

As Fionn calls for assistance, the gathered Fianna arrive, tense and wary, and the group confronts Bran together, leading to the discovery of the slain wolf and revealing Bran's innocence and bravery.

Through a heartfelt commemorative ritual honoring Bran's loyalty and bravery, Fionn and the Fianna pay tribute to the hound's heroism, fostering a renewed sense of camaraderie and commitment to thoughtful decision-making within the group.
Fionn solemnly buries Bran with heartfelt sorrow, dedicating himself to thoughtful decision-making and ensuring his heroic actions will be guided by wisdom and patience in memory of his loyal hound.

name: The Death of Coireal
story:
The Death of Coireal
Bàs Choireil (The Death of Coireal)
A dispute arose between Goll mac Morna and Caireall son of Fionn. Goll was Fionn’s best warrior and so received special honour; in particular, he would get the “mìr-mòr”, the choice portion at their feasts. Caireall resented his pre-eminence, saying he was now old and unworthy of the honour of a great warrior. Caireall’s challenge of Goll to combat begins a lay on the topic.

At first Caireall and Goll wrestled, but neither was able to win. Next, they fought with weapons, and this time Goll killed Caireall with his spear. Fionn then mourned the death of his son.

scenes.setting: A grand hall where the Fianna gather for a feast, filled with laughter and storytelling.
scenes.action: Tensions arise as Caireall expresses his resentment towards Goll's honored status at the feast.
choices: Caireall challenges Goll to a combat to prove his worth.
Caireall decides to speak privately with Fionn to express his grievances.
Caireall chooses to leave the feast to avoid further conflict.
scenes.trigger: If Caireall challenges Goll, it leads directly to a combat scene. Speaking with Fionn delays the conflict, providing a strategic perspective. Leaving could avert immediate conflict, but tensions remain.

scenes.setting: A clearing in a dense forest, a traditional battleground for the Fianna.
scenes.action: Caireall and Goll engage in a wrestling match, testing each other's strength.
choices: Caireall focuses on defense, looking for a mistake from Goll.
Caireall goes on the offensive, trying to overpower Goll.
Caireall calls for a pause to negotiate terms or understanding.
scenes.trigger: Defensive play might prolong the struggle, offering no clear victor yet. Offensive action leads directly to further escalation and combat with weapons. Negotiation might give room for diplomacy if Fionn intervenes.

scenes.setting: A shadowed part of the forest where the final weapon duel takes place.
scenes.action: The fight escalates as both warriors draw weapons, and the duel's outcome becomes imminent.
choices: Caireall fights with all his might, accepting the duel's fate.
Caireall attempts to disarm Goll, hoping to end the conflict without bloodshed.
scenes.trigger: If Caireall fights on, Goll proves victorious, leading to Fionn's mourning over his son. If Caireall attempts to disarm and succeeds, a new resolution might be sparked by showing mercy, altering Fionn's perspective on leadership and honor.

choicelist: With tension crackling through the air and the weight of his challenge pressing heavily upon him, Caireall lunges at Goll, his heart burning with the need to vindicate his honor, as they engage in a wrestling match, testing each other's strength.

Fionn's attempts at mediation between Caireall and Goll backfire, igniting Goll's fury at being openly challenged and resulting in the two warriors engaging ferociously in a wrestling match, testing each other's strength.

Driven by shame and the whispers of dishonor after leaving the feast, Caireall reluctantly seeks out Goll in the forest, determined to prove his worth through combat, as they engage in a wrestling match, testing each other's strength.

Caireall, having focused on defense, sees an opening when Goll overcommits in his attack, but hesitation grips him, allowing Goll's retaliatory strike to escalate the duel to its inevitable deadly conclusion.

Driven by Caireall's decision to go on the offensive, Goll is reminded of the dire stakes behind every clash within the Fianna, quickening his actions to match Caireall’s aggression, as both warriors draw weapons and the duel's outcome becomes imminent.
Goll, insulted by Caireall's attempt at negotiation, perceives it as a sign of weakness and redoubles his resolve, leading them both to draw weapons, and the duel's outcome becomes imminent.

Goll defeats Caireall in combat, prompting a somber mourning from Fionn for the loss of his son, which leads to a deep reflection on the price of honor and the inevitable changing of power within the Fianna.

Caireall successfully disarms Goll, leading to an unexpected reconciliation; Fionn, impressed by his son's mercy and wisdom, reconsiders the values of leadership and honor within the Fianna, fostering a newfound respect between the warriors.

name: The Death of Diarmaid
story:
The Death of Diarmaid
Bàs Dhiarmad (The Death of Diarmaid)
Also known as
Laoidh Dhiarmad (The Lay of Diarmaid)
Further Information
Book of the Dean of Lismore no. 11.
Some versions begin with a verse or two about Glen Shee, saying that Fionn and the Fianna often came there to hunt. This is followed by a verse saying that the lay tells a sad tale about the Fionn and Diarmaid (some versions start with this verse instead).
 Fionn requested that that Diarmaid come to Ben Gulabin (though it is sometimes localised elsewhere) to kill the terrible poisonous boar that lived there and that no weapon could harm. Diarmaid agreed to do this. The Fianna set forth and found the boar. There is a description of the boar, saying that its bristles were sharper than spears – and in some versions sharper even than the Gae Bolga, the fearsome weapon of Cù Chulainn. Diarmaid broke his spear on the boar’s hide, but eventually managed to kill it with his sword. Fionn was displeased by this, as he had hoped and expected that the boar would kill Diarmaid. He asked Diarmaid to measure the length of the boar, from snout to tail and then back again. On the second measurement, the sole of one of Diarmaid’s feet was pierced by one of the boar’s bristles. In some versions he died straight away and the lay concludes with some verses praising his beauty and nobility.
 That is the basic story, but there are versions with more information. For instance, some explain that Diarmaid had eloped with Gràinne, and that this was the reason Fionn wanted him killed, and some versions have a conversation near the start of the lay in which Gràinne warned Diarmaid not to trust Fionn. In some versions, as Diarmaid lay dying he requested that Fionn give him a drink of water as this would heal his wound. Fionn refused and Diarmaid died.
 There are versions of this lay from places in Argyllshire (including Mull, Tiree and Glenorchy), Lochalsh, Lewis, North Uist, Benbecula, South Uist, Barra and Skye.
 Note: Tóraíocht Dhiarmada agus Ghráinne (The Pursuit of Diarmaid and Gráinne), An Cluiche Fichille faoin gCrann Iúir (The Chess Game beneath the Yew Tree), and Diarmaid, Gráinne, agus Ciuthach (Diarmaid, Gráinne, and Ciuthach) also concern the elopement of Diarmaid and Gráinne and the death of Diarmaid.

scenes.setting: The lush, green valley of Glen Shee.
scenes.action: Fionn mac Cumhaill introduces the task of hunting the fearsome boar to Diarmaid and the Fianna.
choices: Diarmaid agrees to the hunt without hesitation.
Diarmaid listens to Gráinne's concerns about Fionn and hesitates.
Diarmaid challenges Fionn, asking why he was chosen for the task.
scenes.trigger: Agreeing leads directly to the hunt. Hesitating prompts a scene with Gráinne providing more insight into the betrayal. Challenging Fionn may generate more conflict between Diarmaid and Fionn, giving insight into Fionn's motivations.

scenes.setting: The rugged terrain of Ben Gulabin.
scenes.action: After a fierce battle, Diarmaid successfully slays the boar with his sword.
choices: Diarmaid follows Fionn's request to measure the boar.
Diarmaid refuses Fionn's request, suspicious of his intentions.
scenes.trigger: Measuring the boar results in Diarmaid being injured by a bristle, leading to the final scene. Refusing might further antagonize Fionn but could offer Diarmaid a moment of reflection before his demise.

scenes.setting: The quiet, somber aftermath on the slopes of Ben Gulabin.
scenes.action: Diarmaid lies dying from his wound and requests water from Fionn, hoping for healing.
choices: Fionn refuses out of spite, fulfilling his wish for Diarmaid's demise.
Fionn, moved by Diarmaid's plight, reluctantly offers water, though ultimately too late.
scenes.trigger: Fionn's refusal leads to Diarmaid's death, with a bitter end highlighting the cost of pride and vengeance. Offering water, even if too late, could reflect Fionn's inner conflict and add complexity to his character, concluding the story with a poignant sense of regret and missed redemption.

choicelist: Diarmaid, trusting Fionn's intentions, charges into the battle with the boar and slays it with his sword, only to receive a cold, calculating look from Fionn, hinting at deeper treachery.

Gráinne's warning haunts Diarmaid as he faces the boar, his hesitation allowing it to nearly overpower him, but with a desperate surge of strength and the weight of doubt casting a shadow, he finally slays the beast with his sword.

Fionn's eyes narrow with barely concealed malice as Diarmaid's challenge sparks a tense silence, the air thick with unsaid accusations; the Fianna watch uneasily as Fionn coldly orders Diarmaid to measure the boar, leading to the deadly task of measuring its length.

As Diarmaid reluctantly complies with Fionn's request to measure the boar, a piercing pain seizes him, causing him to collapse on the rugged terrain of Ben Gulabin, where, grappling with betrayal and impending death, he desperately pleads for water from a conflicted Fionn.

Angered by Diarmaid's defiance and refusal to trust him, Fionn's spiteful demeanor intensifies as Diarmaid, despite his growing weakness, desperately pleads for water, knowing too well that his life hinges on Fionn's capricious mercy.

Diarmaid succumbs to his wound, leaving Fionn to face the haunting consequences of his vindictive choice, as the Fianna mourn the loss of a noble warrior and the tragic downfall wrought by pride and vengeance.

Fionn, with a heavy heart and a rare moment of vulnerability, offers the water too late, watching as Diarmaid fades away, leaving behind a stark reminder of the destructive power of pride and the possibility of redemption lost.

name: The Death of Goll
story:
The Death of Goll
Bás Ghoill (The Death of Goll)
Also known as
Tiomna Ghuill mhic Mórna (The Testament of Goll mac Mórna)
Further Information
Duanaire Finn no. 10.
This tale exists in prose and poetry forms. Conflict arose between Fionn and Goll, and as a result Goll and his wife were in a cave on a promontory, dying of hunger. A conversation ensued between Goll and his wife, in which he urged her to escape and find a new husband from among the Fianna. They remembered their years together and Goll’s victories and considered their plight.
 According to some versions Goll was put to death on the promontory by the rest of the Fianna because of his actions in the story Dóiteán Tighe Fhinn (The Burning of Fionn’s House). Alternatively, a Donegal version has Goll and a pig belonging to Smolach mac Smóil (one of Clann Boiscne) kill each other, while in a version collected in Galway, Goll was in the company of Cormac Mac Airt when he killed Conán Maol in battle, and others of the Fianna then killed Goll. In another version from Galway, Goll and Conán were looking for Fionn together when Cormac and his men arrived, and although Goll sided with Conán in the fight against Cormac, he was saddened when Cormac was killed, remembering the friendship they had had.

scenes.setting: A cavernous cave on a windswept promontory overlooking the sea
scenes.action: Goll and his wife are discussing their dire situation, reflecting on past victories and considering their current plight.
choices: Encourage Goll to reconcile with Fionn and seek peace.
Agree to seek out a new life with a different member of the Fianna.
Decide to stay with Goll and face whatever comes together.
scenes.trigger: The choice leads them either towards a risky attempt at reconciliation, setting out to find new allies, or bracing for potential conflict within their isolation.

scenes.setting: The lands of the Fianna, amidst ancient woods and mysterious landscapes.
scenes.action: Goll, driven by different motivations based on the previous choice, either seeks allies or confronts old adversaries.
choices: Seek out Cormac Mac Airt for support in an attempt to broker peace.
Confront Conán to discuss past grievances and alliances.
Navigate cautiously to avoid conflict while searching for shelter.
scenes.trigger: Choices guide Goll towards potential alliances that could change loyalties, involvement in a direct conflict, or seclusion.

scenes.setting: A battlefield set under gray skies, where tensions reach their peak.
scenes.action: Goll faces the consequences of his choices, determining his fate amidst rivalries and old friendships.
choices: Fight alongside newfound allies to protect against those who seek his death.
Attempt to mediate a truce, hoping to reconcile his past feuds.
Stand alone to confront destiny, accepting whatever outcome awaits.
scenes.trigger: The choices resolve Goll's journey: through a potential new alliance, a tragic fall due to unresolved conflicts, or an honorable stand in solitude.

choicelist: Driven by an earnest belief in reconciliation but burdened by past betrayals, Goll approaches the Fianna with an uneasy mixture of hope and trepidation, only to find simmering distrust and deep-seated enmity among them, forcing him to either seek out Cormac Mac Airt for support in an attempt to broker peace, confront Conán to discuss past grievances and alliances, or navigate cautiously to avoid conflict while searching for shelter.

Haunted by the promise to seek a new life, Goll battles with the betrayal of his own heart as he faces the lands of the Fianna, amidst ancient woods and mysterious landscapes, driven by different motivations based on the previous choice, either seeking allies or confronting old adversaries.

Determined to stand by Goll and face their fate together, his wife steels herself for the inevitable risks, knowing their choices may lead to a deadly confrontation, as Goll ventures into the lands of the Fianna, driven by different motivations based on the previous choice, either to seek allies or confront old adversaries.

Upon seeking out Cormac Mac Airt, Goll must now confront the fierce suspicions and anger from Cormac’s men, who view his bid for peace as a betrayal, leading him to face the consequences of his choices, determining his fate amidst rivalries and old friendships.

Goll confronts Conán, tensions flaring as harsh words are exchanged over old betrayals and alliances, and as the shadows of the past close in, he faces the consequences of his choices, determining his fate amidst rivalries and old friendships.

Goll's cautious navigation is seen as cowardice by some and prudence by others, fueling both suspicion and resentment among the Fianna, and amidst whispers of betrayal and loyalty, Goll now faces the consequences of his choices, determining his fate amidst rivalries and old friendships.
Goll, choosing to stand alongside his newfound allies, defends against the onslaught, but ultimately falls in battle, his legacy cemented by the courage he showed in his final stand.

Goll's attempt to mediate a truce bore fruit for a moment, as old adversaries softened and past grievances were set aside, but the fragile peace shattered when a stray spear claimed his life, leaving behind a legacy of honor and tragedy.

Goll, standing alone on the battlefield beneath the gray skies, bravely accepts his fate as the Fianna close in, choosing to meet his destiny with honor despite the betrayals and conflicts that led him there.

name: The Rustic in the Drab Coat
story:
The Rustic in the Drab Coat
Bodach an Chóta Lachtna (The Rustic in the Drab Coat)
Also known as
Fear a Chòta Liathghlais (The Man in the Grey Coat)
A foreign warrior named Caol an Iarainn (the Slender one of Iron, simplified to Cael in some tellings) arrives in Howth. Desirous to rule Ireland, he challenges the Fianna to find someone who can vanquish him. He tells them that if any one of the Fianna can beat him in either running, wrestling, or fighting, he will return home to his own country. Fionn mac Cumhaill tells the warrior that Caoilte mac Rónáin is the fastest of the Fianna, but he is not there at present. Fionn suggests that the warrior stay and make acquaintance with the Fianna while he goes in search of Caoilte. The warrior agrees.
 On his way to Tara, where he thinks Caoilte may be, Fionn meets a poorly attired giant, known as Bodach an Chota Lachnta (the Tramp with the Grey Coat). Upon hearing the story of Caol an Iarainn, the Bodach tells Fionn that he will challenge him on behalf of the Fianna. Caol an Iarainn agrees to the challenge against the Bodach.
 In some versions the challenger is more generic, and he may even be a member of the Fianna. For instance, in an Islay version, the Bodach has worked for Fionn for a while, carrying heavy burdens others could not, and Conán challenges him to the race because he is jealous of the favour the Bodach is getting from Fionn.
 The night before the race, the Bodach builds a hut to sleep in. Caol an Iarainn refuses to assist, and he also refuses to go hunting or share a meal with the Bodach. The following morning, the day of the race, the Bodach gives Caol an Iarainn a head-start while he rests and eats. When he eventually sets off, he easily overtakes Caol an Iarainn. The Bodach then stops to eat some berries. Caol an Iarainn catches up and passes the Bodach, who easily overtakes him again when he is done picking berries.
 While the literary version depicts Fionn nervously waiting to see which of the men will win, the Fianna are absent from the conclusion of the story in most oral versions. The Bodach wins the race and being near exhaustion, prepares himself oatmeal. He is eating when an angry Caol an Iarainn finishes the race and approaches. The Bodach throws his oatmeal at him with such force that Caol an Iarainn is beheaded, or else strikes him so that his head is the wrong way around. In the case of the former, the Bodach reattaches his head, but in his haste, places it back to front. In one telling from County Clare, Conan races the Bodach instead of Caol an Iarainn, and tricks his way to victory. The decapitation plot is similarly recalled, but in reverse. Conan knocks the Bodach’s head off by throwing his oatmeal and proceeds to reattach it the wrong way. In this telling, the incident happens before the race’s conclusion and the Bodach begins running backwards, allowing the slower Conan to win.

scenes.setting: Howth, where Caol an Iarainn challenges the Fianna.
scenes.action: Caol an Iarainn arrives in Howth and issues a challenge to the Fianna, demanding a worthy opponent for running, wrestling, or fighting.
choices: Accept Caol an Iarainn's challenge and seek Caoilte, the fastest of the Fianna.
Consult the Bodach an Chóta Lachtna about taking on the challenge.
Politely refuse Caol an Iarainn's challenge and risk his wrath.
scenes.trigger: If Caoilte is sought, move to scene 2A where Fionn searches for him. If the Bodach is consulted, move to scene 2B to prepare for his involvement. Refusing leads to a failure scenario, potentially restarting the decision.

scenes.setting: Road to Tara and meeting the Bodach an Chóta Lachtna.
scenes.action: Fionn encounters the Bodach an Chóta Lachtna, who offers to challenge Caol an Iarainn on behalf of the Fianna.
choices: Agree to let the Bodach challenge Caol an Iarainn.
Wait for Caoilte, risking Caol an Iarainn's impatience.
Challenge Caol an Iarainn yourself, testing your own mettle.
scenes.trigger: Letting the Bodach take the challenge leads to scene 3A for the race. Waiting for Caoilte might bring him in time, leading to scene 3B. Challenging Caol an Iarainn yourself could lead to an alternate outcome depending on execution.

scenes.setting: Open fields prepared for the race.
scenes.action: The Bodach and Caol an Iarainn compete in the race, using tactics and stamina to win.
choices: Instruct the Bodach to be strategic and conserve energy.
Encourage the Bodach to run with all his might from the start.
Allow the Bodach to decide how he wants to race.
scenes.trigger: Strategic racing leads to victory and an oatmeal incident that decides Caol's fate. Running with might might tire the Bodach but can still lead to an intense conclusion. Leaving the decision to the Bodach results in varied endings based on his instincts.

choicelist: Fionn, having opted to seek Caoilte the swift and knowing time is against him, is startled by the sudden and foreboding appearance of the Bodach an Chóta Lachtna, whose piercing eyes seem to see through him, and after hearing of Caol an Iarainn's challenge, the Bodach's booming voice resonates with a steadfast resolve to confront the foreign warrior in Caoilte's stead, inciting a tense moment where Fionn must consider the unexpected risks and consequences of alienating such a formidable and mysterious ally.

Fionn, torn by the absence of Caoilte and urgency of Caol an Iarainn's challenge, reluctantly consults the Bodach an Chóta Lachtna, aware of the risk in trusting an unpredictable ally, yet drawn to the enigmatic giant’s tenacity as the Bodach eagerly offers to defend the Fianna’s honor by confronting Caol an Iarainn.

Having refused Caol an Iarainn's challenge and sensing the warrior's rising fury and threat of retaliation against the Fianna, Fionn hastens along the road to Tara, his heart heavy with the fear of impending conflict, where he encounters the Bodach an Chóta Lachtna, who offers to challenge Caol an Iarainn on behalf of the Fianna.

Fionn, having entrusted the race to the unassuming Bodach despite knowing the risks and potential wrath of Caol an Iarainn, watches the tension between the two opponents build, each sizing the other up under the scrutinizing gaze of the Fianna, before the race begins and they employ their tactics and stamina to win.

As the crowd gathers anxiously in the open fields, murmurs of concern ripple through the ranks of the Fianna, who now rest their dwindling hopes on the arriving Caoilte, whose tardiness fosters not just frustration but deep-seated rivalry with the Bodach, now forced to race Caol an Iarainn alone, both men driven by desperation as they compete, using tactics and stamina to win.

Fionn, having brashly challenged Caol an Iarainn himself and realizing the daunting strength of his opponent, must now rely on the unexpected intervention of the Bodach, who steps forward with a hardened resolve to save Fionn from certain defeat, leading to a tense race between the Bodach and Caol an Iarainn, where they compete using tactics and stamina to win.

The Bodach cleverly paces himself, utilizing strategic bursts of speed to win the race, and in a heated conclusion, he hurls his oatmeal at an exhausted Caol an Iarainn, accidentally decapitating him but ultimately securing victory for the Fianna.

Encouraging the Bodach to run with all his might from the start depletes his energy, but his sheer determination and unexpected cunning allow him to narrowly defeat Caol an Iarainn, leading to a final confrontation where, in a fit of exhaustion-fueled rage, he hurls his oatmeal with such force that it decapitates his opponent, securing victory for the Fianna.

The Bodach, relying on his instincts, allows Caol an Iarainn a head-start, only to effortlessly overtake him with strategic pauses, ultimately winning the race and dispatching Caol an Iarainn with a forceful throw of his oatmeal, beheading him and causing a comical reversal of his head on reattachment.

name: Fionn’s Banner
story:
Fionn’s Banner
Bratach Fhinn (Fionn’s Banner)
This exists as an independent lay, but more commonly appears inserted into other lays in which the Fianna prepare for a battle (see Comhrag Fhinn agus Mhanuis and Laoi an Airghinn Mhóir, as well as Book of the Dean of Lismore no. 14: Naonbhar Do-Chuadhmar fá Choill, which has not been orally collected).  

Fearghas, Fionn’s ambassador, met the king of Scandinavia (Lochlann) and when the king rejected Fionn’s terms and the Fianna received the signal from Fearghas, they unfurled their banners and advanced. The king of Scandinavia (Lochlann) asked which hero bore this or that banner, and Fearghas identified them.

The general list of the heroes and their banners is as follows (NB there are minor variations in the names in some versions):

Diarmaid: Liath-luaineach (liath is “grey”. The second element is obscure, possibly “restless one”)
Caoilte: Dubh-nimhe (“the black venomous one”)
Raoine: An Aona-Chasach Ruadh (“The red-haired one-footed one”)
Goll: A’ Bhriochail-Bhrocail (“The ragged, tattered one” [?])
Oscar: Sguab-ghabhaidh (“The terrible sheaf”)
Fionn: An Dealbh Ghrèine, an Deò-Ghrèine, an Gath-Ghrèine, or Gile-Grèine (“Image of the Sun, the Ray of the Sun, the Ray of the Sun, the Whiteness of the Sun”)
 Additionally, one version (Reliquiae Celticae, vol. I, p. 240) says that Fergus had a banner called “Fulang Dorrain” and that Oisean also had a banner, but he does not name it. “Fulang Dorrain” is also given as the name of Fergus’s banner in Dwelly’s dictionary in the context of an idiom: “The banner of Fergus, i.e. the banner of one who could sustain a defeat and play a losing game when necessary, contrary to the English idea that the Gael can only make one rush and are soon disheartened.”

scenes.setting: An open field near the edge of the Fianna's camp, where Fearghas meets with the king of Scandinavia.
scenes.action: Fearghas negotiates with the king of Scandinavia, delivering the terms from Fionn, while the Fianna prepare and watch from a distance.
choices: Fearghas accepts the king's counter-offer and attempts to avoid conflict.
Fearghas stands firm on Fionn's terms, signaling readiness for battle.
Fearghas pretends to accept the terms but cleverly plans for the Fianna to ambush.
scenes.trigger: Choosing to accept the counter-offer might delay conflict but raise internal tensions, choosing readiness for battle leads directly to unfurling the banners, and planning an ambush takes the Fianna by surprise with unexpected tactical advantage.

scenes.setting: The Fianna's encampment as they prepare to unveil their banners.
scenes.action: Upon receiving Fearghas's signal or plan, the Fianna unfurl their distinctive banners and ready themselves emotionally and strategically.
choices: Follow Fionn's traditional strategy and charge head-on.
Adapt and form a defensive stance, allowing the terrain to work in their favor.
scenes.trigger: A charge ignites immediate and chaotic combat, while a defensive stance might draw the enemy in, offering a tactical edge.

scenes.setting: The battlefield, where the Fianna confront the Scandinavians under the sight of their banners.
scenes.action: A battle ensues, with each banner guiding its respective hero and his contingent, embodying their legendary reputations.
choices: Consolidate the forces under Fionn's banner for a decisive blow.
Split and use each banner's unique symbolism to fragment the enemy.
scenes.trigger: Consolidation may lead to overwhelming the opposing forces with unity, while fragmentation could confuse and divide the enemy, leveraging the unique strengths of each banner bearer.

choicelist: Fearghas's acceptance of the king's counter-offer incites subdued anger and mistrust within the ranks of the Fianna, as murmurs of dissent ripple through them, yet with the tension palpable, they unfurl their distinctive banners and ready themselves emotionally and strategically.

Upon receiving Fearghas’s unwavering signal, a ripple of tension spreads through the Fianna, with some questioning the wisdom of such defiance yet others bolstered by the honor of standing firm, leading to the unfurling of their distinctive banners and a readiness, both emotional and strategic, for the battle ahead.

As Fearghas cunningly feigns acceptance of the king's terms, tension rises among the Fianna who feel conflicted by betrayal yet invigorated by the call to ambush; with emotions heightened and resolve steely, they unfurl their distinctive banners and ready themselves emotionally and strategically.

Caught in the swirling chaos of their headlong charge, the Fianna find themselves hard-pressed as the Scandinavians regroup, exploiting gaps opened by their relentless assault; yet amidst the tumult, each banner guides its respective hero and his contingent, embodying their legendary reputations.

With the Fianna opting for a defensive stance, Fionn's warriors brace themselves as the enemy advances, tempers flare among the heroes; Diarmaid, initially resistant to a defensive strategy, fiercely challenges the decision, drawing his sword to rally his men, while Fearghas reminds them of the plan's wisdom, ultimately leading to a tense standoff as the Scandinavian forces engage, each banner directing its hero towards their fates in the ensuing battle.
The Fianna, united under Fionn's radiant banner, charged as one and overwhelmed the Scandinavian forces with their combined might, securing a resounding victory on the battlefield.
The Fianna, utilizing the unique strengths embodied by each hero's banner, successfully fragmented and overwhelmed the Scandinavian forces, leading to a swift and decisive victory on the battlefield.

name: The Little Hall at Allen
story:
The Little Hall at Allen
Bruíon Bheag na hAlmhaine (The Little Hall at Allen)
The story begins when a group of the Fianna are invited to a great feast being held in Connacht. In one version, the host is a local giant, while elsewhere it is a rival faction of warriors. A request is made before the event that all attendees arrive without their weapons. Goll mac Morna is suspicious of this, and brings a concealed knife. During the course of the lavish meal, the host arises and strikes Goll. This marks a common deviation from literary versions, which centre around a conflict between Goll and Fionn at a banquet. A general fight ensues in which he makes good use of the knife. In the version featuring the giant, he uses it to behead the host. In others, he uses it to great effect as the Fianna defeat their hosts.
 This story is quite similar to Soraidh Fhinn go Tír Lochlainn (Fionn’s Wooing in Scandinavia).

scenes.setting: The Fianna gathering place, shortly before departing for Connacht.
scenes.action: Fionn announces the invitation to a great feast in Connacht, emphasizing the no-weapons rule.
choices: Goll agrees to go unarmed, trusting Fionn's leadership.
Goll decides to conceal a small knife, feeling uneasy about the arrangement.
Goll argues against attending the feast, suggesting it might be a trap.
scenes.trigger: Agreeing to go unarmed leads to the feast without preparation, concealing a knife provides a secret advantage later, and arguing against going could lead to a conflict of loyalty within the Fianna.

scenes.setting: The lavishly decorated hall in Connacht where the feast is held.
scenes.action: The host rises with a hostile intent towards Goll.
choices: Goll uses his concealed knife to defend himself immediately.
Goll attempts to defuse the situation with words, appealing to the host's sense of honor.
scenes.trigger: Using the knife leads to an immediate fight and potential resolution through combat. Trying to defuse the situation may delay conflict or lead to an unexpected stab, triggering a different kind of brawl.

scenes.setting: The banquet hall, now amidst a chaotic battle.
scenes.action: The Fianna either struggle to fight unarmed or rally behind Goll's leadership.
choices: Encourage the Fianna to focus on disabling the host's warriors, aiming for escape.
Push to defeat the host, aiming to seize control of the hall.
scenes.trigger: Choosing to escape leads to a tense retreat, leaving future conflicts unresolved. Defeating the host establishes dominance, possibly securing a new alliance or rivalry in the resulting power vacuum.

choicelist: With a growing unease among the Fianna as they realize their vulnerability without arms, the host rises with a hostile intent towards Goll.

With a steely resolve and a swift motion, Goll, aware of the tension in the air and the weight of his suspicion from earlier, discreetly grips his concealed knife as the host rises with hostile intent towards him.

Goll's earlier challenge to Fionn's decision has heightened tensions within the Fianna, causing whispers of doubt among the warriors; as the host rises with hostile intent, the air thickens with the possibility of betrayal, and Goll must decide his next move.

Goll's quick defense with the knife has ignited chaos among the banquet-goers, with warriors rising in outrage at the breach of trust, forcing the Fianna to rally behind Goll's leadership amidst accusations of betrayal.

Though Goll's words momentarily make the host hesitate, his attempt at diplomacy is seen as a sign of weakness by many of the host's faction, prompting a sudden assault on the now-vulnerable Fianna as they scramble either to regroup for escape or to rally behind Goll's leadership amidst the chaos.

The Fianna, under Goll's astute guidance, strategically dismantle the host's defenses, allowing them to escape the perilous banquet hall, but the unresolved tensions linger, foreshadowing future confrontations.

With Goll's leadership and cunning, the Fianna overpower their treacherous hosts, seizing control of the hall, which earns them both new allies and the brewing threat of further rivalries in Connacht.

name: The Enchanted Hall of the Rowan Tree
story:
The Enchanted Hall of the Rowan Tree
Bruíon Chaorthainn (The Enchanted Hall of the Rowan Tree)
The King of Lochlann attempts to conquer Ireland, and Fionn mac Cumhaill and the Fianna kill him and two of his sons in battle. One of his sons, often called Míogach, is spared, and he shows his gratitude by serving Fionn for a period of time (elsewhere he appears as Fionn’s foster-son, or as a young hero who volunteers to serve Fionn). Conán mac Morna warns Fionn that Míogach is dangerous, but Fionn does not listen. In some versions, at the end of Míogach’s service he is given some land.
 Years later, Fionn and the Fianna encounter Míogach, whom Fionn may not recognise at first, while hunting nearby. In some versions, Míogach recites some riddling poetry. It is often Conán who recognises him first. Míogach then invites the Fianna to a feast. Fionn instructs one or more members of the Fianna (often including Diarmaid) to stay behind, while he and the others go with Míogach. In a version from Barra, Míogach is now king of Lochlann and has invited the Fianna to feast with him after hearing that the hunting had failed in Ireland.
 The Fianna enter the dwelling and soon become alarmed when no food is provided at the supposed banquet. They then notice the dwelling changing shape. When they realise they cannot move, Fionn uses his thumb of wisdom to find out what is happening to them, often at the instigation of one of his men. Fionn realises that Míogach has an army of foreigners, kings, and warriors in his other dwelling, and that they need three kings’ blood (or that of their sons) to release them from the seats to which they are magically affixed.
 In some versions of the story, Fionn and the group of trapped Fianna sound the dórd Fiann (chant of the Fianna, otherwise a horn which Fionn blows, or a hammer he strikes), which alerts the Fianna who stayed behind. In other versions, Diarmaid (or another) goes in search of Fionn and happens to hear the dórd while out searching. There is then a battle, which the free Fianna win. They obtain the blood of the kings and use it to release Fionn and the trapped Fianna. The magical blood runs out before Conán can be released, however, and he must be pulled up by force, leaving the skin of his backside behind; this is why he is called Conán Maol (Bald Conán). In some versions, he gets a sheepskin graft and thereafter produces wool for the Fianna’s socks.

scenes.setting: The hunting grounds near the edge of a dense forest in Ireland
scenes.action: Fionn and the Fianna encounter Míogach while hunting, and he invites them to a feast.
choices: Fionn decides to accept Míogach's invitation without hesitation.
Conán advises caution and suggests they should lay a plan before accepting.
Fionn decides to send Diarmaid ahead to scout out Míogach’s dwelling.
scenes.trigger: Accepting without hesitation leads directly to scene 2. Heeding Conán's advice or sending Diarmaid first gives an opportunity for additional preparation or insight in scene 2.

scenes.setting: Inside Míogach’s magnificent yet eerie hall, adorned with shifting illusions
scenes.action: The Fianna are seated at an empty banquet table and slowly realize they are trapped.
choices: Fionn decides to immediately use his thumb of wisdom to uncover the truth about their predicament.
The Fianna attempt to break free by force, testing the strength of their magical bonds.
Conán, suspicious of Míogach, initiates a chant of the dórd Fiann to alert the others.
scenes.trigger: Using wisdom reveals the magical nature of their bonds, requiring specific actions to free themselves in scene 3. Attempting brute force changes focus to a struggle for physical freedom, while the chant offers a chance for external assistance.

scenes.setting: Míogach’s hall and the surrounding forest where the Fianna rally
scenes.action: A battle ensues between the Fianna and Míogach’s warriors, with the fate of the trapped leaders hanging in the balance.
choices: The Fianna harness enchanted blood to break the spell, prioritizing Fionn and others.
They decide to confront Míogach directly to force a negotiation for their release.
scenes.trigger: Using the enchanted blood concludes with the Fianna freeing their leaders, but Conán suffers a mishap. Confronting Míogach could lead to varied negotiations or a final trick, affecting the tale’s resolution.

choicelist: Upon realizing the emptiness of the feast and the sudden immobility gripping them, the Fianna feel a wave of betrayal washing over them, fueling heated whispers of anger and mistrust towards Fionn's hasty acceptance of Míogach's invitation, until they slowly realize they are trapped.

Conán, ever suspicious, voices his concerns about Míogach's motives, leading to a heated debate among the Fianna about the wisdom of their presence, but as tempers flare, they find themselves seated at an empty banquet table, slowly realizing they are trapped.

As Diarmaid returns with an unsettling report about ominous forces gathering at Míogach’s dwelling, tension flares between him and Fionn, who regrets not heeding Conán's earlier caution—yet as they attempt to leave, they find themselves magically bound to their seats at an empty banquet table, slowly realizing they are trapped.

Having used his thumb of wisdom and uncovering Míogach's treachery, Fionn, driven by betrayal and urgency, commands the Fianna to mount a desperate offensive, their battle cries echoing through the hall as they clash with Míogach’s warriors, with the fate of the trapped leaders hanging in the balance.

As the Fianna futilely struggle against their magical bonds, their frustration and desperation grow, driving them into a fierce, untamed rage that spills over into the surrounding forest where battle rages between the rallying Fianna and Míogach’s warriors, with the fate of the trapped leaders hanging in the balance.

Conán's chant reverberates through the forest, awakening a fierce war cry among the free Fianna who storm the hall in response, turning the treacherous feast into a desperate battle to reclaim their trapped leaders, with the fate of the trapped leaders hanging in the balance.

The Fianna triumphantly free their enchanted leaders using the blood, though Conán suffers a comical mishap and a sheepskin remedy, ending with peace restored and a valuable lesson on vigilance and cunning learned.

Through a cunning negotiation with Míogach, utilizing wisdom and strategic wit, Fionn and the Fianna secure their release without bloodshed, ensuring Conán's freedom as well and reinforcing the bonds of loyalty and trust within the group.

name: The Enchanted Hall at Keshcorann
story:
The Enchanted Hall at Keshcorann
Bruíon Chéis Corainn (The Enchanted Hall at Keshcorann)
Fionn mac Cumhaill is out hunting with the Fianna near the Caves of Kesh. They come upon the entrance to a cave which is inhabited by three hags. In some versions, Fionn enters while in pursuit of a badger or fox. In others, the hags compel him, and later the Fianna, to enter. Unbeknownst to Fionn and his comrades, the three have spun magical thread across the entrance of the cave entraps anyone who comes into contact with it. Eventually, all of the Fianna except Goll mac Morna become entrapped by the hags. In some tellings from Roscommon, he is summoned by the call of Fionn’s horn (cf. the dórd Fiann [chant of the Fianna]). More commonly, he is alerted of the trouble by Fionn’s dogs, who remain at the mouth of the cave barking in a frenzied manner. Goll arrives as the hags are preparing to kill their captives. A fierce fight ensues in which he kills two of the hags. The third pleads with him to spare her life, which he agrees to do, so long as she frees his comrades.

scenes.setting: The entrance of a dark cave near the Caves of Kesh.
scenes.action: Fionn mac Cumhaill and the Fianna discover the entrance to a mysterious cave, rumored to be inhabited by hags.
choices: Enter the cave in pursuit of the badger or fox.
Turn back to avoid potential danger.
Investigate the entrance cautiously, looking for any traps.
scenes.trigger: Choosing to enter leads to the entrapment by magical threads inside the cave. Turning back ends the encounter prematurely. Investigating cautiously leads to discovering the trap and finding a safer way in.

scenes.setting: Inside the dimly lit cave, where magical threads are spun.
scenes.action: Fionn and most of the Fianna become ensnared by the hags' magical threads, leaving them vulnerable.
choices: Attempt to break the magical threads and free themselves.
Call out using the dórd Fiann in hopes of summoning help.
Try to bargain with the hags for freedom.
scenes.trigger: Attempting to break free causes more trouble, as the hags tighten their hold, leading to the need for external help. Using the dórd Fiann successfully alerts Goll mac Morna. Bargaining may result in temporary leniency, stalling for Goll's arrival.

scenes.setting: Deep within the cave, where the hags prepare to kill their captives.
scenes.action: Goll mac Morna arrives to face the hags and rescue the entrapped Fianna.
choices: Engage in a fierce battle with the hags to free his comrades.
Negotiate with the third hag to spare her life in exchange for freeing the Fianna.
scenes.trigger: Engaging in battle leads to Goll defeating the hags, rescuing his companions through combat. Negotiating results in the third hag freeing the Fianna, allowing them to escape with a new potential ally or at least sparing more bloodshed.

choicelist: As Fionn heedlessly pursues the fox into the cave, the Fianna are horrified to find themselves ensnared by the invisible threads, their instincts screaming betrayal and danger, leaving them vulnerable to the hags' magic.

Reluctantly turning their backs to the ominous cave, Fionn's decision to avoid danger is met with immediate regret as the hags emerge with dark magic, ensnaring the remaining Fianna in a sudden, perilous ambush, leaving them vulnerable.

Despite their cautious approach and discovery of the trap, the Fianna's attempt to circumvent it backfires as the cunning hags use a sudden magic cast to ensnare them, leaving Fionn and most of the Fianna vulnerable.

Despite their desperate struggle, the Fianna's attempts to break free only tighten the hags’ magical grip, summoning a palpable sense of dread as Fionn’s strained cries echo through the cave, spurring Goll mac Morna into the fray to face the hags and rescue the entrapped Fianna.

The piercing sound of the dórd Fiann echoes through the cave, causing the hags to flinch and snarl in rage as Goll mac Morna bursts in, weapon drawn, prepared to face down the dark witches and rescue his comrades.

The hags, seeing the temporary leniency as a result of Fionn's bargain, betray their promise and move to strike, but Goll mac Morna arrives just in time to intervene, engaging in a fierce battle to rescue the entrapped Fianna.
Goll mac Morna engages in a fierce battle within the enchanted cave, successfully defeating the hags and liberating Fionn and the entrapped Fianna, ensuring their safe escape.

Goll mac Morna's negotiation succeeds, and the third hag, grateful for her life being spared, releases the entrapped Fianna, allowing them to escape the cave safely, forging an uneasy truce that ensures the hags’ enchantments pose no further threat to them.

name: Little Red-haired Eochaidh’s Enchanted Hall
story:
Little Red-haired Eochaidh’s Enchanted Hall
Bruíon Eochaidh Bhig Dheirg (Little Red-haired Eochaidh’s Enchanted Hall)
Also known as
Fionn ann an Taigh a Bhlàir Bhuidhe (Fionn in the House of the Blàr-Buidhe)
Members of the Fianna are out hunting when they happen upon or are enticed into a strange dwelling. In some they are approached by Eochaidh Beag Dearg (also referred to as Eochaidh Béal Dearg or more generic descriptions) who offers the Fianna hospitality. Donegal versions closely mirror the Early Modern romance in that he offers otherworldly apples to entice them.  In a version from Lochaber, the master of the house is away when they arrive, and his wife warns them not to stay.
 After these members of the Fianna go missing, some versions have Fionn use his thumb of wisdom to see that they are in danger, and he sets off to join them, bringing along his young son and Bran. In versions from Argyllshire, when Fionn goes to look for them, he tells his men that “no man born in Ireland” (meaning any man at all) may follow him; Fergus follows him, however, as he was born in Jura, not Ireland.
 More and more otherworldly guests arrive at the dwelling, some of whom challenge the Fianna. In most versions, Conán, who is on door duty, clashes with a large fairy woman – she beats him in the first bout and he then beats her, as he was never any good until he had first been cast down – and she promises that if he spares her life, she will aid the Fianna in some way.
 A fairy warrior then arrives with a black hound. (Material from Laoidh a’ Choin Duibh - The Lay of the Black Dog - is generally incorporated here.) The black hound kills Conán’s hound and all the rest of the Fianna’s hounds, and Bran is also succumbing until Conán uncovers his venomous claw. Bran kills the black hound and Conán kills its owner.
 In some versions, another fairy warrior then arrives with a boar that Eochaidh Beag Dearg has sent for their supper. It runs off, and Conán threatens to kill the warrior who brought it. The warrior then presents the roasted boar to Conán on a spit, and Conán gives the first quarter of meat to Fionn, the second to the Fianna, the third to Bran, and keeps the final quarter for himself.
 A different fairy warrior may also appear carrying a trough of water for the Fianna to wash their hands after dinner. Conán is the first to go to wash, but is warned by Fionn not to act too quickly. Conán places his small toe into the trough and it is burnt to the bone. He then throws the soldier into the trough, turning him to ashes. Conán throws the water at the fairies and those it touches turn to ashes.
 The tale ends with a battle in which Fionn summons the absent Fianna -- often with the dord Féinne, a horn which the Fianna can hear when he blows it, however far away they are – and they defeat the otherworldly forces. In the County Clare version, the fairy woman whose life Conán spared earlier is responsible for alerting the rest of the Fianna.

scenes.setting: A mysterious, otherworldly hall in the forest, encountered by the Fianna during a hunt.
scenes.action: The Fianna are either enticed or warned about the strange enchantment of the dwelling.
choices: Accept the hospitality of Eochaidh beag dearg and enter the hall.
Refuse the invitation, heeding the warning of Eochaidh's wife.
Scout around the hall for signs of danger before deciding.
scenes.trigger: Entering the hall leads to interacting with its magical inhabitants; refusing or scouting affects the level of preparedness in dealing with any ensuing conflicts.

scenes.setting: Inside the enchanted hall filled with otherworldly guests both mysterious and menacing.
scenes.action: The Fianna engage with the guests and face challenges, including the confrontation with the large fairy woman.
choices: Conán chooses to spare the fairy woman's life in exchange for her aid.
Conán decides to defeat the fairy woman without making a pact.
Seek counsel from Fionn on how to handle the challenge.
scenes.trigger: Sparing the fairy ensures potential assistance later; defeating without a pact prevents help; seeking Fionn's counsel could provide strategic insight or an alternative approach.

scenes.setting: The mystical battlefield where the final confrontation with the fairy forces takes place.
scenes.action: A battle breaks out, and Fionn uses the dord Féinne horn to summon reinforcements from the Fianna.
choices: Focus on defeating the black hound before rallying with the summoned Fianna.
Attempt to negotiate with Eochaidh beag dearg to avoid further bloodshed.
Quickly regroup with the Fianna reinforcements and launch a coordinated attack.
scenes.trigger: Defeating the hound may demoralize the enemies; negotiation could lead to a peaceful resolution; coordinating with reinforcements ensures a stronger offensive, leading to a decisive outcome.

choicelist: The Fianna, having accepted the hospitality of Eochaidh Beag Dearg, find themselves caught off guard as the enchanting allure of the hall warps into a sinister trap, their initial trust met with scornful amusement by the otherworldly guests, leading them to a tense confrontation with the large fairy woman.

Reluctantly, the Fianna find themselves on edge after refusing the hospitality of Eochaidh Beag Dearg, their suspicious glances sharpening the tension as they reluctantly engage with the guests and face challenges, including the confrontation with the large fairy woman, wary of potential traps or betrayals due to their cautious approach.

Having scouted around the hall, the Fianna are on high alert and wary of the otherworldly guests, their unease growing as Conán confronts the large fairy woman, leading to a tense standoff that echoes with the promise of trouble, as the supernatural remnants of the hall seem to close in, revealing the true stakes of the situation.

The large fairy woman, spared by Conán earlier, now stands torn between aiding him or succumbing to the pressure of her kin, casting doubt and mistrust among the Fianna, and hinting at a betrayal that erupts into a fierce battle, Fionn using the dord Féinne horn to summon reinforcements from the Fianna.

Conán's decision to defeat the fairy woman without a pact incites the wrath of her kin, who rally fiercely against the Fianna with renewed vigor and vengeance, pushing Fionn to urgently use the dord Féinne horn to summon reinforcements from the Fianna as the battle breaks out.

Fionn, slightly disappointed by Conán's hesitation to act decisively, asserts his leadership by developing a quick plan based on his own wisdom to navigate the battlefield, compelling the Fianna to regroup with strategic precision, and then uses the dord Féinne horn to summon reinforcements from the Fianna.
With the mighty black hound defeated, Fionn and his reunited Fianna launch a victorious assault on the demoralized fairy forces, ensuring their triumph and restoring peace to the land.
Eochaidh Beag Dearg, moved by the bravery and honor of the Fianna, agrees to a truce, ending the conflict peacefully and granting them safe passage from the enchanted hall.

The Fianna, reinforced by their allies and led by Fionn's strategic genius, launch a coordinated attack that overwhelms the otherworldly forces, restoring peace to the enchanted hall and securing their victory.

name: St. Patrick’s Housekeeper
story:
St. Patrick’s Housekeeper
Cailín Aimsire Phádraig (St. Patrick’s Housekeeper)
Also known as
Oisín i ndiadh na Féinne (Oisín after the Fianna), Oisean an dèidh na Fèinne (Oisean after the Fianna)
When Oisín/Oisean was very old, blinded with age and his strength nearly gone, he used to tell Saint Patrick stories about the days of the Fianna. Patrick (or in some versions Oisín/Oisean’s daughter, who was married to Patrick) wrote down his stories but threw the book into the fire thinking that Oisín/Oisean was lying about the size of the beasts the Fianna used to hunt, and only a portion of the book was saved. Patrick brought back a deer and asked Oisín/Oisean if they had any as large as it in the days of the Fianna, and Oisín/Oisean said that in the days of the Fianna even the blackbirds were bigger than that deer, which Patrick did not believe. In some versions it is Patrick’s housekeeper who does not believe the stories, and there is an enmity between her and Oisín/Oisean.

Oisín/Oisean then set out with a serving boy to go hunting. They found a herd of huge deer and killed them, either with the boy guiding Oisín/Oisean’s shot or with a hound. In some versions the hound was in such a frenzy after killing the deer that Oisín/Oisean had to kill it as well, as it was about to attack the two of them.

The boy then cooked the venison (in some versions in a cauldron of the Fianna which Oisín/Oisean directed him to find) and Oisín/Oisean ate the meat. If he had been able to eat all of the meat then he would have recovered his full strength and sight, but as the boy had secretly eaten some of it, he was not fully restored. They then went to hunt a blackbird, and when they killed it and brought back its claw, Patrick saw its great size and believed that Oisín/Oisean was telling the truth before.

scenes.setting: Oisín's modest dwelling in the woods near St. Patrick's settlement
scenes.action: St. Patrick questions Oisín's stories about the Fianna and the enormous creatures they hunted.
choices: Oisín decides to convince St. Patrick of the truth by taking him to find a large beast.
Oisín challenges the housekeeper's skepticism and decides to prove his tales to her instead.
Oisín becomes frustrated and decides to let his stories remain unbelieved.
scenes.trigger: Each choice leads to a slightly different encounter; bringing St. Patrick, the housekeeper, or no one affects the subsequent hunting scene and level of belief.

scenes.setting: Dense forest teeming with wildlife, distant from the settlement
scenes.action: Oisín, possibly accompanied by St. Patrick or his housekeeper, searches for the mythical creatures of his stories.
choices: They find a herd of enormous deer and Oisín plans to hunt them.
They encounter a lone blackbird of unusual size and target it instead.
They find nothing initially, and Oisín must rely on memory and description alone.
scenes.trigger: Choosing the deer or blackbird leads to a successful hunt, offering proof, while finding nothing depends on persuasion skills for belief.

scenes.setting: Clearing in the forest, where the hunt has reached its conclusion
scenes.action: Oisín and his crew (if any) prepare to present their evidence to St. Patrick.
choices: Oisín offers the remains of their hunt to St. Patrick as proof of his stories.
Oisín decides to keep his memories private, satisfied but without proof, focusing on personal contentment.
Oisín confronts the housekeeper directly with the evidence, challenging her disbelief.
scenes.trigger: If proof is offered, St. Patrick and possibly the housekeeper become believers, solidifying Oisín's tales for posterity; otherwise, the truth remains in question but Oisín finds peace in inherent belief.

choicelist: Oisín, determined to prove his tales to an incredulous St. Patrick who follows skeptically, ventures deep into the foreboding forest where familiar shadows of memory clash with the real dangers of the hunt, as they search for the mythical creatures of his stories.

With the housekeeper's skepticism heavy in the air, Oisín grits his teeth against the insult to his legacy and, determined to prove his truth, guides her into the dense forest teeming with wildlife, distant from the settlement.

Oisín, embittered by his decision to let his legends fade unnoticed, wanders the dense forest alone, his frustration and lingering pride compelling him to test his own waning skills against the mythical creatures of his past, driven by the haunting thought of his tales being forgotten, he searches for the mythical creatures of his stories.

The tension mounts as Oisín, sensing the weight of disbelief hanging in the air, urges his companions to swiftly prepare the gigantic deer carcasses, knowing that presenting such substantial proof to St. Patrick will spark both awe and confrontation, while his resolve hardens against the skeptical gaze of those who doubted the grandeur of the Fianna, ultimately preparing to offer the remains of their hunt to St. Patrick as proof of his stories.

Oisín, having slain an enormous blackbird, faces both skepticism and awe as he plans to present the creature's massive claw to St. Patrick, while the housekeeper, bristling with disbelief, seizes the moment to openly mock his claims, intensifying the tension between truth and legend, and forcing Oisín to muster all his remaining pride and defiance as they reach the clearing in the forest, where the hunt has reached its conclusion.

Faced with the disbelief from St. Patrick and his entourage after returning empty-handed, Oisín must passionately recount the grandeur of the Fianna's quarry with only words, driving a wedge of tension between their skepticism and his indomitable faith in the past, as he and his crew prepare to present their evidence to St. Patrick.

St. Patrick, astonished by the undeniable evidence of the enormous blackbird claw, becomes a fervent believer in Oisín's tales, thus ensuring the legendary feats of the Fianna are immortalized and revered for generations.
Choosing contentment over vindication, Oisín cherishes his vivid memories of the Fianna, finding peace in the truth of his own experiences rather than seeking external validation.

Oisín confronts the housekeeper with the evidence of the colossal blackbird's claw, forcing her to acknowledge the truth of his tales, leading to a newfound respect and understanding of the legendary days of the Fianna.

name: The Battle of the Hill of Slaughter
story:
The Battle of the Hill of Slaughter
Cath Chnoc an Áir (The Battle of the Hill of Slaughter)
Also known as
Eachtra Thailc mhic Thréun go hÉirinn (The Adventure of Tailc mac Tréun to Ireland), Laoidh Thailc Mhic Tréin (The Lay of Tailc mac Tréin)
There are prose and poetry versions of this story in manuscript sources, but only fragments of the lay occur in the orally collected versions.
 Fionn and the Fianna are approached by a beautiful young woman who tells them that she has run away from her husband, Tailc mac Tréin (also listed as the King of Cats or similar variations, owing to the fact that he has the head and tail of a cat). The young woman is usually presented as Niamh, and listed as the daughter of the King of Greece. In some tellings, she is abducted by the Fianna and brought to Ireland. In all versions, Tailc soon follows her, and a large battle ensues, which lasts for five days and five nights. In the end, Tailc is killed by Oscar atop a hill which is thereafter known as Cnoc an Áir (the Hill of Slaughter). In most versions, Niamh drops dead from shock when she witnesses the carnage that has been inflicted.

scenes.setting: An ancient forest in Ireland where the Fianna camp beneath towering trees.
scenes.action: Niamh approaches Fionn and the Fianna, seeking refuge from her husband Tailc mac Tréin.
choices: Offer Niamh sanctuary and prepare for Tailc's arrival.
Question Niamh further about her past and intentions.
Refuse to help Niamh and send her away, citing concerns for the safety of the Fianna.
scenes.trigger: Depending on the choice, the Fianna prepare for Tailc's attack, delve deeper into Niamh's story, or face Tailc's wrath after refusing her.

scenes.setting: The open fields of Ireland leading up to the Hill of Slaughter.
scenes.action: Tailc mac Tréin arrives with an army, ready to reclaim Niamh and fight the Fianna.
choices: Lead a preemptive strike against Tailc's forces.
Attempt to negotiate a truce with Tailc.
Fortify a defensive position and await Tailc's assault.
scenes.trigger: Each choice determines the initial battle stance, influencing the intensity and outcome of the conflict with Tailc and his army.

scenes.setting: The Hill of Slaughter, where the final confrontation unfolds.
scenes.action: Oscar engages Tailc in a climactic duel atop the hill.
choices: Focus on defeating Tailc with brute strength and valor.
Use cunning tactics to outsmart Tailc during the duel.
scenes.trigger: Depending on the choice, Oscar either uses sheer power or clever strategy to kill Tailc, leading to varied emotional and physical aftermaths for the surviving characters, including Niamh’s fate.

choicelist: After offering sanctuary to Niamh, Fionn and the Fianna brace themselves for the repercussions of their choice, witnessing Tailc mac Tréin's army emerge from the mists, bristling with intent, and ready to reclaim his wife, leading to a confrontation on the fields that sets the stage for the impending battle atop the Hill of Slaughter.

Having questioned Niamh, suspicions arise within the Fianna about her true motives, causing internal conflict and hesitation just as Tailc mac Tréin arrives with an army, ready to reclaim Niamh and fight the Fianna.

Niamh, betrayed and desperate, reveals herself as an ally to Tailc, leading him directly to the Fianna's camp with an unstoppable fury, as Tailc mac Tréin arrives with an army, ready to reclaim Niamh and fight the Fianna.
Oscar stands amidst the chaos unleashed by the preemptive strike, his forces weary from the relentless conflict, as he engages Tailc in a climactic duel atop the hill.
Niamh's attempt to negotiate peace ends in betrayal when Tailc, dismissing her plea, launches a surprise attack, spurring Oscar to engage Tailc in a climactic duel atop the hill.

Oscar watches as the Fianna, weary from days of defensive maneuvers, rally with determination on the Hill of Slaughter, feeling the weight of their fallen comrades and the strain of holding Tailc's relentless forces at bay, before he engages Tailc in a climactic duel atop the hill.
Oscar defeats Tailc in a fierce display of strength and valor, but the brutality of the battle leads Niamh to collapse and die from the overwhelming shock of the bloodshed around her.

By outsmarting Tailc with his cunning tactics during the duel, Oscar manages to defeat the King of Cats, resulting in a silent, eerie calm upon the Hill of Slaughter, but the shock of witnessing such a tactful demise causes Niamh to collapse, her spirit unable to bear the chaos surrounding her.

name: The Battle of Knock
story:
The Battle of Knock
Cath Cnucha (The Battle of Knock)
This tale recalls the death of Fionn’s father, Cumhall. In most versions, this comes at the hands of Goll mac Morna. Elsewhere however, he is killed by the High King of Ireland at the time, Conn Céadchathach. Fearing for Fionn in the aftermath of Cumhall’s death, his mother whisks him away to the safety of the countryside.
 In the Scottish telling, Cumhall is killed by Arca Dubh after challenging the king of Ireland, ‘Coraige Ruadh’. Before his death, he is married off to the daughter of the king of Lochlann, who subsequently gives birth to twins, one of whom is Fionn. In this telling, the story serves as a precursor to the extraordinary feats of Fionn.

scenes.setting: The battlefield at Knock, in the shadow of lush hills with stormy skies looming.
scenes.action: Cumhall stands poised for battle against Goll mac Morna, tensions high as their forces clash.
choices: Encourage Cumhall to seek a diplomatic solution with Goll mac Morna.
Advise Cumhall to fight bravely alongside his men to protect his honor.
Covertly plan a tactical retreat to ensure survival for another day.
scenes.trigger: Diplomatic choice could delay the conflict but risk treachery. Fighting may lead to Cumhall's demise, triggering the need to protect Fionn. Retreat emphasizes long-term strategy over immediate victory.

scenes.setting: In the quiet of a moonlit forest clearing where Cumhall's wife, Saoirse, is hiding.
scenes.action: Saoirse mourns Cumhall's death and contemplates the future of her son, Fionn.
choices: Decide to raise Fionn in secret, teaching him the ways of his father.
Seek alliance with Conn of 100 battles for protection.
Flee to Lochlann, invoking Fionn’s maternal heritage for safety.
scenes.trigger: Raising Fionn in secret leads to his preparation for greatness. Seeking Conn’s alliance offers political safety but invites scrutiny. Fleeing to Lochlann sets the stage for Fionn’s dual heritage exploration.

scenes.setting: The ceremonial hall of the High King, where decisions of power and future alliances are made.
scenes.action: Fionn, now grown, faces a choice about his destiny and the legacy of his father.
choices: Challenge Goll mac Morna to reclaim his family's honor.
Join forces with Conn of 100 battles, accepting a new role among the Fianna.
Return to Lochlann to unite his dual heritage and forge new alliances.
scenes.trigger: Challenging Goll leads to a climactic battle with potential for revenge or reconciliation. Joining Conn solidifies Fionn as leader of the Fianna, protecting Ireland. Returning to Lochlann shifts Fionn’s story toward international influence and legacy.

choicelist: Cumhall's attempt at diplomacy with Goll mac Morna tragically backfired, leading to treachery and his untimely death, leaving Saoirse engulfed in grief and anger as she mourns Cumhall's death and contemplates the future of her son, Fionn.

The news of Cumhall’s heroic yet tragic stand against Goll mac Morna reaches Saoirse like the wailing of banshees, igniting a fierce determination to honor his sacrifice by ensuring Fionn's survival and fulfilling his father's legacy.

Haunted by the guilt of Cumhall's strategic retreat resulting in unforeseen betrayal and his eventual demise, Saoirse feels an urgent fear gnawing at her resolve as she mourns Cumhall's death and contemplates the future of her son, Fionn.

Having trained in secret on the stories and skills of his father, Fionn enters the ceremonial hall with a defiant fire in his eyes, knowing his clandestine upbringing could lead to scorn or admiration as he faces a choice about his destiny and the legacy of his father.

In the tense atmosphere of Conn's ceremonial hall, where whispers of betrayal and ambition ripple through the gathered chieftains, Fionn stands under the scrutinous gaze of Conn Céadchathach, who, perceiving the young man's potential yet questioning his loyalty due to familial ties, challenges Fionn to declare his path in the shadow of his father's legacy, forcing him to face a choice about his destiny and the legacy of his father.

Fionn, burdened by the whispers of his mother's controversial escape to Lochlann and the pressure of his mixed heritage, stands before the High King amidst accusations of cowardice and betrayal, forcing him to confront the swirling legacy of his father's honor and choose how to navigate the tumultuous path ahead regarding the family's future honor and legacy.

Fionn confronts Goll mac Morna in a fierce duel, ultimately defeating him and reclaiming his family's honor, but choosing mercy over vengeance, he offers a truce that unites their factions and strengthens the Fianna.
By joining forces with Conn of 100 Battles, Fionn embraces his destiny as a leader of the Fianna, uniting his father's legacy with his own, and ensuring the protection and prosperity of Ireland.

Fionn returns to Lochlann, where he skillfully negotiates a powerful alliance between his maternal heritage and the Fianna, solidifying his legacy as a unifier and a leader of immense influence across lands.

name: The Battle of Ventry
story:
The Battle of Ventry
Cath Fionntrá (The Battle of Ventry)
Further Information
Book of the Dean of Lismore no. 6
Dáire Donn, the King of the World, attempts to invade Ireland with the help of European forces, including the King of France, the King of Greece and many other nobles, because the king of France’s wife and daughter have fallen in love and eloped with Fionn mac Cumhaill. A lengthy battle takes place between the invaders and the Fianna, aided by the son of the King of Ulster, who is killed in battle. Oscar fights the King of France, who flees from him. The Tuatha Dé Danann eventually step in and help the Fianna overcome the invaders, and Fionn mac Cumhaill kills Dáire Donn. Once Dáire Donn has been killed, the other invaders accept defeat and retreat.
 Most versions of this story are found in Galway and Kerry, but versions are also found in Donegal, Sligo, and Waterford. Oral versions of the story do not mention the Tuatha Dé Danann. Additionally, they do not always see Fionn and the Fianna victorious in the battle.

scenes.setting: The shores of Ventry, with the invading fleet approaching.
scenes.action: The Fianna, led by Fionn mac Cumhaill, prepare to confront the massive fleet led by Dáire Donn.
choices: Rally the Fianna to give a motivational speech to bolster their courage.
Consult with the son of the King of Ulster for a strategic plan.
Seek aid from the local inhabitants to fortify positions.
scenes.trigger: The choice affects the morale and readiness of the Fianna as the battle begins, setting the tone for initial skirmishes and the next strategic move.

scenes.setting: The battlefield at Ventry, amidst a fierce clash between the Fianna and the invaders.
scenes.action: Oscar challenges the King of France in a pivotal duel, while fierce battles rage around them.
choices: Assist Oscar in the duel, ensuring a victory that might demoralize the enemy.
Focus on strengthening the frontline against other invaders, keeping the pressure on all fronts.
scenes.trigger: Oscar's actions and whether he defeats the King of France alter the enemy's morale and influence the course of the wider battle, leading to either heightened intensity or strategic withdrawal opportunities in the final scene.

scenes.setting: The center of the battlefield where the Tuatha Dé Danann arrive.
scenes.action: The Tuatha Dé Danann intervene, choosing sides in the battle's climactic moments.
choices: Entreat the Tuatha Dé Danann to directly engage with the leading enemy's forces.
Encourage them to support the Fianna with magic that strengthens their endurance and resolve.
scenes.trigger: The intervention strategy chosen impacts whether the Fianna’s victory is decisive or hard-won, concluding with either a swift ending of the invasion or a piecemeal retreat.

choicelist: Energized by Fionn's stirring speech, the Fianna charge into battle with renewed vigor, yet amidst their focused assault, Oscar boldly challenges the King of France in a pivotal duel, while fierce battles rage around them.

As the son of the King of Ulster reveals a bold but risky strategy that leaves the Fianna divided on its execution, tension erupts among the ranks, but Oscar seizes the moment of uncertainty to challenge the King of France in a pivotal duel, while fierce battles rage around them.

The Fianna find themselves fortified by the grateful local inhabitants, but the son of the King of Ulster is dismayed by this reliance on civilians in the heat of battle, creating a schism in strategy as Oscar challenges the King of France in a pivotal duel, while fierce battles rage around them.

Having witnessed Oscar's victory over the King of France, instilling fear and doubt among the enemy ranks, the Tuatha Dé Danann, initially hesitant and divided about joining the battle, are inspired to cast aside their reservations and decisively intervene, choosing sides in the battle's climactic moments.

Despite the Fianna's strained efforts at the frontline, their ranks begin to waver under the relentless assault, prompting a desperate plea for aid as the Tuatha Dé Danann intervene, choosing sides in the battle's climactic moments.
The Tuatha Dé Danann decisively intervene, overpowering the leading enemy forces and resulting in a swift end to the invasion, with the remaining invaders surrendering or fleeing in defeat.
With the Tuatha Dé Danann's magical support bolstering their endurance and resolve, the Fianna achieve a hard-won victory, forcing the invaders into a gradual retreat after Dáire Donn's defeat.

name: The Battle of Gabhair of the Blows
story:
The Battle of Gabhair of the Blows
Cath Ghabhra nam Beumannan (The Battle of Gabhair of the Blows)
Also known as
Bàs Oscair (The Death of Oscar)
This lay, which is in Oisean’s voice, tells of the battle in which Oscar, son of Oisean, was killed. Cairbre, the king of Ireland, wanted to destroy the Fianna, so he gathered a large army to attack them. In the battle Oscar killed a great many of the king’s army, including Cairbre and his son Art, before being slain himself. Cairbre had cast a poisonous spear at him before Oscar reached him, and this eventually killed him. At the end of the lay Oisean mourns the death of his son and laments that he was unable to save or heal him.
 In the medieval literary tradition, the Fianna are effectively destroyed in this battle, and the Battle of Gabhair is conventionally seen as marking the end of the days of the Fianna. This wider context is not present in this lay, however, which focuses more specifically on Oscar’s death.
 Some versions explain that Fionn and Oisean were not present at the battle because they were on the way back from Rome, where Fionn was seeking treatment for the leg wound he received in Dóiteán Tighe Fhinn (The Burning of Fionn’s House), and Cairbre saw that he had a better chance since the Fianna were not all gathered together. Fionn and his companions did not reach the battlefield until after the fight was over.

scenes.setting: The battlefield at Gabhair, where the Fianna and Cairbre's forces are preparing for battle.
scenes.action: The Fianna, without Fionn and Oisín, are assembling to face Cairbre's army.
choices: Oscar decides to lead the charge against Cairbre despite his absence.
Oscar chooses to send a messenger to delay the battle, hoping for Fionn's arrival.
Oscar deliberates gathering more Fianna scouts to gain strategic advantage.
