scenes.trigger: Oscar's choice determines the initial conditions of the battle, leading to either a quick engagement, delayed tactics in waiting for reinforcements, or an informed assault with strategic advantage.

scenes.setting: The heart of the battlefield, amidst chaos and clashing swords.
scenes.action: Oscar engages in fierce combat, facing Cairbre and his son Art.
choices: Oscar attacks Cairbre directly to end his threat quickly.
Oscar engages Art first to weaken Cairbre's will with loss.
Oscar fights defensively to protect his men and wait for reinforcements.
scenes.trigger: The choice affects Oscar's fate and the morale of his troops: attacking Cairbre risks Oscar's life but could end the conflict swiftly; engaging Art distracts Cairbre but prolongs the fight; defensiveness gives time but cannot hold indefinitely.

scenes.setting: The aftermath of Oscar's final stand, on the bloodied field.
scenes.action: Oscar is gravely wounded by Cairbre's poisonous spear, and the focus shifts to his final moments.
choices: Oscar attempts to rally his remaining men, inspiring them to fight on.
Oscar requests a final message be sent to Fionn and Oisín about his deeds.
Oscar uses his final strength to try to slay Cairbre before succumbing.
scenes.trigger: The choice affects the lasting legacy of Oscar's actions: rallying the men can change the tide of the battle; sending a message to Fionn and Oisín ensures Oscar's story is told; attempting to slay Cairbre focuses on immediate revenge but at the cost of creating uncertainty in the battle's outcome. The story concludes with Oscar's inevitable death but leaves varying outcomes for the Fianna.

choicelist: Against a backdrop of chaotic battle cries and clashing swords, Oscar, having boldly led the initial charge in Fionn's absence, finds himself grappling with the weight of his decision as the Fianna, scattered and outnumbered, struggle to maintain their formation, forcing him into a desperate duel with Cairbre and his son, Art.

As the messenger returns unsuccessfully with news that Fionn will not come in time, Oscar, feeling the weight of his futile decision, steels himself amidst the chaos, determined to fight fiercely as he engages Cairbre and his son Art.

Having scouted the battlefield for strategic advantage, Oscar detects an opportunity to flank Cairbre’s son, Art, but as he maneuvers into position, the true might of Cairbre’s forces swiftly counters, forcing Oscar into fierce combat, facing Cairbre and his son Art.

Oscar's decision to confront Cairbre directly leaves him isolated from his men and vulnerable, and as the spear pierces his side and the weight of his choice bears down, the focus shifts to his final moments.

Oscar, seeing Art fall under his blade, witnesses Cairbre's rage intensify as the king hurls his poisonous spear with deadly precision, wounding Oscar grievously; amidst the chaos, Oscar wrestles with his final moments.

Despite Oscar's defensive efforts to protect his men, the delay allowed Cairbre to exploit his advantage, throwing a poisonous spear that grievously struck Oscar, marking his final moments on the blood-soaked battlefield.

Oscar, with his final breath, inspires the remaining Fianna warriors to rise against the overwhelming odds, turning the tide of battle briefly in their favor, but despite their temporary resurgence, the Fianna ultimately succumb to the King’s forces, marking the poignant end of their era.

Oscar's final message reaches Fionn and Oisín, immortalizing his heroic deeds and ensuring that the tale of his bravery and sacrifice is shared across Ireland, even as the Fianna face their eventual downfall.

With his last ounce of strength, Oscar hurls his spear at Cairbre, striking the king down, but as the battle rages with a leaderless enemy and uncertainty hangs over the field, Oscar succumbs to his wounds, leaving the future of the Fianna shrouded in ambiguity.

name: The Battle of the Sheaves
story:
The Battle of the Sheaves
Cath na bPunann (The Battle of the Sheaves)
Also known as
Blàr nan Sguab (The Battle of the Sheaves)
Further Information
Cf. Duanaire Finn no. 21
In the Irish versions, the Fianna are going out one morning to reap the harvest, when they are approached by the otherworldly “Cab an Dosáin” (Tufty Mouth) - he is presented elsewhere as “Ceann m’Órdóige” or the devil. He asks them if they are going to reap the harvest, which they inform him they are. He then asks if they prefer to reap or tie the hay. Not taking the question seriously, they reply that they prefer tying. He informs them that he will reap the hay, and they can bind it. He proceeds to reap the corn so fast that the Fianna end up killing one another trying to keep up the pace, until there is no one left. Dubbed “Cath na bPunann” (The Battle of the Sheaves), it is said to have been the most intense “battle” that the Fianna were ever engaged in.
 In Scottish versions, “Cath na bPunann” refers more literally to a battle in which the Fianna, while gathering the harvest, engage a group of raiding Lochlannaich (Norseman) in battle on the beach in Tiree. They did not have their weapons to hand, so they sent Caoilte, the fastest runner in the Fianna, to fetch them. In the meantime they fought the Lochlannaich with the sheaves they had reaped, and when Caoilte arrived with the weapons they slaughtered them all.
 This story was collected in counties Galway and Kerry in Ireland and Tiree and Mull in Scotland.

Ignore Cab an Dosáin and continue reaping at their own pace.
Challenge Cab an Dosáin to a reaping contest.

Attempt to collaborate more efficiently as a team to keep up.
Confront Cab an Dosáin about his impossible speed.
scenes.trigger: Calling Caoilte leads to preparation for a more direct confrontation; teamwork attempts can lead to exhaustion or unity challenges; confronting Cab an Dosáin could escalate the conflict or open negotiations.

scenes.action: The Fianna, now under siege by invading Lochlannaich, must adapt using their available resources.

Retreat strategically towards the camp for safety and strategy regrouping.
scenes.trigger: Using sheaves as weapons holds the advantage until Caoilte returns, allowing for a powerful counterattack; retreating safely gives time for planning, leading to a stealth surprise against the invaders.

choicelist: The Fianna, taken aback by the overwhelming pace of Cab an Dosáin's reaping, begin to frantically bind the sheaves, tension mounting, as they exchange frantic glances, fear and exasperation building, trapped by the decision they made to let him lead, finding themselves struggling under the pressure of Cab an Dosáin's supernatural pace.

As Cab an Dosáin's reaping intensifies, the Fianna, having disregarded his warning, now face growing frustration and turmoil, with tempers flaring and unity faltering as they strive to keep pace in a field littered with cut sheaves and burgeoning tension.

Amidst a whirlwind of panic and desperation, the Fianna, realizing the folly in challenging Cab an Dosáin, buckle under his supernatural pace, each warrior's frustration simmering towards outright revolt as they struggle to match his otherworldly speed.

With Caoilte dispatched to retrieve weapons, the Fianna, caught between rising panic and stubborn courage, grapple with their vulnerability as the invading Lochlannaich press the advantage of their distraction and disarray under siege.

Though the Fianna initially attempt to collaborate more efficiently in a desperate bid to keep up with Cab an Dosáin's supernatural reaping pace, the resulting exhaustion stirs discord and frustration among them, leaving them vulnerable just as the invading Lochlannaich storm the beach, forcing them to repurpose the sheaves into makeshift weapons for survival until Caoilte returns.

The Fianna, emboldened by their decision to confront Cab an Dosáin, challenge his otherworldly dominance only to find themselves suddenly diverted and vulnerable as his laughter echoes ominously, and the beach transforms into a battleground under siege by invading Lochlannaich, forcing them to adapt using their available resources.
With Caoilte's timely return and the Fianna's resourceful use of the sheaves as weapons, they decisively overpower the Lochlannaich, securing victory on the beach.

With their strategic retreat to the camp allowing them time to regroup and devise a cunning plan, the Fianna launch a surprise stealth attack on the Lochlannaich, utilizing their newfound strength and prepared weapons to decisively defeat the invaders and secure their harvest.

name: The Battle of Six
story:
The Battle of Six
Cath Seisir (The Battle of Six)
This lay is in the voice of Oisean, who tells his story to Patrick.
 Fionn sent six of his men out to collect tribute from foreign kings. When the king of England refused to pay them, there was a battle in which the six men of the Fianna routed the English and returned home to Ireland with five hundred English captives. The heroes who went on this expedition were Caoilte, Faolan, an t-Aodh Mac Rosaich, Oscar, Milidh and Oisean himself.

scenes.setting: The grand hall of Fionn mac Cumhaill in Ireland, where the Fianna gather.
scenes.action: Fionn mac Cumhaill assigns six warriors, including Oisín, Caoilte, Faolan, an t-Aodh Mac Rosaich, Oscar, and Oisín himself, the task of traveling to England to collect tribute.
choices: Agree to the mission and follow Fionn's orders without question.
Question the nature of the tribute and debate the moral implications.
Suggest an alternative method to deal with the English king.
scenes.trigger: Depending on the choice, the approach to the English king may vary, affecting how the mission is conducted in the next scene.

scenes.setting: The court of the English king, surrounded by his knights and advisors.
scenes.action: The Fianna present their demand for tribute to the English king, who is defiant and refuses to comply.
choices: Challenge the English king to personal combat to prove the strength of the Fianna.
Attempt a diplomatic negotiation, offering a compromise.
Threaten the king with force and prepare for battle.
scenes.trigger: Each choice leads to a different outcome: combat with the English forces, potential negotiation success, or immediate escalation to battle.

scenes.setting: The battlefield or negotiation chamber, depending on previous choices.
scenes.action: The outcome of the Fianna's mission is determined, whether through battle or treaty.
choices: If negotiation succeeds, decide whether to uphold the agreement or double-cross the king.
If a battle occurs, choose to take prisoners or show mercy to the defeated foe.
scenes.trigger: The story concludes with the Fianna's return to Ireland, with potential outcomes ranging from peaceful tribute acquisition to tales of battle and honor depending on the player's choices.

choicelist: Steeled by unwavering loyalty to Fionn, Oisín and his companions approach the English king with an uncompromising demand for tribute, igniting the king's ire and resulting in his open defiance and refusal to comply.

The Fianna, led by Oisín, question the English king's refusal and openly debate the righteousness of their mission before him, sparking heated arguments and tension among his knights and advisors, yet remain resolute in their demand for tribute, which the king defies.

Oisín boldly steps forward, proposing an alternative approach that questions the king's honor, angering the English monarch and causing him to rise from his throne with his knights murmuring in discontent, leading to the Fianna presenting their demand for tribute to the English king, who is defiant and refuses to comply.

The English king, feeling slighted by the Fianna's challenge, ignites a furious duel with Oisean, escalating tensions as each warrior's fate hangs by the thread of a sword's edge, eventually leading to a clash of armies where the outcome hinges on either the subjugation or mercy of the English forces.

The English king, wary of the Fianna's reputation yet intrigued by their offer, agrees to a tense negotiation table, where the Fianna must deftly navigate insults and potential betrayal, leading to an uneasy treaty whose terms will soon be tested; the outcome of the Fianna's mission is determined, whether through battle or treaty.

The Fianna's belligerence leads to a swift and brutal clash on the battlefield, the sound of swords and cries echoing as they fight fiercely, forcing the English into submission, ultimately deciding the fate of their captives and the honor of their pact.
Choosing to double-cross the king, the Fianna triumphantly return to Ireland with the tribute and five hundred captives, their cunning celebrated as a testament to their shrewdness and prowess.
The Fianna chose to show mercy to the defeated English foes, which earned them respect and admiration from both the captives and their own people upon their triumphant return to Ireland.

name: Claigean son of Con
story:
Claigean son of Con
Claigean mac Choin (Claigean son of Con)
A musician came to the Fianna called Claigean mac Choin a’ Chinn Chruaidh (Head son of Con of the Hard Head). His music was too loud and rough, and none of them could stand it. He started talking to Caoilte, who told him that each man of the Fianna had a wife, servant and two hounds. So he went to Fionn and played terrible harsh music, demanding not only the things named by Caoilte, but also Bran, Fionn’s hound, Fionn’s spear and Mac an Luin, Fionn’s sword. Fionn refused to give him these things, so he played three loud blasts that left the heroes temporarily deaf. They released their hounds to chase him, and eventually he was killed by Bran in a cave on a mountain (Beinn Èudain). Bran returned home with Claigean’s head in his mouth.
 A version of this lay was collected in Argyllshire.

scenes.setting: The Fianna's encampment, amidst a forest clearing
scenes.action: Claigean mac Choin arrives, playing harsh music that disturbs the Fianna.
choices: Confront Claigean directly about the music.
Ask Caoilte for advice on how to handle the situation.
Endure the music reluctantly, hoping it will end.
scenes.trigger: Confronting Claigean leads to a heated argument; seeking advice from Caoilte gives insight into Claigean's demands; enduring the music makes Claigean believe they accept his presence.

scenes.setting: Fionn's tent within the encampment
scenes.action: Claigean demands Fionn's possessions after playing another loud melody.
choices: Fionn chooses to negotiate with Claigean by offering lesser gifts.
Fionn refuses Claigean outright, defending his possessions.
Fionn decides to challenge Claigean to a skill competition instead.
scenes.trigger: Negotiation attempts delay Claigean's rage; refusing Claigean leads to immediate conflict; a challenge diverts Claigean's attention briefly.

scenes.setting: The mountainous region of Beinn Èudain
scenes.action: Claigean is pursued by the Fianna's hounds after his demands are rebuffed.
choices: Direct the hounds to chase Claigean aggressively.
Attempt to capture Claigean alive for questioning.
Focus on retrieving the enchanted items first, then deal with Claigean.
scenes.trigger: Chasing aggressively leads to Claigean's death by Bran; capturing him could reveal his motives before releasing him; focusing on items may allow Claigean an escape, altering the resolution.

choicelist: Claigean, his pride wounded and temper flaring after the confrontation, storms into Fionn's tent with a brazen audacity, demanding Fionn's possessions after playing another loud melody.
Armed with Caoilte's insights, Fionn confronts Claigean, voicing wrathful disapproval and refusing his demands, as Claigean, undeterred, plays another loud melody, demanding Fionn's possessions.

Faced with the Fianna's reluctant endurance of his abrasive tunes, Claigean, emboldened by what he perceives as their tacit acceptance, storms into Fionn's tent with audacious confidence, demanding not only the treasures spoken of by Caoilte but also Fionn's prized possessions and ultimately playing another loud melody.

The Fianna, frustrated by Fionn's failed negotiation and Claigean's relentless audacity, unleash their hounds with increasing impatience and determination, resulting in the chase through the treacherous terrain of Beinn Èudain, where Claigean is pursued as the hounds narrow the distance.

The refusal ignites Claigean's fury, and with a wailing shriek, he unleashes another deafening blast that sends shockwaves through the Fianna, driving them into a desperate frenzy to silence him, as Claigean is pursued by the Fianna's hounds after his demands are rebuffed.
Following Fionn's challenge, Claigean's defiant laughter echoes through the mountains, provoking the Fianna as he attempts to flee—now pursued by the Fianna's hounds after his demands are rebuffed.
Bran lunges forward with relentless speed, catching up to Claigean and silencing his dreadful music forever, returning triumphantly to the Fianna with Claigean's severed head held firmly in his jaws.

After capturing Claigean alive, the Fianna learned that he was under a spell compelling him to make outrageous demands, and upon discovering this, they forgave him and released him from its influence, allowing him to wander the lands freely, playing his now soothing music.

By prioritizing the retrieval of the enchanted items, the Fianna allowed Claigean to narrowly escape them, leaving only an enigmatic song echoing in the cave to hint at his unfulfilled intent and origin.

name: The Headless Body
story:
The Headless Body
Colann gan Cheann (The Headless Body)
A hideous woman comes to the Fianna one day. In some versions she is headless, in others she has an animal’s head, and in still others she is simply said to be very ugly. She asks several of the Fianna for hospitality, but all reject her apart from Oisean/Oisín (or Diarmaid in some tellings). He gives her food and agrees to let her stay the night, and that night they sleep together. In the morning he finds that she has become a very beautiful woman. She informs him that she is the daughter of a king, and makes a stunning castle appear in the surrounding landscape. Oisean/Oisín then asks her to marry him, and she obliges. A similar transformation can be seen in the medieval Irish saga Echtra Mac nEchach, as well as in international folk tales (ATU D732). In some versions there is a battle among the Fianna to see who should get to marry this beautiful woman, which ends when Fionn says that she should decide whom to marry, and she chooses Oisean/Oisín. In other versions it is Oscar or Diarmaid, rather than Oisean/Oisín, although there are no major deviations in the ensuing plot.
 She tells him that she will stay with him as long as he never reminds her of the state she was in when she arrived. However, she later angers him by giving away puppies he was rearing to various members of the Fianna, and on each occasion, he reminds her of the state she was in when they first met. After the third instance, she disappears along with the castle. In some versions his adventures trying to recover her are recounted, which incorporate Oisín i dTír na nÓg (Oisín in the Land of Youth) and Cailín Aimsire Phádraig (St. Patrick’s Housekeeper).
 This has been collected as a lay in Lewis, and as a story in Mayo, Armagh, Galway and Donegal in Ireland; Sutherland, Easter Ross and Barra in Scotland; and Cape Breton in Canada.

scenes.setting: The camp of the Fianna, amidst the rolling hills and ancient forests of Ireland.
scenes.action: A hideous woman arrives seeking hospitality from the Fianna, but faces rejection after rejection.
choices: Play as Oisín and offer her hospitality.
Play as Diarmaid and offer her hospitality.
Play as another member of the Fianna and reject her.

choices: Ask the princess to marry you immediately.
Remind the Fianna of the terms she set and allow her to choose.
Challenge the rest of the Fianna to a contest for her hand.
scenes.trigger: Allowing her choice honors her condition, whereas competing might lead to unexpected enmity; failure to marry her keeps her for the time being.

scenes.action: The princess repeatedly gives away Oisín or Diarmaid's beloved puppies, testing his patience and memory of her past condition.
choices: Express your anger by reminding her of her past condition.
Forgive her actions and discuss why it matters to you.
Seek counsel from Fionn or other Fianna on handling the situation.
scenes.trigger: Reminding her of her past three times results in her disappearance, while understanding and patience may maintain the magic of the realm and the relationship.

choicelist: The choice to offer hospitality ignites jealousy and disdain among the Fianna, leading to a tense confrontation filled with sharp words and honor-bound challenges, yet amidst the chaos, the princess, now beautiful, reveals her true identity and her magical abilities, sparking competition among the Fianna.

After witnessing Diarmaid's uncommon mercy and kindness towards the hideous woman, the Fianna's unity begins to fray, with jealousy and suspicion rising among them as the now-beautiful princess reveals her true identity and her magical abilities, sparking competition among the Fianna.

Spurned by the Fianna's rejection, the hideous woman scorns all but the one who showed her kindness, transforming the landscape as the newly revealed princess now stands amidst the Fianna, sparking competition for her hand.

Upon immediately asking for her hand in marriage, tension builds as Oisín or Diarmaid's impulsive decision strains his relationship with the Fianna, who feel slighted and uncertain about his allegiance, leading to the princess repeatedly giving away Oisín or Diarmaid's beloved puppies, testing his patience and memory of her past condition.

Upon reminding the Fianna to honor the princess's right to choose and facing her approval, tensions spark among the Fianna over the decision, leading to fractured loyalties and simmering resentment, as everyday life unfolds and the princess repeatedly gives away Oisín or Diarmaid's beloved puppies, testing his patience and memory of her past condition.

Following the spirited contest for her hand, which sowed discord among the Fianna and drew lines of loyalty and rivalry, the princess now subtly tests Oisín or Diarmaid's decision by repeatedly giving away his beloved puppies, testing his patience and memory of her past condition.

Expressing anger and reminding her of her past condition for the third time results in the stunning princess, along with her magical castle, vanishing forever, leaving Oisín or Diarmaid to grapple with the consequences of his impatience and lost love.

Through understanding and open communication, Oisín or Diarmaid maintains the enchantment of the realm and deepens his relationship with the princess, ensuring their magical life together continues in harmony.

Seeking the wisdom of Fionn and the Fianna, Oisín learns the value of forgiveness and understanding, which allows the magic to thrive, maintaining both the enchanting realm and his bond with the transformed princess.

name: Oisean’s Advice to His Mother
story:
Oisean’s Advice to His Mother
Comhairle Oisein dha Mhàthair (Oisean’s Advice to His Mother)
Further Information
Oisín kills Bran between his knees to save his deer-mother’s life
Oisín’s mother, who has been turned into a deer, begins following the Fianna everywhere as they hunt. She overhears Fionn saying that they are going to kill her, and she worriedly approaches Oisín, who knows her true identity. Fearing that she will never be able to escape Bran, who is the finest hunter of all the Fianna’s hounds, Oisín instructs her to run between his legs if the hound gives chase. She does as instructed, and when Bran follows, Oisín closes his legs, killing Bran and allowing his deer-mother to escape unscathed.
 In Scotland, the story can take the form of a waulking song. Delivered in the voice of Oisín, he tells his mother to take care if she goes near the clans of the Fianna. His warnings generally take the form: “If you go to place X, beware of clan/hero Y” and their hounds and weapons.”

scenes.action: Oisín's deer-mother, hidden within the forest, listens to the Fianna's plans and hears of the threat to her life.
choices: Confront Oisín directly about what she overheard and seek his help.
Quickly retreat deeper into the forest to avoid detection.
Listen further to gather more information about the Fianna's intentions.
scenes.trigger: Choosing to confront Oisín leads directly to him giving advice. Retreating means she stays hidden but remains at risk, possibly leading to another encounter. Listening further gives more context to Oisín's later advice.

scenes.setting: A secluded glen, where Oisín meets his deer-mother away from the others.
scenes.action: Oisín devises a plan to save his deer-mother by instructing her on how to evade Bran.
choices: Agree with Oisín's plan and decide to follow his instructions precisely.
Suggestion to approach Fionn and the Fianna directly to plead mercy.
Choose to run away alone, in hopes of escaping both the Fianna and Bran.
scenes.trigger: Agreeing to the plan moves directly to the escape attempt. Pleading with Fionn leads to a confrontation scene. Running away leads to an alternate scenario where the deer must navigate through the forest alone.

scenes.setting: A wide, open field where the Fianna have begun their hunt, surrounded by the sounds of hounds.
scenes.action: The moment of action arrives as Bran catches sight of Oisín's deer-mother and gives chase.
choices: Execute Oisín's plan perfectly, running between his legs at the last moment.
Attempt to use the environment, such as hiding or doubling back, to elude Bran.
Rely on another event, such as a distraction, to evade capture.
scenes.trigger: Executing Oisín's plan leads to Bran's demise and her escape, resolving the story successfully. Trying other tactics may result in getting caught or other members of the Fianna catching up, leading to a different ending where she is either caught or narrowly escapes.

choicelist: Upon hearing his mother's fears and realizing the imminent threat she faces, Oisín, torn between loyalty to Fionn and love for his mother, reluctantly acknowledges the risk she has taken by confronting him, and with an urgent resolve, instructs her on how to evade Bran.

Having retreated into the dense forest, Oisín's deer-mother now faces his disappointment and frustration for not confronting him sooner, understanding the urgency as he passionately instructs her on how to evade Bran, emphasizing the peril both face.

Having absorbed the full scope of the Fianna's plans and felt the chill of impending danger, Oisín’s deer-mother confronts him with desperation and newfound insight, compelling Oisín to quickly devise a plan to save her by instructing her on how to evade Bran.

With the cacophony of the hunt growing louder and tension mounting, Oisín's heart pounds as he watches his deer-mother bound with unwavering trust toward him, determined to execute his plan perfectly amid Bran's relentless pursuit.

As Oisín's deer-mother steps forward to plead for mercy before Fionn and the Fianna, the warriors' eyes harden with resolve as Fionn's voice thunders with betrayal, their whispers growing louder with disapproval, yet before a word of mercy can be uttered, the tense atmosphere shatters as Bran catches sight of the deer-mother and gives chase.

As the deer-mother flees on her own, defying Oisín's warning, a cacophony of hounds erupts and Fionn's voice echoes with anger through the field, intensifying the pursuit, yet as Bran finally catches sight of her, the moment of action arrives as Bran catches sight of Oisín's deer-mother and gives chase.

Oisín’s mother successfully follows his advice, dashing between his legs at the crucial moment, resulting in Bran’s fatal mistake and ensuring her safe escape from the relentless pursuit of the Fianna.
By utilizing the intricate landscape for concealment and misdirection, Oisín's deer-mother successfully eludes Bran, narrowly escaping the hunt and reuniting with her son for safety.

A sudden thunderclap startles the Fianna and their hounds, momentarily halting the chase and giving Oisín's deer-mother the precious seconds she needs to disappear into the thick underbrush, ensuring her escape.

name: The Combat between Fionn and Magnus
story:
The Combat between Fionn and Magnus
Comhrag Fhinn agus Mhanuis (The Combat between Fionn and Magnus)
Also known as
Laoidh Mhághnuis Mhóir (The Lay of Magnus the Great), Oisean agus an Cléireach (Oisean and the Cleric)
This is generally known as a lay, but it also exists as a story. Some versions start with a debate between Patrick and Oisean, after which Oisean tells Patrick the following story.
 The Fianna were out hunting when they saw a large fleet coming ashore. The fleet was led by Magnus, King of Scandinavia (Lochlann) (or the son of the King of Lochlann), who demanded Fionn’s wife and Bran, his hound, as tribute. Fionn refused this, and there was a fight between the two men (or between the two armies). Fionn won, but rather than killing Magnus he offered him the choice of returning home or staying a year with the Fianna, which is what he choose. There was peace between the two forces. In some versions, Magnus made a second attempt after a while, but was again defeated by the Fianna.
 Some versions include a section on the banners of the Fianna (see Bratach Fhinn / Bratach Fhinn). There are versions from Lewis, South Uist, Barra, Tiree and Caithness.

scenes.setting: A windswept shore as the Fianna watch a fleet approaching from the sea.
scenes.action: Magnus, the King of Scandinavia, lands with his fleet and demands Fionn's wife and his hound, Bran, as tribute.
choices: Reject Magnus's demands outright and prepare for combat.
Engage in negotiations to stall Magnus.
Seek advice from Oisín before responding.
scenes.trigger: Rejecting the demands leads directly to a combat, negotiating leads to a tense stalemate, and seeking advice reflects back to consulting and deciding upon a strategy.

scenes.action: A battle commences between Fionn and Magnus, with both forces poised for conflict.
choices: Fight fiercely to defeat Magnus and his forces.
Attempt to offer Magnus an honorable peace and alliance.
Use strategy to outmaneuver Magnus' forces, prioritizing minimal casualties.
scenes.trigger: Successfully defeating Magnus leads to his defeat and a subsequent choice; offering peace could usher an alliance, while outmaneuvering leaves Magnus with a hard choice.

scenes.action: Fionn must decide whether to let Magnus leave, offer him hospitality, or detain him after his defeat.
choices: Allow Magnus to return home with his forces.
Invite Magnus to join the Fianna for a year.
Detain Magnus as leverage to prevent future conflicts.
scenes.trigger: Allowing Magnus to leave concludes in peace between the groups; inviting him fosters unity and sharing of cultures; detaining leads to potential future confrontations.

choicelist: Rejecting Magnus's demands outright, Fionn's fiery refusal ignites Magnus's wrath, inspiring his warriors with an unyielding determination and leading to an intense clash on the battlefield, as a battle commences between Fionn and Magnus, with both forces poised for conflict.
Fionn, feeling the weight of his decision to negotiate, confronts Magnus on the battlefield, knowing the fragile peace could shatter at any moment, as both forces prepare for conflict.

Having sought Oisín's wisdom, Fionn stands resolute, his mind sharpened by counsel, as he confronts Magnus under the ancient trees, the tension palpable as each warrior prepares for a battle that will determine the fate of peace or discord between their people—a battle commences between Fionn and Magnus, with both forces poised for conflict.

Fionn stands amidst the wounded and weary, facing the grim reality of battle's aftermath; tempers flare as the Fianna urge retribution for their fallen, yet tradition and honor compel him to decide whether to let Magnus leave, offer him hospitality, or detain him after his defeat.

After offering Magnus an honorable peace, tensions simmer in the Fianna’s camp as some view the decision as betrayal, while others see it as wisdom, leading Fionn to decide whether to let Magnus leave, offer him hospitality, or detain him after his defeat.

Upon the Fianna's clever outmaneuvering that minimized bloodshed, tensions simmer as Magnus, humiliated yet grudgingly impressed, demands recompense for his men's tactful defeat, leaving Fionn with the critical choice of whether to let Magnus leave, offer him hospitality, or detain him after his defeat.
Magnus, having been allowed to return home with his forces by Fionn, honors the gesture of trust and respect, leading to a lasting peace and mutual respect between the Fianna and the Scandinavians.
Magnus accepted Fionn's offer, spending a year with the Fianna, fostering mutual respect and cultural exchange, which laid the foundation for lasting peace between their peoples.

Detaining Magnus as leverage to prevent future conflicts backfires as it sows seeds of resentment, leading to heightened tensions and eventual skirmishes, forcing Fionn and the Fianna to confront the consequences of their decision.

name: Conán and the Monster of Loch Dearg
story:
Conán and the Monster of Loch Dearg
Conán agus Piast Locha Dheirg (Conán and the Monster of Loch Dearg)
A horrific beast resides in a lake, causing terror to all in the surrounding area. One day the Fianna engage in a fierce fight with the monster. It initially gets the better of them, swallowing a number of them whole, including Conán. Only Fionn, Goll, Oisín and Oscar remain unscathed. They eventually prop open its gigantic mouth with one of their spears, and Oscar jumps in and wreaks havoc with his sword, disembowelling the beast and cutting it from its head to its tail. The Fianna who had been swallowed fall out of the dying beast, injured but still alive, and its blood flows forth into the lake, giving it a reddened appearance, hence the name Lough Dearg (Red Lake).
 This story was collected in Counties Clare, Donegal, Galway, Kerry, Limerick and Mayo in Ireland and Eriskay in Scotland.

scenes.setting: The shores of Loch Dearg, surrounded by lush, verdant forests.
scenes.action: The Fianna, led by Fionn mac Cumhaill, approach Loch Dearg and prepare to confront the horrific beast that has been terrorizing the area.
choices: Launch a surprise frontal assault on the monster

Oscar deftly slices the beast from head to tail, freeing the swallowed Fianna and earning their cheers, as its lifeblood spills into the lake, transforming it into the crimson-hued Loch Dearg.

Oscar, with precision and bravery, strikes directly at the monstrous heart, dealing a lethal blow that causes the beast to collapse, releasing the captive Fianna and turning the lake a deep crimson as the creature's life force spills forth.

name: Conn son of the Red One
story:
Conn son of the Red One
Conn mac an Deirg (Conn son of the Red One)
Most versions begin with someone re questing the tale of Conn from Oisín/Oisean.
 When Conn was a child, his father, Dearg mac Droichil, was killed in Ireland by Goll. A Tiree version says that Conn was from Mull, but the other versions do not say where he was from. When he grew up, Conn came to Ireland seeking revenge for his father’s death, saying he came for the heads of Goll, his sons, Fionn and all of Clan Morna as compensation for his father. A battle then started, and for several days Conn had the upper hand, killing large numbers of the Fianna. Eventually Fionn asked Goll to fight Conn, which he did, killing him.

scenes.setting: The rugged coast of Mull, where Conn begins his journey
scenes.action: Young Conn prepares to set sail for Ireland to avenge his father's death.
choices: Gather a band of warriors to accompany him to Ireland.
Set sail alone without attracting any attention.
Seek guidance from a local wise person before departing.
scenes.trigger: Gathering warriors strengthens Conn's forces, leading to a more confrontational path in Ireland. Going alone allows for a stealthier approach. Seeking wisdom provides strategic guidance, potentially altering Conn's tactics.

scenes.setting: The rolling hills of Ireland, near Fianna fortresses
scenes.action: Conn begins his campaign against Fionn and the Clan Morna.
choices: Launch a direct assault on the Fianna stronghold.
Challenge Goll to a personal duel.
Attempt to negotiate with Fionn for redress before resorting to violence.
scenes.trigger: A direct assault leads to a prolonged battle, increasing tension. A personal duel with Goll shifts focus to individual bravery. Negotiation delays conflict but offers insight into the characters’ motivations.

scenes.setting: A secluded glen outside the Fianna camp
scenes.action: Conn faces Goll in a climactic battle, regardless of previous attempts at negotiation or stealth.
choices: Fight Goll honorably, risking a fair fight but upholding his father's legacy.
Use a cunning tactic, potentially giving him an advantage but risking his honor.
Offer a truce, hoping to end the bloodshed and possibly forge a new path.
scenes.trigger: Fighting honorably leads to Conn's defeat but maintains his legacy's purity. Using cunning can change the battle's outcome but stains his honor. A truce may result in an unexpected alliance, altering the future of the Fianna.

choicelist: Conn, bolstered by a formidable band of warriors he gathered, storms through the Irish landscape, his presence igniting fear and stirring hostility among the Fianna, setting the stage for his campaign against Fionn and the Clan Morna.

Guided by the wisdom of the local sage, Conn approaches Ireland with a cunning strategy that sows discord among the Fianna, creating suspicion and tension within their ranks, as he begins his campaign against Fionn and the Clan Morna.

Conn's direct assault on the Fianna stronghold leaves the countryside ravaged, drawing Goll's furious and unyielding ire as they prepare to face each other in a climactic battle outside the Fianna camp, where honor, cunning, and the hope for a truce collide.

Conn's bold challenge to Goll has incited the seasoned warrior's ire, drawing him into a fierce confrontation marked by mutual respect and underlying vengeance, as Conn faces Goll in a climactic battle, regardless of previous attempts at negotiation or stealth.

Despite Conn’s attempt at negotiation, which was perceived as weakness by some in Clan Morna, tensions were inflamed as rumors of Conn’s demands spread; ultimately, suspicion and pride on both sides led to an inevitable confrontation, with Conn facing Goll in a climactic battle, regardless of previous attempts at negotiation or stealth.
Conn faces Goll bravely in an honorable duel, but ultimately falls in battle, preserving the purity of his father's legacy and earning the respect of the Fianna for his courage.
Using a cunning tactic, Conn manages to defeat Goll in the battle, gaining revenge for his father but forever tarnishing his honor among the Fianna and altering the balance of power within the clans.

Conn's unexpected offer of a truce was met with reluctance but eventually accepted by Goll, leading to a tenuous peace that allowed Conn to find a place among the Fianna, forever altering the legacy and alliances of both parties.

irish_name: Cuireadh Mhaoil uí Mhananáin ar Fhionn
name: Maol of the House of Manannán’s Invitation to Fionn
story:
Maol of the House of Manannán’s Invitation to Fionn
Cuireadh Mhaoil uí Mhananáin ar Fhionn (Maol of the House of Manannán’s Invitation to Fionn)
The story begins after a day’s hunt, when Fionn and the Fianna are relaxing, playing a game of dice or cards. They are suddenly approached by a small bald man (fear maol). In the Cork version, it is also noted that he is a magician with no ears. The fear maol engages Fionn in conversation. Some elements of the literary version are preserved in their dialogue, including a lingering suspicion about the fear maol’s wife’s infidelity. In boasting about his possessions, he eventually informs Fionn that he has a sow and piglets. Following the general premise of the literary tale, he invites the Fianna for a meal, adding that they can eat one of the pigs. Unbeknownst to Fionn, he has sneakily placed him under a geis whereby he can’t turn down the invitation. He then takes off, leaving the Fianna to hurriedly follow him back to his dwelling. It is completely dark by the time the Fianna arrive. The fear maol informs them that while he invited them to share one of his pigs, he never said that he would kill it, and thus they must perform the task. In the Kerry version, Cormac is given the duty, while in the Cork version it falls on Diarmuid. Regardless, the outcome is the same in both variations. They lay the pig out on the table and when they are prepared to give it a death blow, the scene changes in the blink of an eye. In the Kerry version, the table, pig, and fear maol have all disappeared, leaving them in the empty dwelling with nothing but their dice. They then angrily (and hungrily) return home. The fear maol returns the following week and informs them that he had played a trick on them that evening, and proceeds to provide them with a fine meal. In the Cork version, the situation is never rectified. The story ends with the fear maol’s trick, which in this version finds the Fianna instantly sent back to where they were playing cards at the start of the tale.

scenes.setting: A wooded glen where Fionn and the Fianna are relaxing after a hunt.
scenes.action: Fionn and the Fianna are approached by a fear maol, who engages Fionn in conversation.
choices: Accept the fear maol's invitation without suspicion.
Express suspicion about the fear maol’s intentions and question him further.
Politely decline the invitation despite the geis.
scenes.trigger: Accepting or questioning leads to attending the feast; declining triggers a magical compulsion, forcing them to follow anyway.

scenes.setting: The dark dwelling of the fear maol.
scenes.action: The Fianna arrive at the fear maol’s dwelling and realize they must kill the pig themselves.
choices: Have Cormac take charge of the task.
Let Diarmuid handle the killing as in the Cork version.
scenes.trigger: Choosing Cormac or Diarmuid influences who feels tricked by the disappearance when attempting to kill the pig, leading to their next emotional responses.

scenes.setting: Either back at the original glen or an empty dwelling, depending on the choice made earlier.
scenes.action: The fear maol's trick is revealed, and the Fianna find themselves either back at their starting point or left in an empty room.
choices: Forgive the fear maol and accept his future offer to rectify the trick the following week.
Hold a grudge and decide never to trust him again.
scenes.trigger: Forgiving leads to receiving a fine meal the next week, while holding a grudge means leaving without resolution, reflecting the Cork version.

choicelist: As Fionn and the Fianna arrive at the fear maol’s dark dwelling, Fionn realizes with a chill that his lack of suspicion has bound them to a geis they cannot break, leading to a tense atmosphere as they are informed they must kill the pig themselves.

Despite Fionn's earlier suspicions, the Fianna find themselves at the dark dwelling of the fear maol, tension simmering in the air as Fionn's frustrations with the geis boil over; yet, with no other choice, they reluctantly accept the task, realizing they must kill the pig themselves.

The Fianna, compelled by the magic of the geis despite attempting to decline the invitation, find themselves angrily confronting the fear maol in his dark dwelling, suspicious and resentful of his trickery, only to realize with growing frustration that they must kill the pig themselves.

The Fianna, with Cormac bearing the weight of his failed task and seething with shame and frustration, find themselves suddenly whisked back to the glen, the sounds of their laughter and dice echoing their earlier ignorance of the bald man's cunning trickery.

Diarmuid, feeling the sting of humiliation upon attempting to strike the pig only to find it vanished beneath his hand, erupts with indignation at the fear maol's deceit, a shared sense of betrayal rippling through the Fianna as they grapple with their dashed expectations before finding themselves either back at their starting point or left in an empty room.

The Fianna, deciding to forgive the fear maol, return the next week to find a bountiful feast laid out for them, as the fear maol honors his promise and mends his past trickery with great hospitality.

Despite their anger and distrust toward the fear maol, Fionn and the Fianna choose to move on, realizing that not every encounter needs resolution, but the memory of the magician's trick lingers, adding caution to their future dealings.

name: The Burning of Fionn’s House
story:
The Burning of Fionn’s House
Dóiteán Tighe Fhinn (The Burning of Fionn’s House)
Also known as
Bàs Gharaidh (The Death of Garadh)
One day Fionn and the Fianna were out hunting. They left one of the Fianna behind at their fortress as a guard (usually Garadh, but Goll or Conan in some versions, and Orree in the Manx version). There was a dispute between this man and the women of the Fianna, and they decided to get revenge on him. When he fell asleep, they tied his hair to some stakes which they drove into the ground. Then they made a great noise, and he immediately woke and jumped to his feet, thinking there was a battle happening. In doing so his hair and part of his scalp were torn off.
 He was furious about this, and with the woman inside, he set fire to some heather at the door of the fort to kill them. The Fianna were on the other side of a strait when they saw the fire and they leapt over the strait in their hurry to save the women. One of them, Mac Reithe fell into the water and was drowned. It has been called Caol Reatha (Reatha’s Strait) since then.
 The Fianna saved most of the women and caught the arsonist in order to put him to death for what he had done. He requested that they behead him with Mac an Luin (Fionn’s own sword), with his head resting on Fionn’s thigh. This was granted to him and he was killed, with Fionn’s thigh being wounded in the process. In some versions, Fionn goes on a long journey to get himself healed.

scenes.setting: The fortress of the Fianna while the rest are out hunting.
scenes.action: Garadh, left behind to guard the fort, gets into a dispute with the Fianna women.
choices: Attempt to resolve the dispute peacefully.
Ignore the women and focus on guarding the fort.
Take a confrontational stance, escalating tensions.
scenes.trigger: Choosing peaceful resolution may ease the tension and prevent further conflict, while ignoring may lead to negligence and allow plans of revenge to continue. Escalation leads directly to the women's plot.

Stand your ground, attempting to explain the prank.
Prepare for Garadh's inevitable fury by arming yourself.
scenes.trigger: Retreating may lead Garadh to immediate retaliation by setting the fort aflame, while standing your ground might delay his actions long enough for more Fianna to arrive. Being armed prepares you for a direct confrontation.

choices: Leaping directly to try and reach the fort quickly.
Taking a moment to plan a safer route across.
Ensuring the safety of your comrades before acting.
scenes.trigger: A direct leap risks casualties like Mac Reithe, but might save more lives in the fort. A safe route may reduce Fianna losses, allowing better handling of Garadh afterwards. Ensuring safety may delay but ensures more lives are saved.

choicelist: Despite Garadh's earlier attempt at peacemaking, the women, still harboring resentment, decide to seek revenge while he sleeps, tying his hair to the ground and waking him with a start.

Garadh, neglecting his duty and ignoring the growing unrest from the women, finds himself rudely awakened as they enact their vengeful plot, tying his hair to the ground and waking him up with a start.

The confrontation has left Garadh seething with rage; as he drifts into a fitful sleep, driven by the mocking laughter of the Fianna women still echoing in his ears, they decide to retaliate and craftily tie his hair to the ground before waking him with a start.

Garadh, his wrath ignited by the women's trick and your hasty retreat, sets the fort ablaze in a furious act of vengeance, leaving you and the Fianna to desperately leap over the strait to save those trapped inside.

The Fianna charge across the strait with a mix of anger and desperation, knowing that hesitation from trying to reason with Garadh has set the fort ablaze, yet they must now leap over the strait to save the women.

With Garadh armed and furious at the humiliation, he charges towards the gathered Fianna before they can leap the strait, forcing them into a tense confrontation that tests their loyalty and courage, as they ultimately decide to leap over the strait to save the fort.

The Fianna, driven by urgency, leap directly across the strait managing to extinguish the fire and save most of the women, but suffer the loss of Mac Reithe, setting the stage for their capture and execution of the enraged arsonist.

By planning a safer route across the strait, the Fianna arrived with fewer losses, successfully saved the women, captured Garadh, and sentenced him to death without further casualties, leading Fionn to begin his perilous journey for healing.

The Fianna, having ensured their comrades' safety before acting, managed to creatively construct a makeshift bridge from fallen trees, which allowed them to cross the strait safely, ultimately saving all the women and capturing the arsonist swiftly, who was then executed as decided.

name: The Lay of Diarag
story:
The Lay of Diarag
Duan Dhiarag (The Lay of Diarag)
Fionn came to Scotland to hunt. He grew tired and fell asleep while his friend Diarag kept watch. Another man came, the king of Cannaibh, seeking revenge as his father had been killed by Fionn. While Fionn slept, Diarag and the king of Cannaibh fought with spears and swords until Diarag was mortally wounded (or, in one version, both men were mortally wounded). When Fionn woke, he saw Diarag dying and mourned.

scenes.setting: A forest in Scotland where Fionn mac Cumhaill and Diarag have set up camp.
scenes.action: Fionn decides to rest under a tree while Diarag stands watch.
choices: Diarag decides to wake Fionn to alert him of potential danger.
Diarag continues to keep watch silently, hoping the night will pass uneventfully.
Diarag explores the surrounding area to ensure safety, leaving Fionn for a short time.
scenes.trigger: Waking Fionn could enable preparations for an encounter; standing watch may lead directly to confrontation with the Foreign King; exploring could delay Diarag's response to the king's approach.

scenes.action: The Foreign King confronts Diarag seeking revenge on Fionn.
choices: Diarag challenges the Foreign King himself, determined to protect Fionn.
Diarag attempts to reason with the Foreign King, seeking a peaceful resolution.
Diarag calls out to rouse Fionn before engaging with the Foreign King.
scenes.trigger: Challenging the king leads to a direct fight; reasoning with him might delay the confrontation or make it worse; calling for Fionn's help changes the dynamics of the encounter.

scenes.setting: The heart of the forest, where Diarag lies wounded.
scenes.action: Diarag is mortally wounded in the confrontation; Fionn wakes to find his friend dying.
choices: Fionn seeks vengeance against the Foreign King, driven by rage.
Fionn tends to Diarag in his final moments, offering comfort and making promises.
Fionn reflects on the conflict and considers how he can avoid further bloodshed.
scenes.trigger: Choosing vengeance leads to a cyclic path of retaliation; comforting Diarag allows for a poignant farewell; reflection might lead to a path of reconciliation or change in leadership strategies.

choicelist: Awoken by Diarag's urgent whisper, Fionn stands ready, yet the Foreign King still advances with vengeance in his eyes, forcing Diarag to step forward and confront him, determined to protect Fionn at all costs.

The silence of the night is shattered as the Foreign King slips through the shadows unchallenged, fueled with wrath upon seeing Fionn resting unaware, and demands vengeance from Diarag for his father's death, forcing Diarag to make a stand as protector against the king's seething fury.

As Diarag ventures through the forest, his heart heavy with the knowledge that he has left Fionn unguarded, he encounters the Foreign King who seizes upon his momentary lapse, confronting Diarag with the fierce demand for revenge on Fionn.

Diarag, after a fierce and selfless stand against the Foreign King to protect Fionn, lies on the forest floor gasping for breath; his final resolve shattering as Fionn awakens to find his friend dying.
Diarag's attempt at peace is scorned as the Foreign King, fueled by vengeance, strikes him down in anger, and as Diarag lies wounded, Fionn wakes to find his friend dying.

Diarag's cry shatters the stillness of the forest, causing Fionn to bolt upright just in time to see his loyal friend fall beneath the spear of the Foreign King; the sight ignites a burning rage within Fionn as he rushes to Diarag's side, finding him mortally wounded and dying.

Driven by rage, Fionn confronts the Foreign King, ultimately slaying him, but realizes too late that the cycle of revenge brings only more grief, as Diarag's death marks a deep loss that no vengeance can mend.
Fionn honors Diarag's last moments by swearing to remember his bravery, while realizing that future conflicts must be tempered with wisdom to prevent a cycle of endless violence.
Fionn, deeply moved by the loss of Diarag, chooses to seek peace with the king of Cannaibh, vowing to end the cycle of violence and forging a new alliance to honor his fallen friend.

name: The Lay of the Smithy
story:
The Lay of the Smithy
Duan na Ceàrdaich (The Lay of the Smithy)
Also known as
Laoi na Ceardcha (The Lay of the Smithy)
This lay is told in the voice of Oisín/Oisean. He tells how one day Osgar, Daorghlas, Fionn and himself were out when they saw a big, ugly man coming towards them. He had one eye and one foot. Fionn asked where he was from and the man replied that his name was Lon Mac Liobhain, and that he was the smith of the king of Scandinavia (Lochlann), in Bergen. He put a geas on Fionn, saying that they must all now follow him to his smithy. He went ahead of them, and they ran after. Lon ran unnaturally fast and it was hard for them to keep up with him, but Daorghlas was very fast and followed him closely. When they reached the smithy Daorghlas went inside and started to work in it. The other smiths asked “Who is this slender (caol) man with no (timeadh) fear/heat”, and so Fionn gave him the new name Caoilte. (The wordplay here is clever. The question could mean either “Who is this slender, fearless man?” or “Who is this slender man who does not feel the heat (of the forge)?” Fionn combined the sounds of the words caol and timeadh to create the new name “Caoilte”.)
 Caoilte and the smiths then made excellent swords for the heroes. Fionn’s sword was called Mac an Luin. They went from there and there was a battle between the Fianna (Caoilte, Faolan, Fionn, Osgar, Goll and Oisín/Oisean himself) against the army of the king of Scandinavia (Lochlann), which the Fianna won.
 In some versions there is an episode before the battle in which Lon says the swords must be tempered in human blood, and the lot falls to Fionn. He tricks the smith’s mother so that Lon kills her with the sword, and Fionn then kills Lon, thus tempering the blade, and so the swords are ready. At the end of the lay Oisín/Oisean laments his old age and loneliness.
 In versions collected in Donegal, Caoilte’s original name is Delgus or Daolghas instead of Daorghlas, and it is Conan or Conn, rather than Fionn, who gives him his new name.

scenes.setting: A lush green forest in ancient Ireland, where the Fianna first encounter Lon Mac Liobhain.
scenes.action: The Fianna encounter the mysterious and menacing figure of Lon Mac Liobhain, who places a geas on Fionn, compelling them to follow him.
choices: Follow Lon Mac Liobhain immediately, respecting the ancient geas.
Challenge Lon Mac Liobhain, seeking more information about his intentions.
Attempt to flee from Lon Mac Liobhain, resisting the geas.
scenes.trigger: Following him leads directly to the smithy; challenging him can reveal more about the geas but still ends up at the smithy; fleeing results in a pursuit scene back to the smithy.

scenes.setting: Inside the dark, smoky smithy with the sound of hammers and the glow of the forge.
scenes.action: Daorghlas, or Caoilte, begins to work at the forge, impressing the other smiths while the Fianna consider the intent of their visit.
choices: Assist Caoilte in forging the weapons, ensuring their quality.
Question Lon Mac Liobhain about the necessity of the swords.
Seek an alliance with the other smiths, hoping to turn the tables on Lon.
scenes.trigger: Helping Caoilte results in excellent weapons being made; questioning reveals the swords must be tempered in blood; seeking an alliance opens a potential conflict against Lon.

scenes.setting: A battlefield on the outskirts of the kingdom of Scandinavia (Lochlann), amidst an impending battle.
scenes.action: The Fianna, armed with their new swords, prepare to battle the army of the king of Scandinavia.
choices: Lead a direct assault on the enemy forces, trusting in the new weapons.
Seek out Lon Mac Liobhain before the battle to temper the swords in human blood as per his dark command.
Attempt to negotiate with the opposing army, seeking a peaceful resolution using diplomacy.
scenes.trigger: A direct assault results in a fierce battle with potential victory or loss; tempering the swords with blood can lead to a sorcerous advantage; negotiating might lead to unexpected alliances or betrayal.

choicelist: Acknowledging the power of the geas, the Fianna proceed with caution and wariness, their respect for the ancient magic inflaming a rising tension within the group, as Fionn wrestles with the weight of his leadership, all while Daorghlas, now dubbed Caoilte, begins to work at the forge, impressing the other smiths while the Fianna consider the intent of their visit.

As the Fianna challenge Lon Mac Liobhain about the geas, Lon's patience wears thin, his single eye blazing with fury, and he threatens dire consequences if they do not comply, forcing Fionn and his men to weigh their loyalty to each other against the perilous demands of their captor; Daorghlas, now Caoilte, begins to work at the forge, impressing the other smiths while the Fianna consider the intent of their visit.

The Fianna, having attempted to flee and been chased by Lon Mac Liobhain's relentless pace, storm into the smithy with a mix of shame and defiance, their breath ragged and their pride wounded, as Daorghlas, or Caoilte, begins to work at the forge, impressing the other smiths while the Fianna consider the intent of their visit.

With the swords forged to perfection, the Fianna sense the weight of expectation and the looming threat of betrayal as whispers among the smiths suggest that the weapons must still be tempered in blood, a truth that hangs heavy over them, driving them to the battlefield on the outskirts of the kingdom of Scandinavia (Lochlann), amidst an impending battle.

As the Fianna stand on the battlefield with tensions rising, Oisín confronts Lon Mac Liobhain about the need for blood-tempered blades, causing dissension within their ranks, with some warriors looking towards Fionn for leadership while others, uneasy and doubting, feel the weight of this dark command and the path it has set them on as they prepare to battle the army of the king of Scandinavia.

As the Fianna prepare for battle, tensions rise after Caoilte's secret alliance with the smiths is unveiled, inciting distrust among the heroes as they debate trusting their new allies or confronting the treacherous Lon Mac Liobhain, yet despite their turmoil, they stand ready to face the army of the king of Lochlann.

The Fianna, wielding their newly forged swords, charge valiantly into the battlefield against the king of Scandinavia's army, achieving a hard-earned victory that cements their legendary status, but this triumph is tinged with Oisín's later lament of solitude in old age.

Fionn cunningly deceives Lon Mac Liobhain into using his own mother's blood to temper the swords, granting the Fianna a mystical edge that leads them to victorious triumph over the army of Scandinavia.

The Fianna's attempt to negotiate with the opposing army leads to an unexpected alliance, turning the tide of the impending battle and resulting in a harmonious resolution that spares both sides from further bloodshed.

name: The Lay of the Children
story:
The Lay of the Children
Duan na Cloinne (The Lay of the Children)
This lay is framed as a dialogue between Oisean and Patrick.

The narrative takes place after the Battle of Gabhair, in which most of the Fianna were killed, and which none but Caoilte and Oisean survived. Those two went to the place where the women and children of the Fianna stayed and were there when a messenger came from the king of Scandinavia (Lochlann) saying that he had come to take control of Ireland. Oisean and Caoilte refused this, saying the invading army would be killed by the children of the Fianna.

Oisean, Caoilte, and the children raised Fionn’s banner and there was a terrible battle, in which many were killed. That night there was a great mourning for the children of the Fianna who had been killed in the battle. At the end of the lay Oisean tells Patrick that he is filled with sorrow when he sees the hill where the battle was fought.

A version of this lay was collected in Caithness.

scenes.action: Oisín and Caoilte receive a messenger from the King of Scandinavia demanding surrender.
choices: Choose to diplomatically negotiate with the foreign king.
Prepare immediately for battle, insisting that the Fianna's children will defend Ireland.
Seek the counsel of Fionn mac Cumhaill's spirit for guidance.
scenes.trigger: Negotiation may lead to a temporary truce or a cunning trap. Preparing for battle unites the group, but at great risk. Seeking guidance may offer a new strategy or deeper insight.

scenes.setting: The battlefield at the foot of the hill, just before the armies meet.
scenes.action: Oisín, Caoilte, and the children of the Fianna raise Fionn's banner and prepare for combat.
choices: Lead a direct assault against the invaders.
Use guerrilla tactics to surprise and outmaneuver the foreign army.
scenes.trigger: A direct assault may inspire bravery but lead to heavy losses. Guerrilla tactics might create confusion and reduce casualties, but risk demoralizing the younger warriors.

scenes.setting: The aftermath of the battle on the blood-stained hill.
scenes.action: Oisín reflects on the losses and mourns the fallen children of the Fianna.
choices: Honor the fallen with a song of remembrance and continue the fight for Ireland's freedom.
Seek spiritual solace and the blessing of St. Patrick to heal the land and its people.

name: The Lay of the Muileartach
story:
The Lay of the Muileartach
Duan na Muileartaich (The Lay of the Muileartach)
One day the Fianna saw a terrible, ugly, swift monster coming to Ireland. She (or, in some versions, he) was the Muileartach, and she killed many of the heroes with ease. Fionn offered her a ransom to leave, but she refused, saying all that she wanted was the heads of Oscar, Raighne and Caireall. The Fianna rose to fight her, and there followed a fierce struggle at the end of which Fionn killed the Muileartach. It was the hardest fight he had fought since getting his sword from Lon mac Liobhain (see Duan na Ceàrdaich / the Lay of the Smithy). When the king who had sent her out heard the news that she had been killed, he vowed to come to Ireland to get revenge.

name: The Lay of the Nine
story:
The Lay of the Nine
Duan nan Naonar (The Lay of the Nine)
This lay is told in the voice of Oisean, who tells the story to Patrick. Nine of the Fianna were out hunting one day: Fionn, mac Luthach (or, in a version from Caithness, mac an Lobhar), Oscar, Goll, Caoilte, Faolan, Caireall, Diarmaid and Oisean himself. When they were tired after the hunt, they rested on a hillock. A young man came up to them, saying that the king of Scandinavia (Lochlann) had sent him to Ireland to raid it and take tribute. Fionn refused to give him tribute, and the Fianna rose to fight. Although there were only nine of them, they routed the army of Lochlann, each of them killing ten (or six, depending on the version) of the enemy. Fionn won the battle, and the nine all survived the battle.

name: The Fort of the Gold
story:
The Fort of the Gold
Dùn an Òir (The Fort of the Gold)
Fionn and six of the Fianna were out one day when a man came towards them. He said that he came from Dùn an Òir (The Golden Fortress) in the west, a fortress which had never submitted to any enemy. They followed him to the fortress, and there were given hospitality. While they were eating, the warriors of the fortress came to them, intending to kill them. Fionn offered them a ransom if they would let the Fianna leave in peace, but this was refused, so there was a battle between them. The Fianna won and went home after the battle with the treasures of the Fortress of Gold.

name: The Adventure of the Difficult Lad
story:
The Adventure of the Difficult Lad
Eachtra an Ghiolla Dheacair (The Adventure of the Difficult Lad)
Also known as
Teacht an Ghiolla Dheacair (The Coming of the Difficult Lad)
Fionn and the Fianna are hunting when a giant known as the Giolla Deacair (Difficult Lad) approaches them along with an unusually large and skinny horse. In versions from County Galway and South Kerry, he asks Fionn if he may temporarily join the ranks of the Fianna as a servant, to which Fionn almost always obliges. Fionn then allows his horse to graze amongst the Fianna’s own. Being of an ill-temperament, however, the horse begins to fight with the Fianna’s horses. Conán mac Morna demands that the horse be removed. The Giolla Deacair is none too pleased with this, and refuses to remove the horse himself. As a result, the Fianna, led by Conán, attempt to gallop the horse to death. Conán is much smaller than the horse’s normal rider, so up to fifteen other members of the Fianna mount the horse and begin to apply pressure. The Giolla Deacair, disgusted by the attack on his horse, decides to leave Ireland, and when his horse sees his master leaving, it takes off after him along with Conán and the other members of the Fianna. Conán and the other men become stuck to the horse’s back and are unable to dismount, so Fionn and the other Fianna must set out to rescue them. 
 The horse continues on until it reaches the sea, then proceeds to follow his master into the water. When Fionn and the Fianna reach the seashore, they come across two men who magically furnish them with a boat and offer to help track the missing horse and members of the Fianna (In some versions the two men are presented as giants). The search party eventually come upon a steep, rocky island in the middle of the sea, which is presented as ‘the Land of Promise’ or ‘Tír na nÓg’ (‘The Land of Youth’). 
 Fionn and the Fianna enter the island and rescue their comrades from the Giolla Deacair, who turns out to be the island’s king and a powerful enchanter. Broadly reflecting the early modern literary version, some tellings from Connacht have Conán exact punishment upon the Giolla Deacair by insisting that he and fourteen of his men be brought to Ireland in the same manner which he and the Fianna were. The Giolla Deacair accepts this form of retribution and the Fianna await the arrival of him and his men in Ireland. When they arrive and dismount from the horse, the Giolla Deacair motions towards the meadow where the Fianna’s horses are grazing. When the Fianna look back, he and his men have disappeared.

name: The Adventure of the Crop-Eared Dog
story:
The Adventure of the Crop-Eared Dog
Eachtra an Mhadra Mhaoil (The Adventure of the Crop-Eared Dog)
This story is not typically Fenian. In one version however, Fionn and the Fianna are present
and, reflecting motifs from both bruíon (otherworld dwelling) and helper tales, they are held
captive and bound with a magical rope that can only be disarmed by three jugs of water from a magic well in a treacherous glen. A helper figure called an t-Óglach Óg (the young warrior) sets off to retrieve the water after he encounters the Fianna and speaks with Fionn. When he approaches the well, he meets the Madra Maol (Crop-Eared Dog)—a man who has been turned into a dog, and whose ear and tail were cut off by his step-brother. When the dog learns what has happened to the Fianna, he informs the young warrior that this is also the work of his step-brother, and accompanies him on his return journey. The Fianna do not feature in the rest of the story.

In more traditional versions of the tale, Arthur and the Knights of the Roundtable appear in the same captive role as the Fianna, and must be similarly rescued by a young helper. 

This story was collected in County Kerry in Ireland.

Hesitant after learning the dangers, the young warrior approaches the well cautiously, his heart pounding as the Crop-Eared Dog eyes him warily, recounting his tale of betrayal and offering his aid against his own kin.

As the young warrior, after spending precious time searching in vain for additional allies, finally approaches the magic well alone and weary, he is startled by the appearance of Madra Maol, who, having been monitoring his fruitless efforts, admonishes him for the delay, cautioning that every moment lost strengthens his wicked step-brother's hold over the Fianna, before revealing his tragic story and offering to help in the quest against his step-brother.

Having trusted Madra Maol, the young warrior relies on the dog's keen senses and knowledge of his step-brother's cunning nature to skillfully navigate a series of deadly traps—with moments of doubt and fear gnawing at them—set to thwart their journey back to the Fianna, pressing forward without faltering.

Haunted by his earlier decision to shun the Crop-Eared Dog's counsel, the young warrior struggles through the perilous glen alone, his steps faltering into ensnaring traps laid by the vengeful step-brother, until, against all odds, Madra Maol arrives unexpectedly, offering his guidance and sparking hope for their survival and return to the Fianna with the three jugs of water.
Guided by Madra Maol’s keen instincts, the young warrior skillfully navigates the treacherous traps, successfully pacifies the family feud, and returns to liberate the captive Fianna.

Despite the initial chaos caused by their brute force approach, the young warrior and Madra Maol manage to overcome the step-brother's traps, though they lose one jug of water in the process, ultimately breaking the magical rope and freeing the Fianna, while setting Madra Maol on a path to reconciliation with his family.

name: The Adventure of Cab an Dosáin
story:
The Adventure of Cab an Dosáin
Eachtra Chab an Dosáin (The Adventure of Cab an Dosáin)
Also known as
Laoi Chab an Dosáin (The Lay of Cab an Dosáin)
One day while Conán and Diarmaid are out hunting, a man appears on the back of a wild cow (or donkey, or deer). He says that if they can keep up with him, he will give them food and lodging for the night. They eventually reach his abode where he provides them with food and drink as promised. When they go to sleep, Conán becomes overcome with lust at the sight of a fairy woman (sometimes described as the daughter of Cab an Dosáin or more generically as “the young queen”) who causes him no end of misfortune throughout the night. Some accounts broadly reflect literary versions, in which Conán’s justified humiliation comes in response to his belligerence and unwelcome advances toward the fairy woman. In each startling scenario (the last of which involves him undergoing the pain of childbirth), he cries out violently, waking Diarmaid and the others. Elsewhere, Fionn uses his thumb of knowledge to discover what is happening to Conán, and Goll goes to rescue him. The threat of Goll and the Fianna leads their host to release Conán from his torment.

This story, found in both lay and prose form, was collected in Counties Galway and Mayo.

scenes.trigger: Fionn’s wisdom resolves the conflict peacefully with a lesson for Conán; Goll’s intervention results in a confrontation with magical consequences. Both choices conclude the story with Conán's release and either gratitude or chastening.

choicelist: As they follow the wild cow and make their way to the abode of Cab an Dosáin, the air turns tense with an enchantment that lingers long into the night, and Conán, now deeply entangled in visions of a captivating fairy woman, finds himself ensnared in a web of his own desires and vulnerabilities, leading to a night of tormented fantasies and his eventual cries that disrupt the sleep of all.

Conán and Diarmaid, having refused the challenge and ventured far into the darkening woods, are caught in an unsettling storm that forces them to seek shelter at the mysterious abode of Cab an Dosáin, where Conán, shaken and slightly resentful of their earlier decision, is now beset by visions of a captivating fairy woman.

Their earlier confrontation having set an uneasy tone, Conán and Diarmaid find themselves watched by suspicious eyes in Cab an Dosáin's abode, unease rippling through the hall as Conán, already marked by distrust, is beset by visions of a captivating fairy woman.

Though Conán struggles to resist the fairy woman's allure through gritted determination, her enchantment takes a deeper hold, causing him to cry out in a violent, tormented frenzy that forces Fionn and Goll to intervene; Conán's anguished screams alert them to his plight, involving the entire group.

Conán's reckless pursuit of the fairy woman entangles him in a web of enchantment, causing him to collapse in agony and prompting Fionn and Goll, alarmed and furious at this self-inflicted peril, to rush into action, ultimately involving the entire group.

Conán's desperate cries awaken Diarmaid, who immediately informs Fionn, causing tension as the Fianna are pulled into the conflict, with Fionn using his thumb of knowledge to understand the grim predicament while Goll, driven by anger at Conán’s folly, prepares to confront the host in order to end Conán’s torment, ultimately involving the entire group.

Fionn, with his thumb of knowledge, discerned the true nature of the fairy woman’s enchantment and mediated a peaceful end to Conán's torment, imparting a humbling lesson to Conán about the consequences of disrespect and impulsivity.

Goll's forceful intervention breaks the enchantment, leading to a chaotic confrontation that dissipates the magic, but not before Conán learns a harsh lesson about respect and restraint, leaving him bruised yet wiser.

name: The Adventure of Céadach the Great
story:
The Adventure of Céadach the Great
Eachtra Chéadaigh Mhóir (The Adventure of Céadach the Great)
The story is centered around the rivalry between Céadach (or Ceudach) and a peer who eventually kills him. In northern and western versions, his rival is typically referred to as Lonndubh or some variation depending on the location and specific details of the story (for example ‘Lon Dubh Mac Rí Tír na Sorcha’ or ‘Lonndubh Mac Rí na bhFaoileann’). In Kerry versions, his name appears as some form of ‘Gruaig Dhearg’. Their relationship to one another also varies. While some versions depict them as step-brothers, others cast them as young apprentices, students or warriors. The basis of their feud is usually presented as a love triangle, in which the two men compete for the hand of a female character (often referred to as Scoith Shíoda). In some versions, she is referred to as the daughter of a king, while elsewhere she is the daughter of their tutor or the blacksmith for whom they are apprenticing. One common element in almost all tellings is the way in which the competition between the two is settled. The father places the men in a room and has them exit out of two separate doors. He then instructs his daughter to follow whomever she prefers. In all cases, Céadach is selected. In some western and northern versions, Céadach has a more active role in the desired outcome, as he nails a consenting Lonndubh’s finger to an anvil in the promise that should they meet in the future, Lonndubh can deliver the first blow uncontested.
 The couple departs and Céadach takes service with the Fianna. After a successful hunting trip in which he is seen to be the most accomplished of the group, they begin to fear his power and assign him a number of onerous tasks in the hope that he will be killed carrying them out. In time Fionn asks Céadach to accompany him to the Eastern World (in some versions, this trip is the result of a hag placing a geis on Fionn). While his wife (or mother in Scottish versions) initially refuses to let him go, she eventually relents with the proviso that Fionn should raise white sails on their return approach if Céadach is alive and black sails if he has perished during the journey. In some of the versions from County Kerry, she instructs Fionn to raise red sails if Céadach has died and informs him that in such a case, she will then drown herself. In other tellings, Céadach warns Fionn not to carry out the request because his wife is likely to drown them all in her moment of grief. However, in one version from County Kerry, Fionn comes to this conclusion himself through the thumb of knowledge. He also has a premonition that Céadach will be killed by his old rival, Lonndubh. In most versions, this comes to fruition, sometimes invoking the earlier ‘first blow’ aspect of the plot.

The story concludes with Céadach’s resurrection. In Munster, this is typically brought about by the Fianna, who brandish a cure from the Eastern World. In other versions, he is revived by his wife (or mother in Scottish versions). In Ulster renderings, this is achieved by mimicking the actions of a group of crows who bring one of their flock back to life with renewing water.

scenes.setting: A room in the castle of Scoith Shíoda’s father
scenes.action: The father invites Céadach and Lonndubh to each exit through separate doors, letting Scoith Shíoda choose whom to follow.
choices: Céadach decides to intervene by nailing Lonndubh’s finger to an anvil with Lonndubh's consent.
Céadach refrains from intervening and waits for Scoith Shíoda's decision.
Negotiate a different form of competition to win Scoith Shíoda’s favor.
scenes.trigger: The choice affects whether Céadach wins Scoith Shíoda’s hand through negotiation, through the anvil trick, or through waiting, leading to their departure together.

scenes.setting: A dense forest where the Fianna are gathered for a hunt
scenes.action: Céadach outperforms the Fianna, leading them to assign him difficult tasks.
choices: Céadach accepts the tasks courageously, demonstrating his prowess.
Céadach questions the motives of the Fianna and seeks counsel from Scoith Shíoda.
Céadach proposes an alternative way to prove his loyalty without undertaking dangerous tasks.
