The Fianna quickly join their hosts, save for Goll, who remains vigilant. A conflict arises between Goll (or Conán) and Lúghbhaidh (Lú), who is amongst the hosts. They strike Lúghbhaidh and a brawl ensues, during which Goll slays a large number of the hosts.

scenes.setting: The journey to the High King of Tara's feast, along the winding paths through the dense Irish forests.
scenes.action: The Fianna are traveling towards the feast, discussing the unusual request to come unarmed, except for pocket knives.
choices: Trust in the High King's intentions and continue to the feast without questioning.
Heed Conán's warning and keep a close watch for treachery along the way.
Decide to send a scout ahead to observe the feast from a distance before proceeding.
scenes.trigger: Trusting the King leads directly to the feast scene. Being cautious results in a heightened awareness at the feast. Sending a scout could reveal the hidden swords before arrival.

scenes.setting: The grand hall of Tara, filled with the High King's guests seated around a long, wooden banquet table.
scenes.action: The Fianna are greeted with ceremonial grandiosity, yet a cautious tension fills the air, particularly for Goll.
choices: Join the feast fully, attempting to blend with the hosts and enjoy the hospitality.
Remain vigilant, choosing to stay at the edge of the festivities, watching the hosts closely.
Initiate a conversation with Lúghbhaidh, subtly probing for any sign of deception.
scenes.trigger: If participants blend in, they may be caught off guard by conflict. Remaining vigilant could provide an advantage in the ensuing brawl. Approaching Lúghbhaidh directly may either confirm suspicions or forestall the conflict entirely, depending on interactions.

scenes.setting: The chaotic feast hall turned battleground, where tension erupts into conflict.
scenes.action: A brawl erupts following either suspicions or accusations, leading to Goll confronting the hosts in battle.
choices: Fight alongside Goll, ensuring a decisive victory despite the treacherous hosts.
Seek a non-violent resolution amidst the chaos, attempting to mediate peace.
Withdraw to regroup, prioritizing the safety and strategic retreat with the Fianna.
scenes.trigger: Supporting Goll ensures a dramatic battle with a victorious narrative. Mediation offers a potential diplomatic resolution if successful. Withdrawal could lead to a strategic regrouping for future confrontations, affecting relationships with the High King.

choicelist: The Fianna, having trusted in the High King's intentions, enter the grand hall of Tara with an air of unguarded camaraderie, but as they are greeted with ceremonial grandiosity, a subtle undercurrent of unease threads through the celebration, particularly for Goll, who notices the tension more than others; yet the Fianna endeavor to dismiss their doubts, mingling with their hosts amidst an atmosphere that teeters on the brink of concealed betrayal.

With Goll's vigilance heightened due to Conán's warning, he senses the subtle shift in the room's atmosphere, noticing the tight grips of the hosts on their hidden swords, as the Fianna are greeted with ceremonial grandiosity, yet a cautious tension fills the air, particularly for Goll.

The Fianna's scout returns breathless, revealing the hidden swords beneath the banquet table, sparking immediate suspicion and simmering anger amongst the Fianna, particularly in Goll, who senses the looming betrayal; nonetheless, they are greeted with ceremonial grandiosity, yet a cautious tension fills the air, particularly for Goll.

Lulled by the feigned camaraderie, your choice to fully join the feast blindsides the Fianna as hidden blades are revealed, treachery erupting into chaos with Goll swiftly rising to rally against the hosts, igniting a fierce battle.

Goll, vigilant and wary from the edge of the festivities, notices a furtive exchange between Lúghbhaidh and another host, confirming his suspicions of deceit, igniting his ire and prompting an immediate confrontation that escalates as he strikes, leading to a brawl where the hosts reveal their treacherous nature and Goll prepares to face them in battle.

Lúghbhaidh, feeling cornered by your probing questions, grows hostile and accuses Goll of treachery, inciting the hosts against the Fianna as the hall descends into a furious melee, leading to Goll confronting the hosts in battle.

The Fianna, united in battle under Goll's leadership, triumph over the treacherous hosts, solidifying their reputation for bravery and cunning, but severing ties with the High King and casting a shadow of unease over future alliances.

Through skillful diplomacy and calm negotiation amidst the chaos, you manage to de-escalate the conflict, forging a temporary truce with the hosts and preserving the honor and safety of the Fianna at the feast.
The Fianna, led by Goll's tactical retreat, successfully regroup and flee the treacherous feast, preserving their unity and preparing for future alliances with heightened caution.

name: The Lay of the Feud
story:
The Lay of the Feud
Laoi an Fhíocha (The Lay of the Feud)
Also known as
Laoi an Fhiaich (The Lay of the Fiach), Laoi an Fhíoch (The Lay of the Fíoch)
Oisín tells the story of two brothers (the sons of a king in India) who decide to attack the Fianna but who appear to have a particular enmity with Goll. In at least one version it is explained that their mother is Goll’s sister and in others it appears that Goll’s reputation as a warrior has made him a target for the glory-seeking first brother.
 The first brother arrives in Ireland and, after a description of his appearance, he slaughters a huge number of the Fianna. He then demands to fight Oisín and Goll at once but Goll will only accept single combat. After a great struggle, and having been dangerously close to defeat, after Goll eventually overcomes the invader.
 News of the outcome reaches India and the second brother ‘Bua-Gach-Áir’ and he decides to avenge his brother’s death. His mother attempts to convince him not to fight Goll but, spurred on by his father, he does not heed the warning.
 Fionn attempts to convince the brother not to follow through with the plan and Goll narrates a list of the Fianna who he believes should be available to help. (This list is similar to that in Duanaire Finn no. 64.) The battle begins and Goll, having recently battled the first brother, is unable to defeat the second. He requests assistance and is initially refused before Diarmuid assists in defeating Bua-Gach-Áir.
 This lay has been collected in Donegal and Galway in Ireland.

scenes.setting: The shores of Ireland where the first brother arrives with his forces.
scenes.action: The first brother, eager for battle, challenges Oisín and Goll, defeating many of the Fianna.
choices: Accept the challenge for single combat against Goll.
Attempt to persuade the brother to seek peace instead of battle.
Prepare a strategic retreat to regroup the Fianna forces.
scenes.trigger: The first choice leads directly to the combat against Goll; the second might avert initial conflict, but risks misunderstanding leading back to battle; the third gives time for strategic planning, with consequences on available resources for the fight.

scenes.setting: A clearing in the forest where Goll and the Fianna prepare for Bua-Gach-Áir's arrival.
scenes.action: Bua-Gach-Áir arrives, determined to avenge his brother, as Goll struggles with fatigue from the previous battle.
choices: Goll decides to fight Bua-Gach-Áir alone despite his exhaustion.
Goll seeks counsel from Fionn to rally the Fianna for support in battle.
scenes.trigger: The first choice could lead to Goll's defeat without intervention, requiring heroics from others; the second choice sees Fionn marshal the Fianna, impacting morale and the battle's outcome.

scenes.setting: The battlefield where Diarmuid finally confronts Bua-Gach-Áir.
scenes.action: Diarmuid joins the fray to tip the scales, balancing the odds against Bua-Gach-Áir.
choices: Diarmuid employs cunning to deceive and overcome Bua-Gach-Áir.
Diarmuid bets on sheer combat skill, engaging Bua-Gach-Áir in direct confrontation.
scenes.trigger: The choice between deception or direct combat affects Diarmuid's reputation and the Fianna's future tactics, with success leading to victory over Bua-Gach-Áir and variable gains in honor or strategic advantage.

choicelist: Goll, still weary from the grueling duel with the first brother and aware of his own vulnerability after choosing to fight alone, stands resolute as Bua-Gach-Áir arrives, determined to avenge his brother, while the tensions among the Fianna grow as they witness their leader confronting such danger without their immediate support.

Goll, weary yet resolute, faces Bua-Gach-Áir’s arrival with an undercurrent of tension, as Fionn and the Fianna react with frustration to the previous attempt for peace which has clearly failed, leaving them scrambling to decide on their next move.

Although the Fianna managed a strategic retreat to regroup, the toll of this maneuver leaves Goll exhausted and questioning the loyalty of his comrades as Bua-Gach-Áir arrives, determined to avenge his brother.

Goll, barely standing and bleeding from his wounds after his solitary and stubborn confrontation with Bua-Gach-Áir, gasps for aid as Diarmuid, witnessing his comrade's peril, steps forward with resolve to tip the scales, balancing the odds against Bua-Gach-Áir.

As Fionn rallies the Fianna, some warriors question Goll's leadership due to his prior exhaustion but the group's morale shifts when Diarmuid, inspired by unity and honor, joins the fray to tip the scales, balancing the odds against Bua-Gach-Áir.

With Diarmuid's cunning tactics leading to Bua-Gach-Áir's defeat, the Fianna gain not only victory but also a newfound strategic perspective, enhancing their reputation as wise and formidable warriors.

Diarmuid, leveraging his exceptional combat prowess, decisively defeats Bua-Gach-Áir in direct confrontation, securing victory for the Fianna and earning great honor, reinforcing the Fianna's reputation for martial excellence.

name: The Lay of the Mantle
story:
The Lay of the Mantle
Laoidh an Bhrait (The Lay of the Mantle)
Further Information
Book of the Dean of Lismore no. 7; Duanaire Finn no. 65
Conán Maol remains home drinking with the women of the Fianna while the men are out hunting. In their drunkenness, the women proclaim that they are the most faithful in the world. With that, a beautiful woman appears with a magic cloak, which she says can reveal the unfaithfulness of women if it does not fully cover them. Conán finds great amusement in this, and referring to the women’s earlier boasts, implores them to try the magic garment. The garment reveals the infidelity of the first few women. The fate of the remaining women may not appear in oral versions, but in literary versions, which are delivered as a conversation between Oisín and Pádraig, Oisín’s wife is proven to be the sole faithful woman. With the infidelity of the Fenian women revealed, the stranger then departs with her magical cloak.

scenes.setting: The great hall of the Fianna, where drinks are being shared amongst the remaining women and Conán Maol.
scenes.action: The women of the Fianna, in their drunkenness, boast of their fidelity, prompting Conán Maol to mockingly challenge them with the gift of a newly arrived stranger—a magic cloak that can reveal infidelity.
choices: Encourage Conán to proceed with the challenge, eager to see the results.
Attempt to dissuade Conán from using the cloak, warning of the potential discord it could cause.
Ignore Conán’s antics and turn attention to speaking with the stranger about her intentions.
scenes.trigger: Choosing to encourage Conán leads to showing the cloak in action, dissuading results in a brief delay and further discussions amongst the women, while speaking to the stranger reveals more about the cloak’s purpose.

scenes.setting: A tense atmosphere in the hall as the first few women attempt to wear the cloak.
scenes.action: The cloak fails to fully cover the first few women, revealing their infidelity, which leads to mixed reactions of shock, anger, and humor from Conán and the others.
choices: Stand with the women, offering support despite their revelations.
Applaud the stranger for the entertainment and intrigue she has brought.
Challenge the stranger, questioning the fairness or accuracy of the cloak's magic.
scenes.trigger: Supporting the women increases tensions, applauding entertains the idea of further demonstrations, while challenging the magic escalates conflict between Conán and the stranger.

scenes.setting: Focus shifts to Oisín’s wife, who hesitantly agrees to try the cloak.
scenes.action: The cloak fully covers Oisín's wife, revealing her fidelity, leaving everyone in the hall astonished and the stranger preparing to depart.
choices: Celebrate Oisín’s wife's fidelity as a testament to true love.
Express relief that the ordeal is over and suggest returning to normalcy.
Converse with the stranger about her journey and what other truths she seeks to uncover.
scenes.trigger: Celebrating creates a sense of unity and morale among the Fianna, expressing relief signals an end to turmoil, while engaging with the stranger opens potential for learning more about her and her mysterious artifact.

choicelist: Conán, spurred by the user's encouragement and eager for amusement, mockingly insists that each woman try the cloak, provoking a heated atmosphere where the tension is palpable, roles of instigators and victims blur, and the very fabric of trust within the hall frays as the cloak fails to fully cover the first few women, revealing their infidelity, which leads to mixed reactions of shock, anger, and humor from Conán and the others.

Despite attempts to dissuade Conán, the tension in the hall escalates as the women, fearful yet defiant, submit to the cloak's test, revealing infidelity in the first few, which leads to mixed reactions of shock, anger, and humor from Conán and the others.

As the user engages the stranger, the hall hushes, anticipating the stranger's revelation of the cloak’s power, sparking a fierce debate about trust and the outsider's motives, before the cloak fails to fully cover the first few women, revealing their infidelity, which leads to mixed reactions of shock, anger, and humor from Conán and the others.

Suddenly, the hall falls into a heated uproar as Conán, feeling mocked by the support shown to the women, confronts the user with belligerence, challenging their allegiance and causing simmering tensions to rise until Oisín's wife, donning the cloak effortlessly, silences everyone with the undeniable proof of her fidelity, leaving the hall astonished and the stranger preparing to depart.

Conán, buoyed by the earlier applause for the stranger's spectacle, boldly challenges the integrity of the Fenians further by declaring his intent for all to witness the test on Oisín's wife, escalating tensions and anxiety among the gathered, yet after the tumult, the cloak fully covers Oisín's wife, revealing her fidelity, leaving everyone in the hall astonished and the stranger preparing to depart.

The stranger, visibly offended by the challenge to her magic, summons a fierce wind that rattles the hall, casting doubt and discord among the people, yet the chaos subsides as her cloak fully covers Oisín's wife, revealing her fidelity, leaving everyone in the hall astonished and the stranger preparing to depart.

The Fianna, inspired by the unwavering fidelity of Oisín’s wife, come together in renewed unity and respect, vowing to uphold honesty and love within their bonds, as the mysterious stranger departs with her cloak, leaving behind a sense of both wonder and moral reflection.

With the relief of the ordeal over and a newfound sense of tranquility, the Fianna gather to recount the day's events and promise to cherish and trust one another more deeply, while the stranger quietly departs, leaving them to ponder the mysteries she brought into their lives.

The stranger, intrigued by the open dialogue, shares tales of other enchanted artifacts she seeks, sparking a newfound curiosity and adventurous spirit in the Fianna, who offer their aid in her quest for hidden truths across Ireland.

name: The Lay of the Eight
story:
The Lay of the Eight
Laoidh an Ochtair (The Lay of the Eight)
Further Information
Book of the Dean of Lismore no. 12
In this lay Oisean tells Patrick about a campaign in which eight of the Fianna (Oscar, Goll, Caoilte, Faolan, Diarmaid, Fionn, Fergus and Oisean himself) went to raid other countries. They left Ireland and plundered Scotland, the court of the King of England, and France, and seized the city of Bergen in Norway.
 A version of this lay was collected in Caithness.

scenes.setting: The shores of Ireland as the Fianna prepare to set sail
scenes.action: The Fianna, led by Fionn, gather at the coast to embark on their raiding journey. Oisín recounts their departure and the camaraderie among the warriors.
choices: Decide to sail northward towards Scotland first
Opt to head directly to the English court for a bold start
Vote to begin the raid in France for a strategic advantage
scenes.trigger: The choice of destination affects the initial encounter with foreign forces and sets the tone for the raid.

scenes.setting: The foreign lands based on the initial choice (Scotland, England, or France)
scenes.action: The Fianna engage with local defenses as they carry out their raid, encountering unforeseen challenges and making strategic decisions.
choices: Focus on stealth and avoid direct combat to maximize plunder
Engage enemies head-on to demonstrate the strength of the Fianna
Negotiate with local leaders to secure tribute instead of raiding
scenes.trigger: The strategy chosen affects the outcome of the raid, influencing the morale and resources of the Fianna.

scenes.setting: The City of Bergen in Norway
scenes.action: The Fianna, having secured wealth and experience, arrive in Bergen where they face a formidable challenge.
choices: Attempt a surprise attack on the city to catch defenders off guard
Seek an audience with the city leaders to establish dominance without bloodshed
scenes.trigger: The final choice determines the legacy of the raid: a peaceful domination or a brutal conquest, with reflections from Oisín on the lessons learned.

choicelist: As the Fianna sail northward towards Scotland, they are met with treacherous storms that test their resolve and fracture their unity, forcing them to make critical decisions about leadership and survival; the Fianna engage with local defenses as they carry out their raid, encountering unforeseen challenges and making strategic decisions.

The Fianna's bold arrival at the English court is met with swift and fierce resistance, as local forces, forewarned of their audacious approach, launch a relentless counterattack, forcing the heroes to adapt quickly and make strategic decisions about how to proceed: stealth, combat, or negotiation.

Landing in France, the Fianna are met with fierce hostility from the local defenders who anticipated their arrival, having alerted their forces due to a previous slight by the Irish folk, forcing Fionn to navigate internal dissent among his warriors as some question the wisdom of beginning their raid here, yet despite the turmoil, they press on, adapting their strategies as they engage with local defenses, encountering unforeseen challenges and making strategic decisions.

Having relied on stealth in past raids, the lack of direct confrontation has stirred discontent among some Fianna who yearn for open battle, leading to factional tensions as they arrive in Bergen where they face a formidable challenge.
Battered and bloodied from head-on battles that tested even their legendary strength, the Fianna arrive in Bergen, their resolve strained, as they face a formidable challenge.

As the Fianna arrive in Bergen, their earlier strategy of negotiation has left Oscar feeling slighted and Fergus wary of betrayal, causing tension among them, yet they know they must face the challenge ahead as they arrive in Bergen where they face a formidable challenge.

The Fianna launch a daring surprise attack on Bergen, achieving swift victory that cements their reputation as fearsome warriors but prompts Oisín to ponder the moral complexities and repercussions of their actions.

The Fianna, led by Fionn's wisdom and diplomatic prowess, successfully negotiate with the leaders of Bergen, securing not only treasure but also a lasting alliance, allowing Oisín to reflect on the power of strategy over sheer force.

name: The Lay of Laomann
story:
The Lay of Laomann
Laoidh Laomuinn Mhic an Uaimh-fhir (The Lay of Laomann)
This lay is relayed by Oisean. He is sad upon seeing a hill where there used to be a fort, and in the lay he tells the story of what happened there.
 The fort belonged to Laomunn mac an Fhuamhair (son of the giant). In a version collected in the Highlands he had subjected all of Scotland to his domination. In another version collected in Caithness he was one of the Fianna but had abandoned them when they were fighting the Scandinavians (Lochlannaich). The Fianna went to his fortress and there was a battle between them. The Fianna eventually won when Oscar killed Laomunn, although he himself was badly wounded.

scenes.setting: A misty hill overlooking the remnants of a fort
scenes.action: Oisín stands at the hill reminiscing. He recalls the time when the fort was under Laomunn mac an Fhuamhair's domain, and the Fianna were mobilizing for confrontation.
choices: Oisín decides to recount how Laomunn subjugated all of Scotland.
Oisín chooses to reflect on how Laomunn abandoned the Fianna when fighting the Scandinavians.
Oisín focuses on the role of Oscar in the battle that ensued.
scenes.trigger: Oisín's choice sets the perspective of the next scene, focusing on Laomunn as a conqueror, a deserter, or Oscar's heroism.

scenes.setting: The grand hall within Laomunn's formidable fortress
scenes.action: The Fianna confront Laomunn, leading to a fierce and desperate battle.
choices: The player decides if Oscar should confront Laomunn directly.
The player chooses to have the Fianna strategize to outmaneuver Laomunn.
The player decides that the battle should be one of sheer might with all Fianna warriors involved.
scenes.trigger: Oscar's direct confrontation could lead to him being wounded, the strategic outmaneuvering might minimize casualties, and sheer might results in a brutal conflict leading to scene 3.

scenes.setting: The battleground outside the fortress, strewn with fallen warriors
scenes.action: The battle reaches its climax as Oscar confronts Laomunn, and the outcome of their duel determines the aftermath of the conflict.
choices: Oscar defeats Laomunn but is critically wounded, leading to his uncertain fate.
Oscar defeats Laomunn with the support of the Fianna, solidifying unity among the warriors.
Oscar and Laomunn fall together, leading to a somber end where the Fianna must regroup and mourn.
scenes.trigger: The story concludes based on Oscar's victory and its cost: either his own fate is in jeopardy, the Fianna are unified in triumph, or they must recover from shared loss.

choicelist: Laomunn, emboldened by his past conquests over Scotland, stands defiantly over the grand hall as the Fianna, fueled by resentment and rage at his betrayal, clash with him in a fierce and desperate battle.

Enraged by Laomunn's betrayal during their strife with the Scandinavians, the Fianna enter the grand hall with a sense of vengeance and feeling of abandonment, their anger fueling a fierce and desperate battle as tensions run high and alliances fray.

Oscar, fueled by a fierce determination to prove his valor and driven by the weight of Oisín's recollection, charges into the fray with a mighty shout, rallying the Fianna to confront Laomunn with an intensity that shakes the very walls of the fortress, leading to a fierce and desperate battle.

Oscars valiant decision to confront Laomunn directly sets the stage for a duel filled with personal vendettas and haunting silence from the Fianna, as each blow exchanged reverberates with the tension of potential loss, until the battle reaches its climax as Oscar confronts Laomunn, and the outcome of their duel determines the aftermath of the conflict.

Through cunning strategy and deft maneuvers, the Fianna have successfully surrounded Laomunn, forcing him into a desperate confrontation with Oscar, where the outcome of their duel determines the aftermath of the conflict.

With the cries of battle echoing like a storm across the battlefield, the full might of the Fianna crashes against Laomunn’s forces with relentless fury, their combined strength carving a path through blood and chaos as Oscar, undeterred by wounds and grief, finds himself facing Laomunn in a final, decisive duel, and the outcome of their duel determines the aftermath of the conflict.

As the Fianna rally around the fallen Oscar, their victory over Laomunn is bittersweet, casting a shadow of uncertainty over their future as they tend to their wounded leader and ponder the fragile nature of their triumph.
The Fianna, united by their collective triumph over Laomunn with Oscar's leadership, renew their bond and strength, ready to face new challenges together.

In the aftermath of the duel, the Fianna gather solemnly to honor both their fallen comrade Oscar and the defeated Laomunn, vowing to rebuild their strength and unity in memory of their shared sacrifice.

name: The Lay of Maodh-Chabir and Camagich
story:
The Lay of Maodh-Chabir and Camagich
Laoidh Maodh-Chabir agus Chamagich (The Lay of Maodh-Chabir and Camagich)
One day a young woman came to the Fianna. She was the princess of Scandinavia (Lochlann), and she was beautiful and dressed in a silk cloak. A Greek warrior was pursuing her, and she asked the Fianna for refuge. The Greek warrior, Dearg mac na Deirga Dàsnaiche, arrived and there was a battle between the Fianna and his forces. Eventually Goll defeated him, bound him and sent him back to Greece for a ransom.
 A version of this lay was collected in Mull.

scenes.setting: The Fianna's camp in the forests of ancient Ireland
scenes.action: Maodh-chabir, the princess of Scandinavia, arrives seeking refuge from the pursuing Greek warrior Dearg.
choices: Offer her immediate refuge and prepare for an impending battle
Ask the princess to explain her circumstances in greater detail before deciding
Refuse her request and suggest she seeks help elsewhere
scenes.trigger: Choosing to offer refuge leads to preparations for battle; asking for more information may reveal motivations that alter the Fianna's response; refusal results in the princess leaving, possibly creating future consequences.

scenes.setting: Just outside the Fianna's camp amidst the thickening woods
scenes.action: Dearg arrives with his warriors demanding the return of Maodh-chabir, leading to a standoff.

Challenge Dearg to single combat to settle the dispute
Rally the Fianna and prepare for full combat against Dearg's forces
scenes.trigger: Negotiation could lead to a peaceful resolution or deceit; a single combat challenge alters the dynamic between the leaders; full combat leads to a broader fight, affecting the Fianna's strength.

scenes.setting: The battlefield near the Fianna's camp as the sun sets
scenes.action: Goll mac morna faces off against Dearg in a decisive confrontation.
choices: Attempt to capture Dearg and negotiate a ransom for peace
Defeat Dearg decisively, potentially leading to his fall and end of hostilities
scenes.trigger: Capturing Dearg for ransom may ensure a temporary peace and gain resources, while defeating Dearg outright could deter future threats but risk retribution. The resolution affects the Fianna's standing and future stability.

choicelist: As the princess is quickly ushered into the camp for her protection, the Fianna brace themselves, their tension mounting, as Dearg arrives with his warriors demanding the return of Maodh-chabir, leading to a standoff.

After hearing Maodh-chabir's dire tale of pursuit and betrayal, the Fianna weigh the gravity of their decision, knowing that choosing to shelter the princess has attracted the wrath of Dearg and his warriors, who now arrive at the camp demanding her return, leading to a standoff.

Having been turned away by the Fianna, Maodh-chabir was left vulnerable in the woods and was quickly discovered by the arriving Dearg and his warriors-now unbound by any obligation to the Fianna, Dearg's wrath is palpable as he demands retribution and Maodh-chabir's return, leading to a standoff.

Despite initial attempts at peaceful negotiation, tensions flare as Dearg, mistrustful of the Fianna's intentions, rejects the overtures and demands Maodh-chabir's return, escalating into a heated confrontation where Goll mac Morna finally faces off against Dearg in a decisive confrontation.

The air crackles with anticipation as Goll mac Morna, eyes blazing with the fire of battle, steps forward to honor the challenge of single combat against Dearg, a choice that has stoked the embers of animosity among both forces, while the fate of Maodh-chabir and the Fianna hangs in the balance, as Goll mac Morna faces off against Dearg in a decisive confrontation.
The Fianna, energized by the call to arms, clash violently with Dearg's forces, their valor spurring Goll mac Morna to face off against Dearg in a decisive confrontation.
Goll successfully captures Dearg, negotiating a ransom that ensures temporary peace and resources for the Fianna, though the looming threat of future conflicts with Greece remains.

Goll mac Morna triumphs over Dearg in battle, securing a hard-won peace for the Fianna, but the victory leaves a lingering tension as whispers of retribution echo through the halls of their adversaries.

name: The Lay of the Young Woman
story:
The Lay of the Young Woman
Laoidh na h-Ighinne (The Lay of the Young Woman)
Patrick noticed that Oisean/Oisín was sad and asked what was troubling him. Oisean/Oisín replied that the views around him reminded him of what had happened there long before.
 One day the Fianna saw a beautiful young woman coming towards them, dressed in fine clothes. She asked their protection, saying that the son of the king of Spain was pursuing her. Fionn promised her that. When the king of Spain’s son arrived, there was a hard fight. He killed some of the Fianna, and in some versions he killed the young woman as well. Eventually he was killed by Oscar.

scenes.setting: The lush green hills where Oisín and St. Patrick are conversing.
scenes.action: Oisín explains to St. Patrick why the surrounding landscape brings back memories of the past turmoil involving the beautiful young woman and the Fianna.
choices: Oisín chooses to recount the full tale to Patrick, starting from when they first saw the woman.
Oisín decides to focus only on the battle that ensued when the king’s son arrived.
Oisín reflects on the sorrowful outcomes without detailing the sequence of events.
scenes.trigger: Oisín's choice shapes Patrick's understanding and determines whether to proceed with a detailed recount, focus on the battle, or reflect on the aftermath.

scenes.action: She begs Fionn mac Cumhaill and the Fianna for protection from the king of Spain’s son.

Fionn decides to negotiate with the king's son for a peaceful resolution.
Fionn considers sending the woman away to avoid conflict.

Oscar fights defensively, attempting to minimize loss of life, but the outcome remains uncertain.
Oscar seeks to capture rather than kill, hoping to turn the captives to their side.
scenes.trigger: Each choice leads to different resolutions, either securing immediate victory, an uncertain future, or a potential alliance albeit with risks.

With tensions high and the air thick with the promise of bloodshed due to Oisín’s choice to relive the fierce battle, the young woman pleads desperately, her voice trembling as Fionn mac Cumhaill steels himself and the Fianna to protect her from the king of Spain’s son.

The air was tense as Fionn listened with a heavy heart to the echoes of Oisín's sorrowful reflection on their past failures, an awareness of inevitable loss weighing heavily on him as the young woman approached, begging him and the Fianna for protection from the king of Spain’s son.

Fionn, resolute in his promise to protect the young woman, orders the Fianna to brace for the imminent clash, their loyalty and valor at stake, as the king of Spain’s son storms in with vengeful fury, leading to a fierce battle with losses on both sides; Oscar faces the king's son in combat.

The king of Spain’s son rejects Fionn’s attempt at negotiation, responding with contempt and declaring war on the dishonored Fianna, leading to a fierce battle with losses on both sides; Oscar faces the king's son in combat.
Before the Fianna could send her away, the king of Spain’s son ambushes them in fury, forcing them into a desperate battle with heavy losses on both sides as Oscar faces the king's son in combat.

Oscar's fierce victory against the king of Spain's son leads to a somber triumph for the Fianna, as they mourn their fallen comrades and the burden of their hard-won safety weighs heavily on their spirits.
Oscar's defensive strategy results in a tenuous ceasefire with the king of Spain's son, leaving both sides to contemplate a fragile peace or the risk of future conflict.

Oscar successfully captures the king’s son, and through diplomacy, convinces him to join forces with the Fianna, transforming a deadly confrontation into a strategic alliance that strengthens their position and honors the promise to protect the young woman.

name: The Lay of the Woman of the Little Currach
story:
The Lay of the Woman of the Little Currach
Laoi Mná an Churacháin (The Lay of the Woman of the Little Currach)
Also known as
Laoidh an Mhoighre Bhoirb (The Lay of the Moighre Borb), Cath Rìgh na Sorcha (The Battle of the King of Sorcha), Eas Ruaidh (Assaroe)
One day the Fianna see a young woman coming to land in a coracle. She says that she is the daughter of a King from a faraway land, and that she is being pursued by a man whom she refused to marry. Having heard of the prowess of the Fianna, she made up her mind to travel to Ireland to seek their protection from her arranged suitor. The Fianna agree to serve in such a capacity. Eventually, her would-be husband arrives (variously referred to as the King of Egypt or son of the King of Sorcha, he is sometimes accompanied by the girl’s father) and demands that the Fianna hand the girl over. When they refuse, a struggle ensues in which the suitor battles and is ultimately killed by various members of the Fianna. In some tellings, Goll is the one to deliver the death blow, while elsewhere this is attributed to “the youngest” of the Fianna. In some versions, the young woman remains in Ireland as Fionn’s wife for a year after that.

scenes.action: The Fianna spot a young woman arriving in a small currach, asking for their protection.

Question the woman further to learn more about her situation before making a decision.
Turn her away, advising her to seek help elsewhere due to the potential for conflict.

If negotiating, agree to terms that benefit the Fianna and the woman.
Offer the suitor a chance at retreat with honor, saving his life but requiring a vow of peace.

Upon hearing the details of her plight, the Fianna's resolve is tested as murmurs of doubt and fear ripple through their ranks, yet they decide to stand by their promise, steeling themselves for the woman’s suitor and his entourage who arrive, demanding her return.

The woman's absence becomes a point of immediate contention as the suitor, incensed by the Fianna’s previous refusal to shelter her, accuses them of cowardice and deceit before his entourage, demanding her return.

With a swift strike from the youngest member of the Fianna, the suitor falls in battle, ensuring the young woman's safety and securing the Fianna's reputation for valor across the lands.

The successful negotiation leads to a peaceful resolution, strengthening the Fianna's alliances and securing the woman's safety, while setting the stage for future political intrigue and cooperation with the suitor's kingdom.

Honoring the Fianna's magnanimous offer, the suitor retreats with dignity, pledging a vow of peace that ensures no further threats arise, and leaves the young woman free to choose her path, strengthening the bond of trust and respect between her land and Ireland.

name: The Lay of the Black Dog
story:
The Lay of the Black Dog
Laoi na Con Duibhe (The Lay of the Black Dog)
One day the Fianna awake before sunrise and see a small man coming ashore wearing a red cloak and accompanied by a black dog. Thinking his dog to be superior to those of the Fianna, he asks them for a dog fight. They agree, and release their hounds, only for the black dog to kill them all. When he sees how ferocious the black dog is, Fionn unleashes his own hound, Bran. There is a hard fight between them, but Bran eventually kills the other dog.
 After the fight the young man tells them that he never expected that any dog could kill his own except Bran. They then bury the dogs.
 In Irish versions, which are often delivered in prose, the small man may make a wager with Conán Maol that if his hound is defeated, Conán may kill him. Instead, Conán shows him mercy and the man departs (in some versions, he returns to his homeland of Greece). Every year thereafter, he sends tribute to Conán and the Fianna as an act of thanks for his life having been spared.

In versions collected in South Uist, it is Caoilte who meets the man at the start of the lay.

scenes.setting: The shores of a misty lake at dawn, where the Fianna are camping
scenes.action: A small man in a red cloak arrives with a black dog, challenging the Fianna's hounds to a contest
choices: Accept the challenge immediately and unleash the Fianna's hounds
Challenge the small man to a wager before agreeing to the dog fight

scenes.setting: The grassy arena of battle, filled with tension and anticipation
scenes.action: The Fianna's hounds are released, only for the black dog to defeat them all until Bran is released

Observe quietly, allowing Bran's instincts to guide the battle
Intervene strategically, directing Bran in the fight
scenes.trigger: Encouraging Bran might allow him to fight more fiercely, potentially shortening the battle. Observing quietly may lead to a standard fight progression. Intervening might lead to insights into the small man's intentions or potentially reveal hidden talents in Bran.

scenes.setting: A solemn hillside where the defeated dogs are respectfully laid to rest
scenes.action: With the black dog defeated, and the wager resolved, the man must decide his next move
choices: Demand the small man's departure without further recompense
Show mercy and offer continued peaceful relations with his homeland
Accept tribute from the man as a sign of peace and respect
scenes.trigger: Demanding departure may lead to the small man leaving, but possibly holding resentment. Showing mercy could establish a positive, lasting alliance. Accepting tribute alters the relationship, allowing for a mutual exchange of respect and resources in future interactions.

The small man, eyes narrowed and voice sharp with the sting of the wager, speaks ancient binding words that echo across the glen, locking the Fianna into their promise as his black dog leaps forward, tearing through the Fianna's hounds with a brutal efficiency until Bran is released.

The Fianna, initially unsettled by the negotiation attempt viewed as a sign of weakness, rally behind Bran with increased zeal and high-stakes pride, creating a charged atmosphere as Bran confronts the black dog, ultimately defeating it as the Fianna watch intensely.

With Bran's victory echoing bravely in the air, the small man, both awed and resentful of your bolstering speech, stands before you, his eyes conflicted between vengeance and admiration, as he contemplates his next move—knowing the wager has been resolved and his dignity hangs in the balance.

As the Fianna stand in solemn silence, reflecting on their choice to observe and let nature take its course, the tension reaches its peak when the small man, seeing his hopes shattered, clutches his cloak tightly and debates whether his next words will honor the strength of their decision or fuel further conflict: with the black dog defeated, and the wager resolved, the man must decide his next move.

Sensing the strategic guidance during the battle, the small man now eyes you warily, his pride bruised and contemplating recompense under a veil of tension and potential retaliation, the somber duty of laying the defeated dogs to rest underscores the gravity of his impending decision.
The small man departs with a solemn nod, harboring a quiet resentment that sows seeds of possible future conflict between his people and the Fianna.
By showing mercy, the Fianna establish a lasting alliance with the small man's homeland, ensuring mutual respect and peace in their future encounters.

Accepting the tribute as a sign of peace and respect, the Fianna establish a mutually beneficial alliance with the small man, strengthening ties between their lands and honoring the valor of both Bran and the fallen black dog.

name: The Lay of the Boar of the Valley of the Shadow
story:
The Lay of the Boar of the Valley of the Shadow
Laoi Thuirc Ghleanna an Scáil (The Lay of the Boar of the Valley of the Shadow)
Also known as
Seilg Thuirc Ghleanna an Scáil (The Hunt of the Boar of the Valley of the Shadow)
This lay, narrated in the voice of Oisín as he speaks to Saint Patrick, recalls the Fianna’s journey to hunt for the boar of Gleann an Scáil. At one point, Oscar and Goll begin to fight when the former reminds him that it was he who killed his ancestor, Cumhall. Even though the boar evades them, Oisín recalls the great success of the hunt, for their dogs drove thousands of badgers, does, and bucks toward the awaiting Fianna, who went on to slay many of the animals.
 This lay was collected in County Galway in Ireland.

scenes.setting: The verdant yet ominous landscape of Gleann an Scáil, shrouded in mist and shadow.
scenes.action: Oisín leads the Fianna, including Oscar and Goll, as they embark on the hunt for the elusive boar rumored to dwell in the Valley of the Shadow.
choices: Oisín decides to proceed cautiously, sending scouts ahead.
Oisín chooses to charge forward in pursuit of the boar's rumored path.
Oisín opts to split the party to cover more ground.
scenes.trigger: Each choice affects how the party encounters the boar and shapes the relationships within the group, influencing the next scene's tension levels.

scenes.action: Oscar reminds Goll of his ancestor's death, leading to a heated argument that threatens to erupt into violence.
choices: Oisín intervenes to calm both warriors and remind them of the mission at hand.

name: Loinnir son of Leabhar
story:
Loinnir son of Leabhar
Loinnir mac Leabhair (Loinnir son of Leabhar)
This story is not typically Fenian, although Oisín is sometimes incorporated into the plot. Loinnir mac Leabhar, son of the King of Connacht (or son of the high king of Ireland), is out fishing or hunting with Oisín, who is often presented as his brother, when they are approached by a mysterious woman. She soon challenges them to a game of cards (or forfeits). She wins the first game and places a geis on them whereby they must find the place where she put on her shoes that morning. Other stipulations are included in various versions, for example, they may not sleep in the same place more than once until they reach the desired location, or they must complete the task within the space of a year and a day. In some tellings, she puts a geis solely on Loinnir mac Leabhar, whereby he must find her home place. (Elsewhere, he is tasked with finding a woman as beautiful as her.) The story tracks their various adventures during these pursuits.
 This story was collected in counties Cork, Galway and Mayo in Ireland.

name: Lorcán son of Lorc
story:
Lorcán son of Lorc
Lorcán mac Luirc (Lorcán son of Lorc)
Upon losing a game of forfeits (or cards in Donegal tellings) to a loathsome hag, Fionn journeys to the Eastern World to take the head of the king of Oileán Dorcha. In some tellings, the king is named “Donn mac an Deirg” or in Donegal tellings, appears as a generic unnamed giant. On his way, Fionn meets a young man. After a brief exchange, he offers his help to Fionn should he need it. When Fionn accepts, he ties his boat to the back of Fionn’s and they continue on together. Upon reaching their destination, they plot how best to carry out their task. After a series of confrontations with mercenaries, the king’s baker, and his cook, Fionn eventually engages with the king himself in a fierce fight, then kills and beheads him. Fionn returns to Ireland with the head, and in some tellings, kills the hag who had placed the geis on him to undertake the dangerous mission.

name: The Burning of Tara
story:
The Burning of Tara
Loscadh na Teamhrach (The Burning of Tara)
This story recalls the way in which an enchanter, variously referred to as ‘Aillen’ or ‘Aillin’, travels to Tara each year on the eve of Samhain to set fire to the town. To accomplish this, he places the people of Tara in a deep sleep by playing enchanted music on his harp, allowing him to then carry out his plunder uncontested. When the High King informs Fionn of this grim annual tradition, he makes up his mind to confront Aillen. Using a magic spear which had belonged to his father, Fionn successfully avoids the sleeping spell and proceeds to slay the enchanter before he can set Tara alight. In versions from Counties Donegal and Laois, the young Fionn is then granted leadership of the Fianna after presenting Aillen’s head to the High King.

name: Fionn’s Boyhood Deeds
story:
Fionn’s Boyhood Deeds
Macghníomhartha Fhinn (Fionn’s Boyhood Deeds)
This category recalls various incidents from Fionn’s childhood, including a period spent hiding in the countryside for fear that his father’s enemies would find and kill him, the origin of his name, his athletic prowess as a hurler, and the acquisition of his thumb of knowledge. In the latter tale, which is perhaps the best known of all Fionn’s childhood exploits, he catches and prepares the salmon of knowledge for his mentor, a great poet. He is given strict instructions not to eat any of it. While Fionn is roasting the fish he presses down on it, burning his thumb in the process. He instinctively puts it in his mouth to relieve the pain, and is met with a sudden burst of knowledge. From this point on, Fionn only has to place his thumb in his mouth, or in some versions chew on it, to access any information that he seeks.
 Stories of this kind are widespread and have been collected in Counties Armagh, Cavan, Clare, Cork, Donegal, Galway, Kerry, Kildare, Kilkenny, Laois, Leitrim, Limerick, Louth, Mayo, Meath, Monaghan, Roscommon, Sligo, Tipperary, Tyrone, and Waterford in Ireland; North Uist, Benbecula, South Uist, Barra, Eriskay, Vatersay, Mull, Glenorchy, Lorne, Tiree and Wester Ross in Scotland; and in Illinois in the United States.

name: Goll’s Boyhood Deeds
story:
Goll’s Boyhood Deeds
Macghníomhartha Ghoill (Goll’s Boyhood Deeds)
This category recalls various incidents from Goll’s youth. Shortly after he is born, his mother dies. After three days, young Goll begins crying and his father is unable to comfort him, try as he may. Having exhausted all other options, he takes him to a local wise man, who advises him to get the child one or more wet nurses. After drinking their milk, the young Goll sleeps uninterrupted for several days. He continues like this until he is a year old, at which time his growing strength and demand overwhelms the wet nurses. His father then returns to the wise man, who advises him to keep his son in a darkened cage with only meat to eat until he is three years old. In a development which broadly reflects a plot from Macghníomhartha Fhinn (Fionn’s Boyhood Deeds), Goll observes a hurling match taking place outside. Goll joins in, overpowering and killing several of the other players on his way to effortlessly scoring goals. Cumhall, who is the leader of the Fianna at the time, hears about Goll’s strength and performance, and begins to seek the child out to kill him. In one version, this is because some of his sons were killed by Goll during the match. Goll is sent away to Spain to escape the pursuit of Cumhall. After several years, Cumhall eventually catches up with him in Spain, and Goll asks if it would be better to fight where they stand or return to Ireland and battle beside Loch Léin. Cumhall says that it would be better that they fight in Ireland, so they return. In the ensuing battle, Goll slays Cumhall. Goll (whose original name is given as Iollann in a Scottish tale), is called “Goll” (lit. purblind) after losing an eye during his battle with Cumhall. In another Scottish account, he is given a black eye in the fight, rather than losing it.

name: Oisín’s Boyhood Deeds
story:
Oisín’s Boyhood Deeds
Macghníomhartha Oisín (Oisín’s Boyhood Deeds)
While hunting, Fionn sees a beautiful deer and sets his hounds after it. Rather than harm the deer, however, Fionn finds them playing with it. Later that evening, a beautiful woman appears before Fionn and informs him that she is the deer that he was hunting earlier. She tells him how a druid whom she refused to marry had turned her into a deer nearly a decade earlier. Fionn, being pleased with her company, agrees to marry her. One day while Fionn is away, the druid appears to the woman and changes her back into a deer. When Fionn returns, he is distressed to see that there is no sign of his wife. For years, he fruitlessly searches for her all over Ireland. One day while hunting, a young boy approaches Fionn and tells him how a druid had changed his mother into a deer, and how she used to nurse him. Fionn brings the boy home with him, knowing he is his son, and names him Oisín (meaning fawn).
