Fionn remains uncertain about the boy’s story and seeks evidence or proof from the Druid.
scenes.trigger: Embracing Oisín leads to a familial bond and the boy learning the ways of the Fianna. Seeking proof delays trust and unity, creating a path of understanding and acceptance over time.

choicelist: Despite Fionn's initial joy at discovering his wife's true identity, the knowledge of her transformation haunts him, driving him into restless nights filled with guilt and a relentless obsession for retribution against the druid, yet his efforts prove futile as years pass and Fionn is left searching for his wife unsuccessfully.

After discovering his hounds playing with the deer, Fionn feels both wonder and frustration for not seizing the moment to uncover more, leading to years of fruitless searching, haunted by the memory of that pivotal encounter with lingering regret.

Because Fionn chose to leave the deer in the forest, he is haunted by a profound sense of loss and regret, dogged by whispers from those who blame his inaction for their chieftain’s despair, leading him into a relentless and fruitless search for his wife for years, ultimately failing to find her.

Fionn, weary and frustrated from fruitless years of trusting mystical assistance, arrives at the tranquil glade with a heart hardened by the realization of the Druids' futility, only to be confronted by the young boy, Oisín, who reveals his heritage.

As Fionn retraces his steps through the hauntingly familiar forests, he encounters a mystical force that warns him of the danger in uncovering past sorrows, yet he steadfastly presses on, driven by desperation and defiance, only to discover the truth about the boy's heritage.
By embracing Oisín as his son, Fionn not only gains a cherished family bond but also nurtures Oisín into a revered warrior of the Fianna, ensuring his mother's legacy lives on in both name and valor.

After a journey of trials and conversations with the Druid, Fionn ultimately uncovers the truth about Oisín's heritage, leading to a heartfelt reunion and Fionn's eventual acceptance and embrace of Oisín as his son, solidifying their bond and Oisín's place among the Fianna.

irish_name: Mar a Mhairbh Caoilte am Famhair
name: How Caoilte Slew the Giant
story:
How Caoilte Slew the Giant
Mar a Mhairbh Caoilte am Famhair (How Caoilte Slew the Giant)
Also known as
Laoidh Chaoilte (The Lay of Caoilte)
The Fianna were hunting when a dark mist fell about them and they became lost. They sent Caoilte, the fastest runner of the Fianna, before them to find the road. He did not find the road, but he found a tower in which there was a fairy woman. She had weapons – a crossbow, seven swords, seven spears and seven hounds (or, according to some versions, five swords, five spears and five hounds). She gave him hospitality for the night and the next day told him that a giant was coming from the shore, and that death would be preferable to going to fight him. Despite this, Caoilte prepared himself for battle and went to meet the giant. The giant said that he had not come to kill him, but to see his beloved who was in the tower. Caoilte said that she would be a better partner for himself than for the giant. The giant was angry about this and told Caoilte that it was he who had killed Caoilte’s father at the Battle of Ben Cruachan (or, according to some versions from South Uist, the Battle of Ben Gulabin). They began to fight and Caoilte killed the giant, although he was also wounded badly himself. When he was lying, wounded, he heard a woman’s voice. It was Ailidh or Aine, daughter of the king of Connacht (or in some South Uist versions, Gràinne). Caoilte asked her to carry his shield (and, in one version, his sword as well) to Dùn Geal, The White Fort, or Dùn Til in some versions. She took the shield and ran so lightly that the grass did not bend under her feet as she went.

scenes.setting: A dark, mist-covered forest where the Fianna are lost during a hunt
scenes.action: Caoilte, the swiftest of the Fianna, searches for a path amid the fog and discovers a mysterious tower
choices: Enter the tower to seek guidance from the fairy woman
Return to the Fianna to update them on the situation
Continue searching the forest for the road
scenes.trigger: Entering the tower leads to an encounter with the fairy woman, returning to the Fianna leads to seeking a different path, and continuing to search risks getting further lost, all affecting the urgency and preparation for what lies ahead.

scenes.setting: Inside the tower where the fairy woman resides
scenes.action: Caoilte receives hospitality from the fairy woman and learns of the approaching giant threat
choices: Accept the fairy woman's weapons and heed her warning
Decline the fairy woman’s offer of weapons and rely on personal skills
Ask the fairy woman for more information about the giant’s intentions
scenes.trigger: Accepting the weapons prepares Caoilte for the battle with boosted confidence, declining them tests his skills, and seeking more information can reveal the giant’s connection to Caoilte’s past and his motives.

scenes.setting: The shore, where the giant has arrived and confronts Caoilte
scenes.action: Caoilte faces the giant, who reveals his past actions and his purpose
choices: Challenge the giant to a duel for Ailidh’s affection
Attempt to parley with the giant and avoid violence
Attack the giant immediately to avenge his father
scenes.trigger: Choosing to duel results in a trial of strength and wit, parleying could lead to unexpected alliances or resolutions, and attacking immediately engages in a fierce battle, each affecting whether Caoilte earns respect, resolution, or revenge.

choicelist: The fairy woman regards Caoilte’s entrance with grave eyes, warning that his soul was now woven into the fate of the realm as she reveals the giant's imminent approach, urging him to take up her enchanted weapons in preparation for the dire confrontation ahead.

Caoilte returns to the Fianna to reveal the tower and the fairy woman's warning, only to be met with skepticism and doubt from his companions, heightening the tension as he decides to heed the fairy woman's advice and heads back to accept her hospitality, where he learns of the approaching giant threat.

Having lost precious time wandering further into the mist and feeling the weight of urgency, Caoilte finally stumbles back to the enigmatic tower and finds the fairy woman agitated and disappointed by his delay, admonishing him for squandering the chance to arm himself adequately as she reveals the looming threat of the giant, offering sanctuary, weapons, and dire warnings for what awaits.

Armed with the fairy woman's weapons and heeding her ominous warning, Caoilte steels himself for the encounter, his bold acceptance seen as a slight by the giant, who angrily recalls slaying Caoilte’s father in past battle, forcing Caoilte to face the giant's complex motives as he stands ready either to fight for Ailidh's affection, reason with him, or attack immediately.

Caoilte, having refused the fairy woman's weapons out of pride in his own skills, approaches the giant with nothing but his own prowess, only to be caught off guard as the giant reveals the devastating truth of his role in the death of Caoilte's father, igniting a personal and fierce conflict over Ailidh’s affection.

Having learned from the fairy woman about the giant's connection to his past, Caoilte confronts the giant with a deep-seated need for vengeance mixed with curiosity about his father's death, leading to a charged encounter where the giant reveals his past actions and his purpose.
Caoilte, after a grueling duel of strength and wit with the giant, emerges victorious and earns both the respect of Ailidh and the honor of his slain father.

Through deft negotiation and mutual understanding, Caoilte and the giant reach a truce, forming an unexpected alliance that honors both Caoilte’s heritage and the giant’s quest for love, transforming enmity into unity.

Enraged and driven by the memory of his father's death, Caoilte launches a fierce assault on the giant, ultimately prevailing in a brutal battle, but not without sustaining grievous injuries in the process.

irish_name: Mar a Mhairbh Caoilte a’ Mhuc
name: How Caoilte Slew the Boar
story:
How Caoilte Slew the Boar
Mar a Mhairbh Caoilte a’ Mhuc (How Caoilte Slew the Boar)
One day the Fianna were hunting when they saw a huge, fierce pig. It was so strong that it killed all of the hounds they had with them. Fionn promised that the man who killed the pig would have whichever woman and treasures he wanted as a reward. Caoilte went in pursuit of the pig and they had a hard fight, but Caoilte was not able to overcome her. He called on his fairy lover for help. She came, and between them they eventually killed the pig. Following his fairy lover’s advice, Caoilte chose the first of the women who were shown to him at Fionn’s house. The women all had cloaks over their heads so that Caoilte would not recognise and choose Fionn’s wife, but she was the woman he chose.

scenes.setting: The lush, sprawling forests where the Fianna are hunting.
scenes.action: The Fianna encounter the monstrous boar, and Fionn promises a reward to whomever can slay it.
choices: Caoilte steps forward and offers to pursue the boar alone.
Caoilte suggests they pursue the boar together as a team.
Caoilte decides not to pursue the boar and suggests they retreat.
scenes.trigger: If Caoilte chooses to pursue the boar alone, he goes deeper into the forest. If he suggests teamwork, the scene shifts to a strategy session among the Fianna. If he decides to retreat, the scene explores the consequences of leaving the boar unchecked.

scenes.setting: A dense, shadowy part of the forest where the boar has made its lair.
scenes.action: Caoilte faces the boar, engaging in a brutal battle that leaves him struggling.
choices: Caoilte calls upon his fairy lover for assistance.
Caoilte decides to try a new combat strategy.
Caoilte chooses to retreat and regroup.
scenes.trigger: Calling the fairy lover results in parallel efforts that weaken the boar. A new strategy presents a creative solution to combat and may lead to a new advantage. Retreat leads Caoilte back to the Fianna, impacting their trust.

scenes.setting: Fionn’s grand hall, with the women standing cloaked before him.
scenes.action: After slaying the boar, Caoilte is to choose a reward among the cloaked women.
choices: Caoilte follows the advice of his fairy lover on whom to choose.
Caoilte uses his intuition to select a woman.
Caoilte hesitates and seeks Fionn's advice.
scenes.trigger: Guidance by the fairy lover leads him to Fionn's wife, creating potential intrigue. Intuition tests his instincts for a rewarding choice. Seeking advice impacts relationships, either causing tension or resulting in a politically favorable choice.

choicelist: Caoilte, driven by pride and the burden of his solitary choice, charges into the boar's lair, his resolve tested as he finds himself overwhelmed by the beast's sheer ferocity, leaving him on the brink of defeat and desperately needing a strategy to overcome this seemingly insurmountable foe.

Amid the echoing calls of the Fianna strategizing in the shadows, Caoilte charges the boar with renewed fury, only to find himself dodging its tusks alone as the team's formation falters, leaving him struggling in a brutal battle.

Despite his earlier suggestion to retreat, the decision leaves the Fianna vulnerable to the boar's fury, forcing Caoilte into a desperate confrontation, his comrades' lives now weighing heavily on his conscience as he engages in a brutal battle that leaves him struggling.

Moved by the powerful bond and the weight of his fairy lover's earlier intervention, Caoilte approaches the line of cloaked women amidst palpable tension in Fionn's hall, aware that the consequences of his choice could incite envy or distrust among the Fianna and perhaps even Fionn himself.

Having narrowly defeated the boar through his newfound combat strategy, defying expectations and stoking jealousy among the Fianna, Caoilte steps into Fionn’s grand hall, tension hanging in the air, as he knows his choice among the cloaked women could either honor his hard-won triumph or breed mistrust among his companions, yet now, after slaying the boar, Caoilte is to choose a reward among the cloaked women.

As Caoilte enters Fionn’s grand hall, he faces the tense and judgmental gazes of the Fianna, who question his earlier retreat and express doubt in his capability, and now, amidst this palpable tension, Caoilte is to choose a reward among the cloaked women.
By trusting his fairy lover's guidance, Caoilte selects Fionn's wife as his reward, sparking a web of intrigue and potential conflict within the Fianna.

By trusting his intuition, Caoilte selects Fionn's wife unknowingly, resulting in a mix of delight and underlying tension among the Fianna, as Fionn must subtly navigate the complexities of honor and loyalty within his ranks.
Upon seeking Fionn's advice, Caoilte is guided to choose a woman of great wisdom and beauty, strengthening bonds within the Fianna, while averting potential discord with Fionn.

name: How Bran Was Killed
story:
How Bran Was Killed
Mar Chaidh Bran a Mharbhadh (How Bran Was Killed)
Further Information
Death of Bran in battle followed by lament/praise
Most versions of this lay begin with two verses of dialogue between the heron and the wren, the heron concerned about her leg and the wren saying that he is Fionn’s physician and can heal her leg if need be. After this the story moves to “the day we slew the boar” or “the grey boar”, in most versions. The Fianna were out hunting when a fight started between Fionn’s hound Bran and Goll’s hound, the result of which was that Bran killed the other dog. Goll was furious about this and was about the kill Bran’s handler when Oisean stopped him. Oisean had already struck Bran – seemingly killing him immediately – though he bitterly regretted doing so. After this Conán asked about Bran’s attributes. Oisean then told him of how good he was at hunting all kinds of animals and concluded with a physical description: Bran had yellow paws, black sides, a white belly, a green back and crimson ears.

scenes.setting: In a quiet glen, with heron and wren conversing beside a stream.
scenes.action: The heron is worried about her injured leg, and the wren offers healing magic claiming to be Fionn's physician.
choices: Allow the wren to attempt to heal the heron's leg.
Advise the heron to seek Fionn's own assistance instead.
Ignore the wren's claims and continue with your own plans.
scenes.trigger: If the wren heals the heron, it may affect later events positively. Seeking Fionn delays the next scene and changes how allies see the player. Ignoring keeps things unchanged.

scenes.setting: A dense forest where the Fianna are hunting, and an altercation arises.
scenes.action: A fight ensues between Fionn’s hound, Bran, and Goll’s hound, resulting in Bran killing the other dog.
choices: Intervene and try to negotiate peace between Goll and Fionn.
Support Goll's anger and confront Fionn.
Take sides with Oisín in defending Bran's actions.
scenes.trigger: Negotiating peace prevents Bran from being immediately harmed, siding with Goll escalates the conflict, while supporting Oisín assures counteractions against Goll's retaliation.

scenes.setting: The contested battlefield where Bran’s fate hangs in balance.
scenes.action: Oisín strikes Bran in regret, and Conán questions Bran’s worth and legacy.
choices: Speak in defense of Bran’s attributes as a loyal companion.
Encourage Conán to consider the bond between the Fianna members over past slights.
Remain silent, letting events unfold without intervention.
scenes.trigger: Defending Bran may lead to a mournful but respectful conclusion, encouraging peace may heal rifts, while silence could result in unresolved tensions and division.

choicelist: As the Fianna chase through the forest, the air crackles with tension, for the wren's successful healing of the heron has spread whispered omens of imbalance in nature, intensifying the rivalry; fueled by this unease, a fierce fight erupts between Bran and Goll’s hound, culminating in Bran killing the other dog.

Bran, emboldened by Fionn’s endorsement and with a divine influence from the heron requesting aid, charges with ferocity against Goll’s hound, inadvertently sparking a fierce altercation between the two legendary warriors, resulting in Bran killing the other dog.

Amidst heightened tensions and suspicion, fueled by the lack of trust in magical solutions from the earlier scene, the Fianna find themselves on edge, leading to a fierce confrontation where Bran and Goll’s hound clash with fatal consequences.

Amidst the heated negotiations you attempted to broker, tensions flare as Goll, still seething from his hound's death, accuses Fionn of favoring Bran over justice, forcing Oisín, in a desperate act of atonement, to strike Bran in regret, and Conán questions Bran’s worth and legacy.

In the aftermath of siding with Goll and confronting Fionn, tensions rise as the Fianna splinter into factions, voices raised in anger and loyalty questioned, until Oisín, overwhelmed by regret and confusion amidst the discord, strikes Bran, and Conán questions Bran’s worth and legacy.

Oisín, emboldened by your support, confronts Goll's fury head-on, fiercely defending Bran's loyalty and courage to the entire Fianna, but in his heated passion, he miscalculates and in a moment of anguish strikes Bran in regret, while Conán questions Bran's worth and legacy.

Oisín's heartfelt defense of Bran's loyalty and unmatched hunting prowess softened the hearts of the Fianna, leading to a mournful yet respectful farewell to their beloved hound, which ultimately strengthened their bonds and honored Bran's legacy.
By emphasizing the deep bonds and shared history among the Fianna, Conán is persuaded to look beyond the past conflict, allowing Bran's memory to be honored and bringing healing to the group.

Silence descended upon the battlefield, leaving the Fianna divided and mourning not just Bran's loss but the fracture in their once-unbreakable bond, the wound of which would linger in their hearts for years to come.

name: Meargach of the Blades
story:
Meargach of the Blades
Meargach na Lann (Meargach of the Blades)
Also known as
Laoi Mheargaigh na Lann (The Lay of Meargach of the Blades)
Using his thumb of knowledge, Fionn sees that a large warrior is on his way to challenge him. Fionn proceeds to ask the Fianna if there is anyone who will fight in his place. After receiving a less than enthusiastic response, Oscar comes forward and says that he will fight the incoming stranger, known as Meargach. When Meargach arrives, he and Oscar engage in a prolonged battle. Seeing that Oscar is outmatched, Fionn suggests that they break until morning. Fionn lures Meargach into a false sense of security, prompting him tell stories about his life and travels late into the night while Oscar sleeps. (This motif also appears in Bás an Mhacaoibh Mhóir mhic Rí na hEaspáine [The Death of the Big Lad, son of the King of Spain].) The next morning, the two resume their fight and the well-rested Oscar has a distinct advantage. In the end, he kills Meargach.

scenes.setting: The base camp of the Fianna, amidst the rolling hills of Ireland.
scenes.action: Fionn, using his thumb of knowledge, foresees the arrival of Meargach, a formidable warrior, and asks the Fianna for a volunteer to face him.
choices: Volunteer to fight Meargach yourself.
Encourage Oscar to take up the challenge.
Consult with Fionn for a strategy.
scenes.trigger: Volunteering to fight leads directly to facing Meargach, encouraging Oscar results in Oscar preparing for the duel, while consulting Fionn provides insights and strengthens Oscar's resolve.

scenes.setting: A vast, open field at dawn, the ground still damp with morning dew.
scenes.action: Oscar and Meargach engage in a fierce battle filled with the clash of blades as Fionn observes.
choices: Encourage a temporary truce to rest until morning.
Suggest tempting Meargach to talk about his experiences and tire him out.
Aid Oscar directly by distracting Meargach during the fight.
scenes.trigger: Calling a truce leads to a night of stories weakening Meargach's spirits, tiring him through talk makes the morning fight easier, while direct interference risks worsened relations with the Fianna.

scenes.setting: The same open field now bathed in the golden light of the morning sun.
scenes.action: Oscar and Meargach resume their battle, but Oscar now has the upper hand due to the tactics employed the previous night.
choices: Strategically advise Oscar to focus on Meargach's weaknesses as learned from the stories.
Allow Oscar to fight freely, trusting his instincts.
Provide moral support from the sidelines to bolster Oscar’s confidence.
scenes.trigger: Strategic advice ensures Oscar swiftly defeats Meargach, trusting his instincts results in a hard-fought victory solidifying Oscar's legend, while moral support strengthens his resolve to win decisively. The story concludes with either peace restored or new challenges anticipated for the Fianna based on Oscar's triumph.

choicelist: As you step forward to face Meargach yourself, tension mounts, with the Fianna murmuring their doubts and Oscar expressing frustration at your risky decision, resulting in Meargach attacking you fiercely before Oscar intervenes to assist, leading to the duel between Oscar and Meargach.

With Oscar choosing to fight, the Fianna watch intently, yet whispers of doubt ripple through as some question Fionn's decision, heightening tensions as Oscar and Meargach engage in a fierce battle filled with the clash of blades as Fionn observes.

Having consulted with Fionn, Oscar enters the fray with a calculated plan, but as the battle intensifies, the sound of clashing blades fills the air and tension mounts, drawing wary glances from the Fianna as Fionn's strategy reveals its gamble amidst the ensuing chaos.

The morning sun casts long shadows as Meargach, bitter about the night’s truce and realizing he was outwitted, confronts Oscar with renewed savagery, yet Oscar remains unfazed and draws strength from the stories shared, using the insights gained to maintain his upper hand.

As the golden light of morning casts long shadows, Meargach's eyes narrow with the realization of Fionn's cunning, fueling his rage and relentless attacks, yet Oscar, empowered by Fionn's strategizing the previous night, skilfully counters, and gradually gains the upper hand.

Meargach, feeling insulted by Fionn's bold interference, turns his wrath towards Fionn with a thunderous roar that echoes across the field, forcing Oscar to defend both himself and his leader, shifting the tide of battle into unpredictable chaos as Meargach's anger propels him into a furious assault, but Oscar now has the upper hand due to the tactics employed the previous night.

Oscar, leveraging the strategic insights gained from Meargach's own tales, swiftly capitalizes on his opponent's weaknesses and skillfully defeats him, ensuring peace is restored and solidifying his heroic status among the Fianna.

Trusting his instincts, Oscar engages fiercely with Meargach, ultimately securing a hard-fought victory that enhances his legend and restores peace, setting the stage for future challenges and adventures for the Fianna.
Oscar's confidence surges with the Fianna's support, allowing him to outmaneuver Meargach and secure a decisive victory, restoring peace and securing his place as a legendary hero among the Fianna.

name: The Blue Men
story:
The Blue Men
Na Fir Ghorma (The Blue Men)
Fionn and Bran are on the beach one day when they see three big men come ashore in a coracle. They say they have come to take Fionn back to their own kingdom with them, or else they will challenge the Fianna to combat. In many versions, they state that fire can’t burn them, water can’t drown them, and they can’t be slain with weapons; nothing can defeat them but three magical caps, when placed on their heads.
 The big men do not recognise Fionn. He tricks them, saying he will go to fetch Fionn, and he sails away with Bran, his hound, until he reaches the Kingdom of the Big Men. There he meets another big man who takes him to the king. Still nobody realises that he is Fionn. The king tells him that he has not slept for more than seventeen years because every night a monster comes ashore to destroy the kingdom. In some versions, the monster has eaten the big men’s sister. Fionn tells the king that he will defend the kingdom himself, and every night for three nights he goes down to the shore and tricks the monster, telling it that the king and his family are dead. Eventually, he fights the creature and with Bran’s help he kills it. The king then realises that he is Fionn because there was a prophecy that Fionn would kill the monster. Fionn returns to Ireland and subjects the three big men to his authority and/or kills them. In many versions, this is accomplished by means of the three caps, which he stole while in the Kingdom of the Big Men.

scenes.setting: A sandy beach in Ireland, where Fionn and Bran encounter the Blue Men coming ashore.
scenes.action: The Blue Men arrive and demand that Fionn come with them or face the Fianna in combat.
choices: Agree to go with the Blue Men to their kingdom to learn more about their intentions.
Refuse to go and prepare to fight them on the beach.
Pretend to agree to go with them, but use the opportunity to learn more about the Blue Men first.
scenes.trigger: Agreeing to go leads to scene 2 in the Blue Men's kingdom. Refusing leads to immediate confrontation and scene 2 also in the Blue Men's kingdom. Pretending to agree gives Fionn more information for later scenes, starting scene 2 in the kingdom as a result of their departure.

scenes.setting: The mysterious kingdom of the Blue Men, where Fionn confronts the king about the monster threat.
scenes.action: Fionn learns from the Blue Men king about the monster that terrorizes them every night.
choices: Offer to help the king by confronting the monster single-handedly.
Convince the king to lend you some warriors for aid in facing the monster.
Offer a different strategy to trick the monster instead of fighting it head-on.
scenes.trigger: Confronting the monster leads directly to scene 3, where the battle takes place. Seeking help adds allies to scene 3, potentially changing outcomes. Attempting a trick might allow Fionn to weaken the monster, making the fight easier in scene 3.

scenes.setting: The shores of the Blue Men's kingdom, at dusk, where the monster emerges from the sea.
scenes.action: Fionn faces the monster with Bran, possibly aided by additional allies or strategies.
choices: Utilize the knowledge of the monster's habits learned earlier to gain an advantage in the fight.
Use the stolen magical caps in a crucial moment to weaken the monster further.
In case the battle turns dire, choose to retreat and regroup for a final confrontation.
scenes.trigger: Using knowledge or caps leads to successful defeat of the monster. Retreating risk losing respect but allows a chance to recover and strategize, with potential consequences for Fionn’s authority over the Blue Men.

choicelist: As Fionn agrees to accompany the Blue Men, the king watches him with a suspicious eye, challenged by the fearsome warriors who insist on testing his loyalty and revealing his true intentions, until Fionn learns from the Blue Men king about the monster that terrorizes them every night.

Fionn, having openly defied the Blue Men by refusing their demands on the beach, finds himself brought before their king, surrounded by hostile gazes and wary warriors, who inform him that his defiance and valor are the very reasons he must now address the monster that terrorizes them every night.

Upon arriving in the Blue Men's kingdom, Fionn's deception is met with suspicion and the king, furious at being tricked, demands an explanation for Fionn's charade; amidst the rising tension, Fionn boldly offers to face the monster that terrorizes them every night.

Alone on the shadowed shore with only Bran's loyal stance by his side, Fionn, having chosen to rely solely on his own prowess, feels the weight of his decision pressing heavily as the monstrous creature, more formidable than tales could convey, rises from the depths, its abyssal eyes boring into him, ready to test the mettle of a hero marked by destiny yet unaided by mortal nor magic, where the silence magnifies the simmering tension of life-or-death stakes—but still, he embraces the challenge, knowing every move must count as Fionn faces the monster with Bran, possibly aided by additional allies or strategies.

Fionn stands resolute on the shore, flanked by the warriors reluctantly lent by the king, their doubt and muttered curses amplifying the tension as the monster rises menacingly from the sea, yet amid this perilous unease, he readies himself with Bran for the fight ahead.

Fionn deceives the monster by setting up an elaborate ruse that plays on the monster's fear of the kingdom's supposed demise, fraying its resolve and buying just enough time for him and Bran—alongside any allies gathered—to face the monster at its weakest, potentially changing the tide of the battle, where he confronts it with renewed boldness as it emerges from the sea.

Fionn cleverly exploits the monster's predictable patterns, using his accumulated knowledge to outmaneuver and slay it with Bran's help, earning the respect of the Blue Men and solidifying his authority over them.

Fionn strategically uses the stolen magical caps to weaken the monstrous creature, ultimately vanquishing it with the aid of Bran, thus fulfilling the prophecy and securing his authority over the Blue Men before triumphantly returning to Ireland.

After retreating to regroup, Fionn devises a clever new strategy by observing the monster's weaknesses, ultimately leading to a triumphant return where he successfully defeats the creature and re-establishes his authority over the Blue Men.

name: The Daughter of the King under the Waves
story:
The Daughter of the King under the Waves
Nighean Righ fo Thuinn (The Daughter of the King under the Waves)
This story is usually preceded by Laoi Cholann gan Cheann (“The Lay of the Headless Body”), in which an otherworldly woman marries one of the Fianna, but leaves when he offends her.
 Here, she returns to her own land, Rìoghachd fo Thuinn (the Kingdom under the Waves), and her husband (Diarmaid or Oscar) follows her. When he eventually reaches her kingdom, he finds that she has been laid under a deadly spell and the only thing that will heal her is a certain cup owned by the king of Magh an Iongnaidh (the Plain of Wonder) or, in the Canadian version, the king of Bàrr an Iùin (Summit of Wonder [?]). After defeating the king’s warriors, he is given the cup, his wife is healed, and they return happily to the Fianna in Ireland.

scenes.setting: The shores of the Kingdom under the Waves, a mystical realm beneath the ocean's surface.
scenes.action: Diarmaid/Oscar arrives at the Kingdom under the Waves seeking his wife, Niamh Cinn Óir.
choices: Approach a group of otherworldly beings to ask for guidance.
Search the kingdom's shoreline for clues by himself.
Attempt to navigate deeper into the kingdom without guidance.
scenes.trigger: Choosing to ask for guidance leads to receiving a map of the kingdom, searching the shoreline reveals a hidden path, and navigating deeper alone results in getting temporarily lost, each path leading to different routes toward his wife's location.

scenes.setting: Central palace of the Kingdom under the Waves, lush and vibrant with opalescent halls.
scenes.action: Diarmaid/Oscar discovers Niamh Cinn Óir under a deadly spell and learns about the cup that could save her.
choices: Embark on a quest to confront the king of Magh an Iongnaidh directly for the cup.
Seek allies within the kingdom for assistance in acquiring the cup.
scenes.trigger: Choosing a direct confrontation leads to a battle with the king's warriors, while seeking allies uncovers potential inside help that might weaken the king's defenses. This choice influences the difficulty of obtaining the cup.

scenes.setting: The throne room of the king of Magh an Iongnaidh, surrounded by warriors and magical defenses.
scenes.action: Diarmaid/Oscar faces the final challenge to obtain the healing cup.
choices: Challenge the king to single combat for the cup.
Attempt to negotiate an exchange or trickery to secure the cup.
scenes.trigger: Engaging in single combat might result in a mutual respect and the cup being granted, while successful negotiation or trickery can lead to a diplomatic resolution. Each choice determines whether the return to the Fianna is triumphant or more diplomatically nuanced, potentially affecting future relations with the otherworld.

choicelist: Guided by the map received from the otherworldly beings, Diarmaid/Oscar navigates through the treacherous halls of the palace only to find Niamh Cinn Óir under a deadly spell, realizing with urgency that the sought-after cup is the sole cure she needs.

name: Oisín Keeping Watch over the Temple
story:
Oisín Keeping Watch over the Temple
Oisín ag Faire an Teampaill (Oisín Keeping Watch over the Temple)
Each night while St. Patrick is trying to build his church, something destroys the day’s progress. Oisín tells Patrick that if he were to give him his eyesight back, he would keep watch. Patrick begins to pray and Oisín quickly regains both his sight and strength. He is given a sword and put on watch duty the next evening. When Patrick and a group of his men arrive in the morning, they find the monster that had been destroying their church each night dead and skinned on the ground, with the victorious Oisín asleep nearby after having eaten half of the beast. They begin to fear that if they anger Oisín, he will kill them all. Patrick begins to pray again and Oisín soon loses his sight and strength.
 In Scottish tellings, Patrick is married to Oisín’s daughter. While building a new church one day, no one is strong enough to place a huge stone over the front door, so Patrick asks Oisín. He replies that he will do it if he is given sixteen deer to eat in order to boost his strength. In the end he is only given fifteen, and as a result places the stone slightly askew.

name: Oisín in the Land of Youth
story:
Oisín in the Land of Youth
Oisín i dTír na nÓg (Oisín in the Land of Youth)
Also known as
Laoi Oisín i dTír na nÓg (The Lay of Oisín in the Land of Youth)
International Tale Type
ATU 470B
One day while out hunting, a beautiful woman on a white horse approaches Oisín. She introduces herself as Niamh and asks him if he will accompany her back to Tír na nÓg (the Land of Youth). Although he is initially hesitant, he eventually agrees to go. He remains with her there leading a life of comfort for what he believes has been three years, when in actuality three hundred have gone by. Feeling homesick for Ireland, he asks Niamh if he can make a brief return. She agrees and gives him her white horse for the journey. However, she gives him the strict instruction not to step foot on Irish soil, as he will be instantly transformed into an old man. When arriving in Ireland, Oisín notices the vast changes which have taken place over the past three hundred years. During his travels, he sees a group of men attempting to lift a heavy stone and offers to help. He easily lifts the stone, but as he does so, the girth of his saddle breaks, sending him tumbling to the ground. Just as Niamh had said, three centuries of aging immediately catch up with Oisín, leaving him old and decrepit. The white horse quickly hastens back to Tír na nÓg without its unfortunate rider, who remains in Ireland.
 The tale is widespread, and found in Counties Antrim, Armagh, Clare, Cork, Donegal, Dublin, Fermanagh, Galway, Kerry, Kilkenny, Laois, Limerick, Mayo, Monaghan, Roscommon, Sligo, Tipperary, Waterford, Westmeath, and Wicklow in Ireland; Mull, South Uist and an unknown location in Inverness-shire in Scotland; and Maine in the United States.

Oisín continues to search for familiar landmarks, but as the weight of centuries becomes too much to bear, a momentary slip from the horse causes him to touch the ground, transforming him into an old man who ultimately must accept his place in a changed world.

name: Oisín’s View of Hell
story:
Oisín’s View of Hell
Radharc Oisín ar Ifreann (Oisín’s View of Hell)
While St. Patrick is trying to explain God’s power to Oisín, the elderly warrior remarks that if he were to see his former comrades of the Fianna in Hell, he would cede to what Patrick was saying and recognize the power of God. Patrick then prays and they are able to see the members of the Fianna struggling in Hell. In some tellings, Oisín sees Hell in a dream, while in others, the earth opens up and Patrick escorts him down to Hell. In some tellings, this interaction transpires after Oisín has already been baptised and serves to reinforce his decision. Oisín sometimes asks Patrick to relieve the suffering of the damned members of the Fianna.

name: The Race of the Hill of the Women of Fionn
story:
The Race of the Hill of the Women of Fionn
Rás Shliabh na mBan Finn (The Race of the Hill of the Women of Fionn)
Fionn mac Cumhaill is seeking a wife, and so devises a plan whereby all interested women are to take part in a race to the top of Sliabh na mBan (The Hill of the Women, i.e. Slievenamon), where he will greet the winner with the promise of marrying her. Fionn stealthily alters the result by offering assistance to Gráinne. In some tellings he offers her a shortcut up the mountain, while in others he carries her up the night before the race, giving her a default victory the following day. There are two typical endings to the tale. The more common of the two mentions Fionn and Gráinne’s subsequent marriage. The other sees the rival women jealously stone the victorious Gráinne. When she is dead, they continue to throw stones over her body, forming a large cairn at the top of the mountain.

Collected in Counties Donegal, Kerry, Kildare, and Tipperary in Ireland.

name: The Knife of the Victories
story:
The Knife of the Victories
Scian na mBua (The Knife of the Victories)
The Fianna are out hunting deer and using a powerful knife known as ‘scian na mbua’ (the blade of victories) to cut up the venison. During the course of the day, they lose the knife. They are deeply troubled as they return home without it. They decide to send Conán Maol out to look for the knife, but he soon returns empty-handed. They then send Diarmuid, who is equally unsuccessful.

Goll mac Morna is the next to go. He is determined not to return without it, and scours the valley over twenty times. Just as he is about to give up, a large castle suddenly appears before him. He cautiously approaches it and upon hearing noise inside, looks in only to see a group of small, naked, red-complexioned men passing around the knife to one another. In the blink of an eye, Goll is in their midst and recovers the knife. He proceeds to slay all of the men. As he makes his way through the castle, the ugliest hag he has ever seen soon appears before him. She informs him that he has killed her brothers, and that she will now kill him. She proceeds to carefully measure out lines on the floor, and informs Goll that the first one to reach each point may throw their opponent into the air. She beats him to the first two marks, and Goll is injured each time after she sends him flying. He quickly realizes that if he does not beat her to the third mark, he may be killed. He finally gets the better of the hag, and proceeds to throw her. When she lands, the impact sends her sharp teeth into her head, quickly killing her. In some tellings, Goll kills her outright using the knife rather than throwing. In all versions, Goll is overcome with exhaustion and takes time to rest. On his way out of the castle, he looks at the hag’s corpse and decides to give it one more thrust with the knife to ensure she is dead. When he does so, the little red men come out of her and begin attacking him. He eventually overtakes them all with the knife and proceeds on his way back to the Fianna, who lavish him with praise for recovering the lost item.

This story was collected in Counties Donegal and Kerry

irish_name: Seacht Sluasaid Chré le Cúl Fhinn
name: Seven Shovelfuls of Clay to Fionn’s Back
story:
Seven Shovelfuls of Clay to Fionn’s Back
Seacht Sluasaid Chré le Cúl Fhinn (Seven Shovelfuls of Clay to Fionn’s Back)
A mysterious, mystical woman arrives offshore in a currach, approaching the Fianna who are in the midst of preparing a feast after a day’s hunt. Fionn sets out to greet the woman, who as it turns out, is looking for him. After a brief conversation, she challenges Fionn to a game of chess (or forfeits), to which he obliges. Fionn wins the first game. Upon winning the second game, the woman imposes on Fionn that he must be her husband until such a time as seven shovelfuls of dirt are poured over him. (In some tellings, the required number is three shovelfuls.) While he initially objects, she places a geis on him to this effect, and he soon finds himself accompanying her to her father’s kingdom.

After they arrive, it becomes clear that she has tricked him and intends to give him as a prize to her father, who has long sought Fionn’s head. Fionn is soon captured and thrown in jail to await his imminent execution. One day, he asks the guards if they would like to hear some music from Ireland. Using his horn, the dord Féinne, he plays a tune which alerts Diarmaid that he is in trouble.

Diarmaid immediately makes his way to the faraway kingdom and enquires about Fionn. When he is informed that the king is planning to publicly execute Fionn, he follows the great crowd of onlookers to the castle and intervenes. He slaughters hundreds of the king’s best men and goes on to perform a number of arduous tasks set before him. When the king continues to rebuff Diarmaid’s attempts to see Fionn, Diarmaid kills him and frees the leader of the Fianna.

The two hastily make their way back to Ireland, but they are followed by an ominous cloud (or in some tellings, a large bird). When they arrive in Ireland, the woman appears from the form which has been following them. She chastises Fionn for having left and broken his obligation to her, and attempts to coax him into returning to her father’s kingdom. When Diarmaid learns that pouring seven shovelfuls of soil over Fionn will break the geis of marriage, he quickly goes about doing so. Diarmaid then kills the woman.
